author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Left Munich at 835 P M on 1st May arriving at Vienna early next morning should have arrived at 646 but train was an hour late

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: BudaPesth seems a wonderful place from the glimpse which I got of it from the train and the little I could walk through the streets

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I feared to go very far from the station as we had arrived late and would start as near the correct time as possible

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The impression I had was that we were leaving the West and entering the East the most western of splendid bridges over the Danube which is here of noble width and depth took us among the traditions of Turkish rule

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We left in pretty good time and came after nightfall to Klausenburgh

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here I stopped for the night at the Hotel Royale

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had for dinner or rather supper a chicken done up some way with red pepper which was very good but thirsty

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mem  get recipe for Mina

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I asked the waiter and he said it was called paprika hendl and that as it was a national dish I should be able to get it anywhere along the Carpathians

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I found my smattering of German very useful here indeed I dont know how I should be able to get on without it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Having had some time at my disposal when in London I had visited the British Museum and made search among the books and maps in the library regarding Transylvania it had struck me that some foreknowledge of the country could hardly fail to have some importance in dealing with a nobleman of that country

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I find that the district he named is in the extreme east of the country just on the borders of three states Transylvania Moldavia and Bukovina in the midst of the Carpathian mountains one of the wildest and least known portions of Europe

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was not able to light on any map or work giving the exact locality of the Castle Dracula as there are no maps of this country as yet to compare with our own Ordnance Survey maps but I found that Bistritz the post town named by Count Dracula is a fairly wellknown place

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I shall enter here some of my notes as they may refresh my memory when I talk over my travels with Mina

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In the population of Transylvania there are four distinct nationalities Saxons in the South and mixed with them the Wallachs who are the descendants of the Dacians Magyars in the West and Szekelys in the East and North

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am going among the latter who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This may be so for when the Magyars conquered the country in the eleventh century they found the Huns settled in it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I read that every known superstition in the world is gathered into the horseshoe of the Carpathians as if it were the centre of some sort of imaginative whirlpool if so my stay may be very interesting

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mem  I must ask the Count all about them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I did not sleep well though my bed was comfortable enough for I had all sorts of queer dreams

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was a dog howling all night under my window which may have had something to do with it or it may have been the paprika for I had to drink up all the water in my carafe and was still thirsty

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Towards morning I slept and was wakened by the continuous knocking at my door so I guess I must have been sleeping soundly then

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had for breakfast more paprika and a sort of porridge of maize flour which they said was mamaliga and eggplant stuffed with forcemeat a very excellent dish which they call impletata

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mem  get recipe for this also

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had to hurry breakfast for the train started a little before eight or rather it ought to have done so for after rushing to the station at 730 I had to sit in the carriage for more than an hour before we began to move

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It seems to me that the further east you go the more unpunctual are the trains

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: What ought they to be in China

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All day long we seemed to dawdle through a country which was full of beauty of every kind

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Sometimes we saw little towns or castles on the top of steep hills such as we see in old missals sometimes we ran by rivers and streams which seemed from the wide stony margin on each side of them to be subject to great floods

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It takes a lot of water and running strong to sweep the outside edge of a river clear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At every station there were groups of people sometimes crowds and in all sorts of attire

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some of them were just like the peasants at home or those I saw coming through France and Germany with short jackets and round hats and homemade trousers but others were very picturesque

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The women looked pretty except when you got near them but they were very clumsy about the waist

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They had all full white sleeves of some kind or other and most of them had big belts with a lot of strips of something fluttering from them like the dresses in a ballet but of course there were petticoats under them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The strangest figures we saw were the Slovaks who were more barbarian than the rest with their big cowboy hats great baggy dirtywhite trousers white linen shirts and enormous heavy leather belts nearly a foot wide all studded over with brass nails

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They wore high boots with their trousers tucked into them and had long black hair and heavy black moustaches

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They are very picturesque but do not look prepossessing

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: On the stage they would be set down at once as some old Oriental band of brigands

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They are however I am told very harmless and rather wanting in natural selfassertion

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was on the dark side of twilight when we got to Bistritz which is a very interesting old place

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Being practically on the frontierfor the Borgo Pass leads from it into Bukovinait has had a very stormy existence and it certainly shows marks of it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Fifty years ago a series of great fires took place which made terrible havoc on five separate occasions

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At the very beginning of the seventeenth century it underwent a siege of three weeks and lost 13000 people the casualties of war proper being assisted by famine and disease

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Count Dracula had directed me to go to the Golden Krone Hotel which I found to my great delight to be thoroughly oldfashioned for of course I wanted to see all I could of the ways of the country

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was evidently expected for when I got near the door I faced a cheerylooking elderly woman in the usual peasant dresswhite undergarment with long double apron front and back of coloured stuff fitting almost too tight for modesty

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I came close she bowed and said The Herr Englishman Yes I said Jonathan Harker

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She smiled and gave some message to an elderly man in white shirtsleeves who had followed her to the door

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He went but immediately returned with a letter       My FriendWelcome to the Carpathians

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am anxiously expecting      you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Sleep well tonight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At three tomorrow the diligence will      start for Bukovina a place on it is kept for you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At the Borgo      Pass my carriage will await you and will bring you to me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I trust      that your journey from London has been a happy one and that you      will enjoy your stay in my beautiful land

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Your friend  DRACULA

title: Dracula
words: 4 May

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I found that my landlord had got a letter from the Count directing him to secure the best place on the coach for me but on making inquiries as to details he seemed somewhat reticent and pretended that he could not understand my German

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This could not be true because up to then he had understood it perfectly at least he answered my questions exactly as if he did

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He and his wife the old lady who had received me looked at each other in a frightened sort of way

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter and that was all he knew

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula and could tell me anything of his castle both he and his wife crossed themselves and saying that they knew nothing at all simply refused to speak further

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask any one else for it was all very mysterious and not by any means comforting

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Just before I was leaving the old lady came up to my room and said in a very hysterical way  Must you go Oh young Herr must you go

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She was in such an excited

title: Dracula
words: I was just able to follow her by asking many questions

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I told her that I must go at once and that I was engaged on important business she asked again  Do you know what day it is

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I answered that it was the fourth of May

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She shook her head as she said again  Oh yes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I know that

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I know that but do you know what day it is

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: On my saying that I did not understand she went on  It is the eve of St Georges Day

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Do you not know that tonight when the clock strikes midnight all the evil things in the world will have full sway

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Do you know where you are going and what you are going to

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She was in such evident distress that I tried to comfort her but without effect

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Finally she went down on her knees and implored me not to go at least to wait a day or two before starting

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was all very ridiculous but I did not feel comfortable

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: However there was business to be done and I could allow nothing to interfere with it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I therefore tried to raise her up and said as gravely as I could that I thanked her but my duty was imperative and that I must go

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She then rose and dried her eyes and taking a crucifix from her neck offered it to me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I did not know what to do for as an English Churchman I have been taught to regard such things as in some measure idolatrous and yet it seemed so ungracious to refuse an old lady meaning so well and in such a state of mind

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She saw I suppose the doubt in my face for she put the rosary round my neck and said For your mothers sake and went out of the room

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am writing up this part of the diary whilst I am waiting for the coach which is of course late and the crucifix is still round my neck

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Whether it is the old ladys fear or the many ghostly traditions of this place or the crucifix itself I do not know but I am not feeling nearly as easy in my mind as usual

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If this book should ever reach Mina before I do let it bring my goodbye

words: 5 May

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Castle

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The grey of the morning has passed and the sun is high over the distant horizon which seems jagged whether with trees or hills I know not for it is so far off that big things and little are mixed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am not sleepy and as I am not to be called till I awake naturally I write till sleep comes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There are many odd things to put down and lest who reads them may fancy that I dined too well before I left Bistritz let me put down my dinner exactly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I dined on what they called robber steakbits of bacon onion and beef seasoned with red pepper and strung on sticks and roasted over the fire in the simple style of the London cats meat

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The wine was Golden Mediasch which produces a queer sting on the tongue which is however not disagreeable

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had only a couple of glasses of this and nothing else

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I got on the coach the driver had not taken his seat and I saw him talking with the landlady

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They were evidently talking of me for every now and then they looked at me and some of the people who were sitting on the bench outside the doorwhich they call by a name meaning wordbearercame and listened and then looked at me most of them pityingly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could hear a lot of words often repeated queer words for there were many nationalities in the crowd so I quietly got my polyglot dictionary from my bag and looked them out

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must say they were not cheering to me for amongst them were OrdogSatan pokolhell stregoicawitch vrolok and vlkoslakboth of which mean the same thing one being Slovak and the other Servian for something that is either werewolf or vampire

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mem  I must ask the Count about these superstitions  When we started the crowd round the inn door which had by this time swelled to a considerable size all made the sign of the cross and pointed two fingers towards me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With some difficulty I got a fellowpassenger to tell me what they meant he would not answer at first but on learning that I was English he explained that it was a charm or guard against the evil eye

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This was not very pleasant for me just starting for an unknown place to meet an unknown man but every one seemed so kindhearted and so sorrowful and so sympathetic that I could not but be touched

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I shall never forget the last glimpse which I had of the innyard and its crowd of picturesque figures all crossing themselves as they stood round the wide archway with its background of rich foliage of oleander and orange trees in green tubs clustered in the centre of the yard

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then our driver whose wide linen drawers covered the whole front of the boxseatgotza they call themcracked his big whip over his four small horses which ran abreast and we set off on our journey

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I soon lost sight and recollection of ghostly fears in the beauty of the scene as we drove along although had I known the language or rather languages which my fellowpassengers were speaking I might not have been able to throw them off so easily

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Before us lay a green sloping land full of forests and woods with here and there steep hills crowned with clumps of trees or with farmhouses the blank gable end to the road

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was everywhere a bewildering mass of fruit blossomapple plum pear cherry and as we drove by I could see the green grass under the trees spangled with the fallen petals

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In and out amongst these green hills of what they call here the Mittel Land ran the road losing itself as it swept round the grassy curve or was shut out by the straggling ends of pine woods which here and there ran down the hillsides like tongues of flame

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The road was rugged but still we seemed to fly over it with a feverish haste

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could not understand then what the haste meant but the driver was evidently bent on losing no time in reaching Borgo Prund

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was told that this road is in summertime excellent but that it had not yet been put in order after the winter snows

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In this respect it is different from the general run of roads in the Carpathians for it is an old tradition that they are not to be kept in too good order

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Of old the Hospadars would not repair them lest the Turk should think that they were preparing to bring in foreign troops and so hasten the war which was always really at loading point

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Beyond the green swelling hills of the Mittel Land rose mighty slopes of forest up to the lofty steeps of the Carpathians themselves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Right and left of us they towered with the afternoon sun falling full upon them and bringing out all the glorious colours of this beautiful range deep blue and purple in the shadows of the peaks green and brown where grass and rock mingled and an endless perspective of jagged rock and pointed crags till these were themselves lost in the distance where the snowy peaks rose grandly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here and there seemed mighty rifts in the mountains through which as the sun began to sink we saw now and again the white gleam of falling water

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One of my companions touched my arm as we swept round the base of a hill and opened up the lofty snowcovered peak of a mountain which seemed as we wound on our serpentine way to be right before us  Look

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Isten szekGods seatand he crossed himself reverently

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As we wound on our endless way and the sun sank lower and lower behind us the shadows of the evening began to creep round us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This was emphasised by the fact that the snowy mountaintop still held the sunset and seemed to glow out with a delicate cool pink

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here and there we passed Cszeks and Slovaks all in picturesque attire but I noticed that goitre was painfully prevalent

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: By the roadside were many crosses and as we swept by my companions all crossed themselves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here and there was a peasant man or woman kneeling before a shrine who did not even turn round as we approached but seemed in the selfsurrender of devotion to have neither eyes nor ears for the outer world

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There were many things new to me for instance hayricks in the trees and here and there very beautiful masses of weeping birch their white stems shining like silver through the delicate green of the leaves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Now and again we passed a leiterwagonthe ordinary peasants cartwith its long snakelike vertebra calculated to suit the inequalities of the road

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: On this were sure to be seated quite a group of homecoming peasants the Cszeks with their white and the Slovaks with their coloured sheepskins the latter carrying lancefashion their long staves with axe at end

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As the evening fell it began to get very cold and the growing twilight seemed to merge into one dark mistiness the gloom of the trees oak beech and pine though in the valleys which ran deep between the spurs of the hills as we ascended through the Pass the dark firs stood out here and there against the background of latelying snow

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Sometimes as the road was cut through the pine woods that seemed in the darkness to be closing down upon us great masses of greyness which here and there bestrewed the trees produced a peculiarly weird and solemn effect which carried on the thoughts and grim fancies engendered earlier in the evening when the falling sunset threw into strange relief the ghostlike clouds which amongst the Carpathians seem to wind ceaselessly through the valleys

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Sometimes the hills were so steep that despite our drivers haste the horses could only go slowly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I wished to get down and walk up them as we do at home but the driver would not hear of it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: No no he said you must not walk here the dogs are too fierce and then he added with what he evidently meant for grim pleasantryfor he looked round to catch the approving smile of the restand you may have enough of such matters before you go to sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The only stop he would make was a moments pause to light his

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One by one several of the passengers offered me gifts which they pressed upon me with an earnestness which would take no denial these were certainly of an odd and varied kind but each was given in simple good faith with a kindly word and a blessing and that strange mixture of fearmeaning movements which I had seen outside the hotel at Bistritzthe sign of the cross and the guard against the evil eye

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then as we flew along the driver leaned forward and on each side the passengers craning over the edge of the coach peered eagerly into the darkness

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was evident that something very exciting was either happening or expected but though I asked each passenger no one would give me the slightest explanation

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This state of excitement kept on for some little time and at last we saw before us the Pass opening out on the eastern side

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There were dark rolling clouds overhead and in the air the heavy oppressive sense of thunder

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It seemed as though the mountain range had separated two atmospheres and that now we had got into the thunderous one

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was now myself looking out for the conveyance which was to take me to the Count

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Each moment I expected to see the glare of lamps through the blackness but all was dark

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The only light was the flickering rays of our own lamps in which the steam from our harddriven horses rose in a white cloud

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We could see now the sandy road lying white before us but there was on it no sign of a vehicle

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The passengers drew back with a sigh of gladness which seemed to mock my own disappointment

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was already thinking what I had best do when the driver looking at his watch said to the others something which I could hardly hear it was spoken so quietly and in so low a tone I thought it was An hour less than the time

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then turning to me he said in German worse than my own  There is no carriage here

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Herr is not expected after all

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He will now come on to Bukovina and return tomorrow or the next day better the next day

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Whilst he was speaking the horses began to neigh and snort and plunge wildly so that the driver had to hold them up

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then amongst a chorus of screams from the peasants and a universal crossing of themselves a calèche with four horses drove up behind us overtook us and drew up beside the coach

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could see from the flash of our lamps as the rays fell on them that the horses were coalblack and splendid animals

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They were driven by a tall man with a long brown beard and a great black hat which seemed to hide his face from us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could only see the gleam of a pair of very bright eyes which seemed red in the lamplight as he turned to us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He said to the driver  You are early tonight my friend

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The man stammered in reply  The English Herr was in a hurry to which the stranger replied  That is why I suppose you wished him to go on to Bukovina

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You cannot deceive me my friend I know too much and my horses are swift

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As he spoke he smiled and the lamplight fell on a hardlooking mouth with very red lips and sharplooking teeth as white as ivory

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One of my companions whispered to another the line from Burgers Lenore      Denn die Todten reiten schnell     For the dead travel fast

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The strange driver evidently heard the words for he looked up with a gleaming smile

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The passenger turned his face away at the same time putting out his two fingers and crossing himself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Give me the Herrs luggage said the driver and with exceeding alacrity my bags were handed out and put in the calèche

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then I descended from the side of the coach as the calèche was close alongside the driver helping me with a hand which caught my arm in a grip of steel his strength must have been prodigious

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Without a word he shook his reins the horses turned and we swept into the darkness of the Pass

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As I looked back I saw the steam from the horses of the coach by the light of the lamps and projected against it the figures of my late companions crossing themselves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then the driver cracked his whip and called to his horses and off they swept on their way to Bukovina

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As they sank into the darkness I felt a strange chill and a lonely feeling came over me but a cloak was thrown over my shoulders and a rug across my knees and the driver said in excellent German  The night is chill mein Herr and my master the Count bade me take all care of you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There is a flask of slivovitz the plum brandy of the country underneath the seat if you should require it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I did not take any but it was a comfort to know it was there all the same

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I felt a little strangely and not a little frightened

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I think had there been any alternative I should have taken it instead of prosecuting that unknown night journey

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The carriage went at a hard pace straight along then we made a complete turn and went along another straight road

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It seemed to me that we were simply going over and over the same ground again and so I took note of some salient point and found that this was so

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I would have liked to have asked the driver what this all meant but I really feared to do so for I thought that placed as I was any protest would have had no effect in case there had been an intention to delay

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Byandby however as I was curious to know how time was passing I struck a match and by its flame looked at my watch it was within a few minutes of midnight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This gave me a sort of shock for I suppose the general superstition about midnight was increased by my recent experiences

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I waited with a sick feeling of suspense

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then a dog began to howl somewhere in a farmhouse far down the roada long agonised wailing as if from fear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The sound was taken up by another dog and then another and another till borne on the wind which now sighed softly through the Pass a wild howling began which seemed to come from all over the country as far as the imagination could grasp it through the gloom of the night

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At the first howl the horses began to strain and rear but the driver spoke to them soothingly and they quieted down but shivered and sweated as though after a runaway from sudden fright

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then far off in the distance from the mountains on each side of us began a louder and a sharper howlingthat of wolveswhich affected both the horses and myself in the same wayfor I was minded to jump from the calèche and run whilst they reared again and plunged madly so that the driver had to use all his great strength to keep them from bolting

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In a few minutes however my own ears got accustomed to the sound and the horses so far became quiet that the driver was able to descend and to stand before them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He petted and soothed them and whispered something in their ears as I have heard of horsetamers doing and with extraordinary effect for under his caresses they became quite manageable again though they still trembled

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The driver again took his seat and shaking his reins started off at a great pace

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This time after going to the far side of the Pass he suddenly turned down a narrow roadway which ran sharply to the right

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Soon we were hemmed in with trees which in places arched right over the roadway till we passed as through a tunnel and again great frowning rocks guarded us boldly on either side

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Though we were in shelter we could hear the rising wind for it moaned and whistled through the rocks and the branches of the trees crashed together as we swept along

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It grew colder and colder still and fine powdery snow began to fall so that soon we and all around us were covered with a white blanket

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The keen wind still carried the howling of the dogs though this grew fainter as we went on our way

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The baying of the wolves sounded nearer and nearer as though they were closing round on us from every side

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I grew dreadfully afraid and the horses shared my fear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The driver however was not in the least disturbed he kept turning his head to left and right but I could not see anything through the darkness

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Suddenly away on our left I saw a faint flickering blue flame

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The driver saw it at the same moment he at once checked the horses and jumping to the ground disappeared into the darkness

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I did not know what to do the less as the howling of the wolves grew closer but while I wondered the driver suddenly appeared again and without a word took his seat and we resumed our journey

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I think I must have fallen asleep and kept dreaming of the incident for it seemed to be repeated endlessly and now looking back it is like a sort of awful nightmare

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Once the flame appeared so near the road that even in the darkness around us I could watch the drivers motions

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He went rapidly to where the blue flame aroseit must have been very faint for it did not seem to illumine the place around it at alland gathering a few stones formed them into some device

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Once there appeared a strange optical effect when he stood between me and the flame he did not obstruct it for I could see its ghostly flicker all the same

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This startled me but as the effect was only momentary I took it that my eyes deceived me straining through the darkness

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then for a time there were no blue flames and we

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: sped onwards through the gloom with the howling of the wolves around us as though they were following in a moving circle

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At last there came a time when the driver went further afield than he had yet gone and during his absence the horses began to tremble worse than ever and to snort and scream with fright

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could not see any cause for it for the howling of the wolves had ceased altogether but just then the moon sailing through the black clouds appeared behind the jagged crest of a beetling pineclad rock and by its light I saw around us a ring of wolves with white teeth and lolling red tongues with long sinewy limbs and shaggy hair

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They were a hundred times more terrible in the grim silence which held them than even when they howled

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For myself I felt a sort of paralysis of fear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is only when a man feels himself face to face with such horrors that he can understand their true import

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All at once the wolves began to howl as though the moonlight had had some peculiar effect on them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The horses jumped about and reared and looked helplessly round with eyes that rolled in a way painful to see but the living ring of terror encompassed them on every side and they had perforce to remain within it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I called to the coachman to come for it seemed to me that our only chance was to try to break out through the ring and to aid his approach

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I shouted and beat the side of the calèche hoping by the noise to scare the wolves from that side so as to give him a chance of reaching the trap

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: How he came there I know not but I heard his voice raised in a tone of imperious command and looking towards the sound saw him stand in the roadway

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As he swept his long arms as though brushing aside some impalpable obstacle the wolves fell back and back further still

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Just then a heavy cloud passed across the face of the moon so that we were again in darkness

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I could see again the driver was climbing into the calèche and the wolves had disappeared

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This was all so strange and uncanny that a dreadful fear came upon me and I was afraid to speak or move

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The time seemed interminable as we swept on our way now in almost complete darkness for the rolling clouds obscured the moon

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We kept on ascending with occasional periods of quick descent but in the main always ascending

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Suddenly I became conscious of the fact that the driver was in the act of pulling up the horses in the courtyard of a vast ruined castle from whose tall black windows came no ray of light and whose broken battlements showed a jagged line against the moonlit sky

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: CHAPTER II  JONATHAN HARKERS JOURNAL continued     5 May

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must have been asleep for certainly if I had been fully awake I must have noticed the approach of such a remarkable place

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In the gloom the courtyard looked of considerable size and as several dark ways led from it under great round arches it perhaps seemed bigger than it really is

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have not yet been able to see it by daylight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When the calèche stopped the driver jumped down and held out his hand to assist me to alight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Again I could not but notice his prodigious strength

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His hand actually seemed like a steel vice that could have crushed mine if he had chosen

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he took out my traps and placed them on the ground beside me as I stood close to a great door old and studded with large iron nails and set in a projecting doorway of massive stone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could see even in the dim light that the stone was massively carved but that the carving had been much worn by time and weather

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As I stood the driver jumped again into his seat and shook the reins the horses started forward and trap and all disappeared down one of the dark openings

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I stood in silence where I was for I did not know what to do

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Of bell or knocker there was no sign through these frowning walls and dark window openings it was not likely that my voice could penetrate

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The time I waited seemed endless and I felt doubts and fears crowding upon me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: What sort of place had I come to and among what kind of people

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: What sort of grim adventure was it on which I had embarked

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Was this a customary incident in the life of a solicitors clerk sent out to explain the purchase of a London estate to a foreigner

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Solicitors clerk

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mina would not like that

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Solicitorfor just before leaving London I got word that my examination was successful and I am now a fullblown solicitor

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I began to rub my eyes and pinch myself to see if I were awake

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It all seemed like a horrible nightmare to me and I expected that I should suddenly awake and find myself at home with the dawn struggling in through the windows as I had now and again felt in the morning after a day of overwork

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But my flesh answered the pinching test and my eyes were not to be deceived

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was indeed awake and among the Carpathians

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All I could do now was to be patient and to wait the coming of the morning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Just as I had come to this conclusion I heard a heavy step approaching behind the great door and saw through the chinks the gleam of a coming light

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then there was the sound of rattling chains and the clanking of massive bolts drawn back

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A key was turned with the loud grating noise of long disuse and the great door swung back

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Within stood a tall old man clean shaven save for a long white moustache and clad in black from head to foot without a single speck of colour about him anywhere

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He held in his hand an antique silver lamp in which the flame burned without chimney or globe of any kind throwing long quivering shadows as it flickered in the draught of the open door

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The old man motioned me in with his right hand with a courtly gesture saying in excellent English but with a strange intonation  Welcome to my house

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Enter freely and of your own will

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He made no motion of stepping to meet me but stood like a statue as though his gesture of welcome had fixed him into stone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The instant however that I had stepped over the threshold he moved impulsively forward and holding out his hand grasped mine with a strength which made me wince an effect which was not lessened by the fact that it seemed as cold as icemore like the hand of a dead than a living man

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Again he said  Welcome to my house

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Come freely

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Go safely and leave something of the happiness you bring

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The strength of the handshake was so much akin to that which I had noticed in the driver whose face I had not seen that for a moment I doubted if it were not the same person to whom I was speaking so to make sure I said interrogatively  Count Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He bowed in a courtly way as he replied  I am Dracula and I bid you welcome Mr Harker to my house

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Come in the night air is chill and you must need to eat and rest

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As he was speaking he put the lamp on a bracket on the wall and stepping out took my luggage he had carried it in before I could forestall him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I protested but he insisted  Nay sir you are my guest

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is late and my people are not available

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Let me see to your comfort myself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He insisted on carrying my traps along the passage and then up a great winding stair and along another great passage on whose stone floor our steps rang heavily

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At the end of this he threw open a heavy door and I rejoiced to see within a welllit room in which a table was spread for supper and on whose mighty hearth a great fire of logs freshly replenished flamed and flared

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Count halted putting down my bags closed the door and crossing the room opened another door which led into a small octagonal room lit by a single lamp and seemingly without a window of any sort

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Passing through this he opened another door and motioned me to enter

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was a welcome sight for here was a great bedroom well lighted and warmed with another log firealso added to but lately for the top logs were freshwhich sent a hollow roar up the wide chimney

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Count himself left my luggage inside and withdrew saying before he closed the door  You will need after your journey to refresh yourself by making your toilet

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I trust you will find all you wish

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When you are ready come into the other room where you will find your supper prepared

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The light and warmth and the Counts courteous welcome seemed to have dissipated all my doubts and fears

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Having then reached my normal state I discovered that I was half famished with hunger so making a hasty toilet I went into the other room

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I found supper already laid out

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My host who stood on one side of the great fireplace leaning against the stonework made a graceful wave of his hand to the table and said  I pray you be seated and sup how you please

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You will I trust excuse me that I do not join you but I have dined already and I do not sup

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I handed to him the sealed letter which Mr Hawkins had entrusted to me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He opened it and read it gravely then with a charming smile he handed it to me to read

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One passage of it at least gave me a thrill of pleasure

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must regret that an attack of gout from which malady I am a constant sufferer forbids absolutely any travelling on my part for some time to come but I am happy to say I can send a sufficient substitute one in whom I have every possible confidence

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He is a young man full of energy and talent in his own way and of a very faithful disposition

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He is discreet and silent and has grown into manhood in my service

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He shall be ready to attend on you when you will during his stay and shall take your instructions in all matters

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Count himself came forward and took off the cover of a dish and I fell to at once on an excellent roast chicken

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This with some cheese and a salad and a bottle of old Tokay of which I had two glasses was my supper

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: During the time I was eating it the Count asked me many questions as to my journey and I told him by degrees all I had experienced

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: By this time I had finished my supper and by my hosts desire had drawn up a

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mr Hawkins

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: London

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: London

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: a chair by the fire and begun to smoke a cigar which he offered me at the same time excusing himself that he did not smoke

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had now an opportunity of observing him and found him of a very marked physiognomy

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His face was a stronga very strongaquiline with high bridge of the thin nose and peculiarly arched nostrils with lofty domed forehead and hair growing scantily round the temples but profusely elsewhere

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His eyebrows were very massive almost meeting over the nose and with bushy hair that seemed to curl in its own profusion

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The mouth so far as I could see it under the heavy moustache was fixed and rather cruellooking with peculiarly sharp white teeth these protruded over the lips whose remarkable ruddiness showed astonishing vitality in a man of his years

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For the rest his ears were pale and at the tops extremely pointed the chin was broad and strong and the cheeks firm though thin

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The general effect was one of extraordinary pallor

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Hitherto I had noticed the backs of his hands as they lay on his knees in the firelight and they had seemed rather white and fine but seeing them now close to me I could not but notice that they were rather coarsebroad with squat fingers

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Strange to say there were hairs in the centre of the palm

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The nails were long and fine and cut to a sharp point

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As the Count leaned over me and his hands touched me I could not repress a shudder

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It may have been that his breath was rank but a horrible feeling of nausea came over me which do what I would I could not conceal

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Count evidently noticing it drew back and with a grim sort of smile which showed more than he had yet done his protuberant teeth sat himself down again on his own side of the fireplace

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We were both silent for a while and as I looked towards the window I saw the first dim streak of the coming dawn

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There seemed a strange stillness over everything but as I listened I heard as if from down below in the valley the howling of many wolves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Counts eyes gleamed and he said  Listen to themthe children of the night

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: What music they make

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Seeing I suppose some expression in my face strange to him he added  Ah sir you dwellers in the city cannot enter into the feelings of the hunter

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he rose and said  But you must be tired

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Your bedroom is all ready and tomorrow you shall sleep as late as you will

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have to be away till the afternoon so sleep well and dream well

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With a courteous bow he opened for me himself the door to the octagonal room and I entered my bedroom

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am all in a sea of wonders

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I doubt I fear I think strange things which I dare not confess to my own soul

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: God keep me if only for the sake of those dear to me                                        7 May

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is again early morning but I have rested and enjoyed the last twentyfour hours

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I slept till late in the day and awoke of my own accord

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I had dressed myself I went into the room where we had supped and found a cold breakfast laid out with coffee kept hot by the pot being placed on the hearth

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was a card on the table on which was written  I have to be absent for a while

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Do not wait for meD

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I set to and enjoyed a hearty meal

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I had done I looked for a bell so that I might let the servants know I had finished but I could not find one

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There are certainly odd deficiencies in the house considering the extraordinary evidences of wealth which are round me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The table service is of gold and so beautifully wrought that it must be of immense value

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The curtains and upholstery of the chairs and sofas and the hangings of my bed are of the costliest and most beautiful fabrics and must have been of fabulous value when they were made for they are centuries old though in excellent order

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I saw something like them in Hampton Court but there they were worn and frayed and motheaten

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But still in none of the rooms is there a mirror

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There is not even a toilet glass on my table and I had to get the little shaving glass from my bag before I could either shave or brush my hair

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have not yet seen a servant anywhere or heard a sound near the castle except the howling of wolves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some time after I had finished my mealI do not know whether to call it breakfast or dinner for it was between five and six oclock when I had itI looked about for something to read for I did not like to go about the castle until I had asked the Counts permission

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was absolutely nothing in the room book newspaper or even writing materials so I opened another door in the room and found a sort of library

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The door opposite mine I tried but found it locked

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In the library I found to my great delight a vast number of English books whole shelves full of them and bound volumes of magazines and newspapers

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A table in the centre was littered with English magazines and newspapers though none of them were of very recent date

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The books were of the most varied kindhistory geography politics political economy botany geology lawall relating to England and English life and customs and manners

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There were even such books of reference as the London Directory the Red and Blue books Whitakers Almanac the Army and Navy Lists andit somehow gladdened my heart to see itthe Law List

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Whilst I was looking at the books the door opened and the Count entered

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He saluted me in a hearty way and hoped that I had had a good nights rest

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he went on  I am glad you found your way in here for I am sure there is much that will interest you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: These companionsand he laid his hand on some of the bookshave been good friends to me and for some years past ever since I had the idea of going to London have given me many many hours of pleasure

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Through them I have come to know your great England and to know her is to love her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I long to go through the crowded streets of your mighty London to be in the midst of the whirl and rush of humanity to share its life its change its death and all that makes it what it is

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But alas as yet I only know your tongue through books

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: To you my friend I look that I know it to speak

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But Count I said you know and speak English thoroughly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He bowed gravely

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I thank you my friend for your all tooflattering estimate but yet I fear that I am but a little way on the road I would travel

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: True I know the grammar and the words but yet I know not how to speak them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Indeed I said you speak excellently

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Not so he answered

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Well I know that did I move and speak in your London none there are who would not know me for a stranger

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: That is not enough for me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here I am noble I am  boyar  the common people know me and I am master

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But a stranger in a strange land he is no one men know him notand to know not is to care not for

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am content if I am like the rest so that no man stops if he see me or pause in his speaking if he hear my words Ha ha a stranger

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have been so long master that I would be master stillor at least that none other should be master of me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You come to me not alone as agent of my friend Peter Hawkins of Exeter to tell me all about my new estate in London

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You shall I trust rest here with me awhile so that by our talking I may learn the English intonation and I would that you tell me when I make error even of the smallest in my speaking

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am sorry that I had to be away so long today but you will I know forgive one who has so many important affairs in hand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Of course I said all I could about being willing and asked if I might come into that room when I chose

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He answered Yes certainly and added  You may go anywhere you wish in the castle except where the doors are locked where of course you will not wish to go

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There is reason that all things are as they are and did you see with my eyes and know with my knowledge you would perhaps better understand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I said I was sure of this and then he went on  We are in Transylvania and Transylvania is not England

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Our ways are not your ways and there shall be to you many strange things

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Nay from what you have told me of your experiences already you know something of what strange things there may be

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This led to much conversation and as it was evident that he wanted to talk if only for talkings sake I asked him many questions regarding things that had already happened to me or come within my notice

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Sometimes he sheered off the subject or turned the conversation by pretending not to understand but generally he answered all I asked most frankly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then as time went on and I had got somewhat bolder I asked him of some of the strange things of the preceding night as for instance why the coachman went to the places where he had seen the blue flames

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He then explained to me that it was commonly believed that on a certain night of the yearlast night in fact when all evil spirits are supposed to have unchecked swaya blue flame is seen over any place where treasure has been concealed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: That treasure has been hidden he went on in the region through which you came last night there can be but little doubt for it was the ground fought over for centuries by the Wallachian the Saxon and the Turk

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Why there is hardly a foot of soil in all this region that has not been enriched by the blood of men patriots or invaders

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In old days there were stirring times when the Austrian and the Hungarian came up in hordes and the patriots went out to meet themmen and women the aged and the children tooand waited their coming on the rocks above the passes that they might sweep destruction on them with their artificial avalanches

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When the invader was triumphant he found but little for whatever there was had been sheltered in the friendly soil

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But how said I can it have remained so long undiscovered when there is a sure index to it if men will but take the trouble to l

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Count smiled and as his lips ran back over his gums the long sharp canine teeth showed out strangely he answered  Because your peasant is at heart a coward and a fool

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Those flames only appear on one night and on that night no man of this land will if he can help it stir without his doors

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And dear sir even if he did he would not know what to do

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Why even the peasant that you tell me of who marked the place of the flame would not know where to look in daylight even for his own work

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Even you would not I dare be sworn be able to find these places again  There you are right I said

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I know no more than the dead where even to look for them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then we drifted into other matters

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Come he said at last tell me of London and of the house which you have procured for me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With an apology for my remissness I went into my own room to get the papers from my bag

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Whilst I was placing them in order I heard a rattling of china and silver in the next room and as I passed through noticed that the table had been cleared and the lamp lit for it was by this time deep into the dark

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The lamps were also lit in the study or library and I found the Count lying on the sofa reading of all things in the world an English Bradshaws Guide

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I came in he cleared the books and papers from the table and with him I went into plans and deeds and figures of all sorts

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was interested in everything and asked me a myriad questions about the place and its surroundings

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He clearly had studied beforehand all he could get on the subject of the neighbourhood for he evidently at the end knew very much more than I did

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I remarked this he answered  Well but my friend is it not needful that I should

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I go there I shall be all alone and my friend Harker Jonathannay pardon me I fall into my countrys habit of putting your patronymic firstmy friend Jonathan Harker will not be by my side to correct and aid me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He will be in Exeter miles away probably working at papers of the law with my other friend Peter Hawkins

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: So  We went thoroughly into the business of the purchase of the estate at Purfleet

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I had told him the facts and got his signature to the necessary papers and had written a letter with them ready to post to Mr Hawkins he began to ask me how I had come across so suitable a place

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I read to him the notes which I had made at the time and which I inscribe here  At Purfleet on a byroad I came across just such a place as seemed to be required and where was displayed a dilapidated notice that the place was for sale

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is surrounded by a high wall of ancient structure built of heavy stones and has not been repaired for a large number of years

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The closed gates are of heavy old oak and iron all eaten with rust

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The estate is called Carfax no doubt a corruption of the old  Quatre Face  as the house is foursided agreeing with the cardinal points of the compass

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It contains in all some twenty acres quite surrounded by the solid stone wall above mentioned

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There are many trees on it which make it in places gloomy and there is a deep darklooking pond or small lake evidently fed by some springs as the water is clear and flows away in a fairsized stream

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The house is very large and of all periods back I should say to mediæval times for one part is of stone immensely thick with only a few windows high up and heavily barred with iron

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It looks like part of a keep and is close to an old chapel or church

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could not enter it as I had not the key of the door leading to it from the house but I have taken with my kodak views of it from various points

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The house has been added to but in a very straggling way and I can only guess at the amount of ground it covers which must be very great

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There are but few houses close at hand one being a very large house only recently added to and formed into a private lunatic asylum

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is not however visible from the grounds

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I had finished he said  I am glad that it is old and big

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I myself am of an old family and to live in a new house would kill me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A house cannot be made habitable in a day and after all how few days go to make up a century

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I rejoice also that there is a chapel of old times

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We Transylvanian nobles love not to think that our bones may lie amongst the common dead

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I seek not gaiety nor mirth not the bright voluptuousness of much sunshine and sparkling waters which please the young and gay

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am no longer young and my heart through weary years of mourning over the dead is not attuned to mirth

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Moreover the walls of my castle are broken the shadows are many and the wind breathes cold through the broken battlements and casements

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I love the shade and the shadow and would be alone with my thoughts when I may

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Somehow his words and his look did not seem to accord or else it was that his cast of face made his smile look malignant and saturnine

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Presently with an excuse he left me asking me to put all my papers together

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was some little time away and I began to look at some of the books around me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One was an atlas which I found opened naturally at England as if that map had been much used

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: On looking at it I found in certain places little rings marked and on examining these I noticed that one was near London on the east side manifestly where his new estate was situated the other two were Exeter and Whitby on the Yorkshire coast

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was the better part of an hour when the Count returned

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Aha he said still at your books

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Good

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But you must not work always

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Come I am informed that your supper is ready

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He took my arm and we went into the next room where I found an excellent supper ready on the table

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Count again excused himself as he had dined out on his being away from home

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But he sat as on the previous night and chatted whilst I ate

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: After supper I smoked as on the last evening and the Count stayed with me chatting and asking questions on every conceivable subject hour after hour

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I felt that it was getting very late indeed but I did not say anything for I felt under obligation to meet my hosts wishes in every way

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was not sleepy as the long sleep yesterday had fortified me but I could not help experiencing that chill which comes over one at the coming of the dawn which is like in its way the turn of the tide

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They say that people who are near death die generally at the change to the dawn or at the turn of the tide any one who has when tired and tied as it were to his post experienced this change in the atmosphere can well believe it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All at once we heard the crow of a cock coming up with preternatural shrillness through the clear morning air Count Dracula jumping to his feet said  Why there is the morning again

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: How remiss I am to let you stay up so long

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You must make your conversation regarding my dear new country of England less interesting so that I may not forget how time flies by us and with a courtly bow he quickly left me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I went into my own room and drew the curtains but there was little to notice my window opened into the courtyard all I could see was the warm grey of quickening sky

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: So I pulled the curtains again and have written of this day

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 8 May

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I began to fear as I wrote in this book that I was getting too diffuse but now I am glad that I went into detail from the first for there is something so strange about this place and all in it that I cannot but feel uneasy

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I wish I were safe out of it or that I had never come

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It may be that this strange nightexistence is telling on me but would that that were all

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If there were any one to talk to I could bear it but there is no one

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have only the Count to speak with and heI fear I am myself the only living soul within the place

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Let me be prosaic so far as facts can be it will help me to bear up and imagination must not run riot with me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If it does I am lost

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Let me say at once how I standor seem to

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I only slept a few hours when I went to bed and feeling that I could not sleep any more got up

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had hung my shaving glass by the window and was just beginning to shave

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Suddenly I felt a hand on my shoulder and heard the Counts voice saying to me Goodmorning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I started for it amazed me that I had not seen him since the reflection of the glass covered the whole room behind me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In starting I had cut myself slightly but did not notice it at the moment

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Having answered the Counts salutation I turned to the glass again to see how I had been mistaken

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This time there could be no error for the man was close to me and I could see him over my shoulder

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But there was no reflection of him in the mirror

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The whole room behind me was displayed but there was no sign of a man in it except myself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This was startling and coming on the top of so many strange things was beginning to increase that vague feeling of uneasiness which I always have when the Count is near but at the instant I saw that the cut had bled a little and the blood was trickling over my chin

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I laid down the razor turning as I did so half round to look for some sticking plaster

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When the Count saw my face his eyes blazed with a sort of demoniac fury and he suddenly made a grab at my throat

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I drew away and his hand touched the string of beads which held the crucifix

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It made an instant change in him for the fury passed so quickly that I could hardly believe that it was ever there

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Take care he said take care how you cut yourself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is more dangerous than you think in this country

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then seizing the shaving glass he went on And this is the wretched thing that has done the mischief

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is a foul bauble of mans vanity

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Away with it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: and opening the heavy window with one wrench of his terrible hand he flung out the glass which was shattered into a thousand pieces on the stones of the courtyard far

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I went into the diningroom breakfast was prepared but I could not find the Count anywhere

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: So I breakfasted alone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is strange that as yet I have not seen the Count eat or drink

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He must be a very peculiar man

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: After breakfast I did a little exploring in the castle

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I went out on the stairs and found a room looking towards the South

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The view was magnificent and from where I stood there was every opportunity of seeing it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The castle is on the very edge of a terrible precipice

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A stone falling from the window would fall a thousand feet without touching anything

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As far as the eye can reach is a sea of green tree tops with occasionally a deep rift where there is a chasm

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here and there are silver threads where the rivers wind in deep gorges through the forests

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But I am not in heart to describe beauty for when I had seen the view I explored further doors doors doors everywhere and all locked and bolted

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In no place save from the windows in the castle walls is there an available exit

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The castle is a veritable prison and I am a prisoner

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: CHAPTER III  JONATHAN HARKERS JOURNAL continued    When I found that I was a prisoner a sort of wild feeling came over me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I rushed up and down the stairs trying every door and peering out of every window I could find but after a little the conviction of my helplessness overpowered all other feelings

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I look back after a few hours I think I must have been mad for the time for I behaved much as a rat does in a trap

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When however the conviction had come to me that I was helpless I sat down quietlyas quietly as I have ever done anything in my lifeand began to think over what was best to be done

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am thinking still and as yet have come to no definite conclusion

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Of one thing only am I certain that it is no use making my ideas known to the Count

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He knows well that I am imprisoned and as he has done it himself and has doubtless his own motives for it he would only deceive me if I trusted him fully with the facts

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: So far as I can see my only plan will be to keep my knowledge and my fears to myself and my eyes open

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am I know either being deceived like a baby by my own fears or else I am in desperate straits and if the latter be so I need and shall need all my brains to get through

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had hardly come to this conclusion when I heard the great door below shut and knew that the Count had returned

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He did not come at once into the library so I went cautiously to my own room and found him making the bed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This was odd but only confirmed what I had all along thoughtthat there were no servants in the house

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When later I saw him through the chink of the hinges of the door laying the table in the diningroom I was assured of it for if he does himself all these menial offices surely it is proof that there is no one else to do them
