author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I determined not to return tonight to the gloomhaunted rooms but to sleep here where of old ladies had sat and sung and lived sweet lives whilst their gentle breasts were sad for their menfolk away in the midst of remorseless wars

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I drew a great couch out of its place near the corner so that as I lay I could look at the lovely view to east and south and unthinking of and uncaring for the dust composed myself for sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I suppose I must have fallen asleep I hope so but I fear for all that followed was startlingly realso real that now sitting here in the broad full sunlight of the morning I cannot in the least believe that it was all sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was not alone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The room was the same unchanged in any way since I came into it I could see along the floor in the brilliant moonlight my own footsteps marked where I had disturbed the long accumulation of dust

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In the moonlight opposite me were three young women ladies by their dress and manner

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I thought at the time that I must be dreaming when I saw them for though the moonlight was behind them they threw no shadow on the floor

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They came close to me and looked at me for some time and then whispered together

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Two were dark and had high aquiline noses like the Count and great dark piercing eyes that seemed to be almost red when contrasted with the pale yellow moon

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The other was fair as fair as can be with great wavy masses of golden hair and eyes like pale sapphires

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I seemed somehow to know her face and to know it in connection with some dreamy fear but I could not recollect at the moment how or where

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All three had brilliant white teeth that shone like pearls against the ruby of their voluptuous lips

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was something about them that made me uneasy some longing and at the same time some deadly fear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I felt in my heart a wicked burning desire that they would kiss me with those red lips

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is not good to note this down lest some day it should meet Minas eyes and cause her pain but it is the truth

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They whispered together and then they all three laughedsuch a silvery musical laugh but as hard as though the sound never could have come through the softness of human lips

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was like the intolerable tingling sweetness of waterglasses when played on by a cunning hand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The fair girl shook her head coquettishly and the other two urged her on

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One said  Go on

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You are first and we shall follow yours is the right to begin

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The other added  He is young and strong there are kisses for us all

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I lay quiet looking out under my eyelashes in an agony of delightful anticipation

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The fair girl advanced and bent over me till I could feel the movement of her breath upon me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Sweet it was in one sense honeysweet and sent the same tingling through the nerves as her voice but with a bitter underlying the sweet a bitter offensiveness as one smells in blood

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was afraid to raise my eyelids but looked out and saw perfectly under the lashes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The girl went on her knees and bent over me simply gloating

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was a deliberate voluptuousness which was both thrilling and repulsive and as she arched her neck she actually licked her lips like an animal till I could see in the moonlight the moisture shining on the scarlet lips and on the red tongue as it lapped the white sharp teeth

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lower and lower went her head as the lips went below the range of my mouth and chin and seemed about to fasten on my throat

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then she paused and I could hear the churning sound of her tongue as it licked her teeth and lips and could feel the hot breath on my neck

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then the skin of my throat began to tingle as ones flesh does when the hand that is to tickle it approaches nearernearer

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could feel the soft shivering touch of the lips on the supersensitive skin of my throat and the hard dents of two sharp teeth just touching and pausing there

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I closed my eyes in a languorous ecstasy and waitedwaited with beating heart

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But at that instant another sensation swept through me as quick as lightning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was conscious of the presence of the Count and of his being as if lapped in a storm of fury

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As my eyes opened involuntarily I saw his strong hand grasp the slender neck of the fair woman and with giants power draw it back the blue eyes transformed with fury the white teeth champing with rage and the fair cheeks blazing red with passion

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But the Count

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Never did I imagine such wrath and fury even to the demons of the pit

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His eyes were positively blazing

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The red light in them was lurid as if the flames of hellfire blazed behind them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His face was deathly pale and the lines of it were hard like drawn wires the thick eyebrows that met over the nose now seemed like a heaving bar of whitehot metal

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With a fierce sweep of his arm he hurled the woman from him and then motioned to the others as though he were beating them back it was the same imperious gesture that I had seen used to the wolves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In a voice which though low and almost in a whisper seemed to cut through the air and then ring round the room he said  How dare you touch him any of you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: How dare you cast eyes on him when I had forbidden it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Back I tell you all

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This man belongs to me Beware how you meddle with him or youll have to deal with me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The fair girl with a laugh of ribald coquetry turned to answer him  You yourself neve

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Shakespeare

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: er loved you never love

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: On this the other women joined and such a mirthless hard soulless laughter rang through the room that it almost made me faint to hear it seemed like the pleasure of fiends

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then the Count turned after looking at my face attentively and said in a soft whisper  Yes I too can love you yourselves can tell it from the past

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Is it not so

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Well now I promise you that when I am done with him you shall kiss him at your will

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Now go go

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must awaken him for there is work to be done

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Are we to have nothing tonight said one of them with a low laugh as she pointed to the bag which he had thrown upon the floor and which moved as though there were some living thing within it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For answer he nodded his head

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One of the women jumped forward and opened it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If my ears did not deceive me there was a gasp and a low wail as of a halfsmothered child

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The women closed round whilst I was aghast with horror but as I looked they disappeared and with them the dreadful bag

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was no door near them and they could not have passed me without my noticing

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They simply seemed to fade into the rays of the moonlight and pass out through the window for I could see outside the dim shadowy forms for a moment before they entirely faded away

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then the horror overcame me and I sank down unconscious

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: CHAPTER IV  JONATHAN HARKERS JOURNAL continued    I awoke in my own bed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If it be that I had not dreamt the Count must have carried me here

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I tried to satisfy myself on the subject but could not arrive at any unquestionable result

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: To be sure there were certain small evidences such as that my clothes were folded and laid by in a manner which was not my habit

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My watch was still unwound and I am rigorously accustomed to wind it the last thing before going to bed and many such details

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But these things are no proof for they may have been evidences that my mind was not as usual and from some cause or another I had certainly been much upset

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must watch for proof

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Of one thing I am glad if it was that the Count carried me here and undressed me he must have been hurried in his task for my pockets are intact

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am sure this diary would have been a mystery to him which he would not have brooked

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He would have taken or destroyed it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As I look round this room although it has been to me so full of fear it is now a sort of sanctuary for nothing can be more dreadful than those awful women who werewho  are waiting to suck my blood

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 18 May

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have been down to look at that room again in daylight for I  must  know the truth

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I got to the doorway at the top of the stairs I found it closed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It had been so forcibly driven against the jamb that part of the woodwork was splintered

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could see that the bolt of the lock had not been shot but the door is fastened from the inside

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I fear it was no dream and must act on this surmise

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 19 May

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am surely in the toils

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Last night the Count asked me in the suavest tones to write three letters one saying that my work here was nearly done and that I should start for home within a few days another that I was starting on the next morning from the time of the letter and the third that I had left the castle and arrived at Bistritz

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I would fain have rebelled but felt that in the present state of things it would be madness to quarrel openly with the Count whilst I am so absolutely in his power and to refuse would be to excite his suspicion and to arouse his anger

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He knows that I know too much and that I must not live lest I be dangerous to him my only chance is to prolong my opportunities

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Something may occur which will give me a chance to escape

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I saw in his eyes something of that gathering wrath which was manifest when he hurled that fair woman from him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He explained to me that posts were few and uncertain and that my writing now would ensure ease of mind to my friends and he assured me with so much impressiveness that he would countermand the later letters which would be held over at Bistritz until due time in case chance would admit of my prolonging my stay that to oppose him would have been to create new suspicion

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I therefore pretended to fall in with his views and asked him what dates I should put on the letters

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He calculated a minute and then said  The first should be June 12 the second June 19 and the third June 29

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I know now the span of my life

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: God help me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 28 May

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There is a chance of escape or at any rate of being able to send word home

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A band of Szgany have come to the castle and are encamped in the courtyard

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: These Szgany are gipsies I have notes of them in my book

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They are peculiar to this part of the world though allied to the ordinary gipsies all the world over

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There are thousands of them in Hungary and Transylvania who are almost outside all law

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They attach themselves as a rule to some great noble or  boyar  and call themselves by his name

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They are fearless and without religion save superstition and they talk only their own varieties of the Romany tongue

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I shall write some letters home and shall try to get them to have them posted

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have already spoken them through my window to begin acquaintanceship

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They took their hats off and made obeisance and many signs which however I could not understand any more than I could their spoken language                                       I have written the letters

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Minas is in shorthand and I simply ask Mr Hawkins to communicate with her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: To her I have explained my situation but without the horrors which I may only surmise

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It would shock and frighten her to death were I to expose my heart to her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Should the letters not carry then the Count shall not yet know my secret or the extent of my knowledge                                       I have given the letters I threw them through the bars of my window with a gold piece and made what signs I could to have them posted

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The man who took them pressed them to his heart and bowed and then put them in his cap

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could do no more

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I stole back to the study and began to read

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As the Count did not come in I have written here                                       The Count has come

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He sat down beside me and said in his smoothest voice as he opened two letters  The Szgany has given me these of which though I know not whence they come I shall of course take care

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Seehe must have looked at itone is from you and to my friend Peter Hawkins the otherhere he caught sight of the strange symbols as he opened the envelope and the dark look came into his face and his eyes blazed wickedlythe other is a vile thing an outrage upon friendship and hospitality

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is not signed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Well so it cannot matter to us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And he calmly held letter and envelope in the flame of the lamp till they were consumed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he went on  The letter to Hawkinsthat I shall of course send on since it is yours

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Your letters are sacred to me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Your pardon my friend that unknowingly I did break the seal

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Will you not cover it again

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He held out the letter to me and with a courteous bow handed me a clean envelope

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could only redirect it and hand it to him in silence

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When he went out of the room I could hear the key turn softly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A minute later I went over and tried it and the door was locked

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When an hour or two after the Count came quietly into the room his coming awakened me for I had gone to sleep on the sofa

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was very courteous and very cheery in his manner and seeing that I had been sleeping he said  So my friend you are tired

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Get to bed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There is the surest rest

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I may not have the pleasure to talk tonight since there are many labours to me but you will sleep I pray

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I passed to my room and went to bed and strange to say slept without dreaming

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Despair has its own calms

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 31 May

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This morning when I woke I thought I would provide myself with some paper and envelopes from my bag and keep them in my pocket so that I might write in case I should get an opportunity but again a surprise again a shock

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Every scrap of paper was gone and with it all my notes my memoranda relating to railways and travel my letter of credit in fact all that might be useful to me were I once outside the castle

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I sat and pondered awhile and then some thought occurred to me and I made search of my portmanteau and in the wardrobe where I had placed my clothes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The suit in which I had travelled was gone and also my overcoat and rug I could find no trace of them anywhere

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This looked like some new scheme of villainy                                        17 June

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This morning as I was sitting on the edge of my bed cudgelling my brains I heard without a cracking of whips and pounding and scraping of horses feet up the rocky path beyond the courtyard

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With joy I hurried to the window and saw drive into the yard two great leiterwagons each drawn by eight sturdy horses and at the head of each pair a Slovak with his wide hat great nailstudded belt dirty sheepskin and high boots

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They had also their long staves in hand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I ran to the door intending to descend and try and join them through the main hall as I thought that way might be opened for them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Again a shock my door was fastened on the outside

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then I ran to the window and cried to them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They looked up at me stupidly and pointed but just then the hetman of the Szgany came out and seeing them pointing to my window said something at which they laughed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Henceforth no effort of mine no piteous cry or agonised entreaty would make them even look at me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They resolutely turned away

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The leiterwagons contained great square boxes with handles of thick rope these were evidently empty by the eas

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Shortly afterwards I heard the cracking of their whips die away in the distance

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 24 June before morning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Last night the Count left me early and locked himself into his own room

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As soon as I dared I ran up the winding stair and looked out of the window which opened south

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I thought I would watch for the Count for there is something going on

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Szgany are quartered somewhere in the castle and are doing work of some kind

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I know it for now and then I hear a faraway muffled sound as of mattock and spade and whatever it is it must be the end of some ruthless villainy

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had been at the window somewhat less than half an hour when I saw something coming out of the Counts window

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I drew back and watched carefully and saw the whole man emerge

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was a new shock to me to find that he had on the suit of clothes which I had worn whilst travelling here and slung over his shoulder the terrible bag which I had seen the women take away

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There could be no doubt as to his quest and in my garb too

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This then is his new scheme of evil that he will allow others to see me as they think so that he may both leave evidence that I have been seen in the towns or villages posting my own letters and that any wickedness which he may do shall by the local people be attributed to me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It makes me rage to think that this can go on and whilst I am shut up here a veritable prisoner but without that protection of the law which is even a criminals right and consolation

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I thought I would watch for the Counts return and for a long time sat doggedly at the window

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then I began to notice that there were some quaint little specks floating in the rays of the moonlight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They were like the tiniest grains of dust and they whirled round and gathered in clusters in a nebulous sort of way

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I watched them with a sense of soothing and a sort of calm stole over me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I leaned back in the embrasure in a more comfortable position so that I could enjoy more fully the aërial gambolling

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Something made me start up a low piteous howling of dogs somewhere far below in the valley which was hidden from my sight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Louder it seemed to ring in my ears and the floating motes of dust to take new shapes to the sound as they danced in the moonlight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I felt myself struggling to awake to some call of my instincts nay my very soul was struggling and my halfremembered sensibilities were striving to answer the call

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was becoming hypnotised

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Quicker and quicker danced the dust the moonbeams seemed to quiver as they went by me into the mass of gloom beyond

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: More and more they gathered till they seemed to take dim phantom shapes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And then I started broad awake and in full possession of my senses and ran screaming from the place

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The phantom shapes which were becoming gradually materialised from the moonbeams were those of the three ghostly women to whom I was doomed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I fled and felt somewhat safer in my own room where there was no moonlight and where the lamp was burning brightly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When a couple of hours had passed I heard something stirring in the Counts room something like a sharp wail quickly suppressed and then there was silence deep awful silence which chilled me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With a beating heart I tried the door but I was locked in my prison and could do nothing

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I sat down and simply cried

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As I sat I heard a sound in the courtyard withoutthe agonised cry of a woman

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I rushed to the window and throwing it up peered out between the bars

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There indeed was a woman with dishevelled hair holding her hands over her heart as one distressed with running

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She was leaning against a corner of the gateway

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When she saw my face at the window she threw herself forward and shouted in a voice laden with menace  Monster give me my child

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She threw herself on her knees and raising up her hands cried the same words in tones which wrung my heart

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then she tore her hair and beat her breast and abandoned herself to all the violences of extravagant emotion

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Finally she threw herself forward and though I could not see her I could hear the beating of her naked hands against the door

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Somewhere high overhead probably on the tower I heard the voice of the Count calling in his harsh metallic whisper

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His call seemed to be answered from far and wide by the howling of wolves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Before many minutes had passed a pack of them poured like a pentup dam when liberated through the wide entrance into the courtyard

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was no cry from the woman and the howling of the wolves was but short

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Before long they streamed away singly licking their lips

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could not pity her for I knew now what had become of her child and she was better dead

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: What shall I do

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: what can I do

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: How can I escape from this dreadful thing of night and gloom and fear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 25 June morning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My dearest Lucy  Forgive my long delay in writing but I have been simply overwhelmed with work

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The life of an assistant schoolmistress is sometimes trying

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am longing to be with you and by the sea where we can talk together freely and build our castles in the air

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have been working very hard lately because I want to keep up with Jonathans studies and I have been practising shorthand very assiduously

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When we are married I shall be able to be useful to Jonathan and if I can stenograph well enough I can take down what he wants to say in this way and write it out for him on the typewriter at which also I am practising very hard

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He and I sometimes write letters in shorthand and he is keeping a stenographic journal of his travels abroad

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I am with you I shall keep a diary in the same way

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula
words: I shall try to do what I see lady journalists do interviewing and writing descriptions and trying to remember conversations

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Besides I have nothing to tell you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There is really nothing to interest you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Town is very pleasant just now and we go a good deal to picturegalleries and for walks and rides in the park

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As to the tall curlyhaired man I suppose it was the one who was with me at the last Pop

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some one has evidently been telling tales

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: That was Mr Holmwood

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He often comes to see us and he and mamma get on very well together they have so many things to talk about in common

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We met some time ago a man that would just  do for you  if you were not already engaged to Jonathan

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He is an excellent  parti  being handsome well off and of good birth

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He is a doctor and really clever

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Just fancy

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He is only nineandtwenty and he has an immense lunatic asylum all under his own care

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mr Holmwood introduced him to me and he called here to see us and often comes now

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I think he is one of the most resolute men I ever saw and yet the most calm

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He seems absolutely imperturbable

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I can fancy what a wonderful power he must have over his patients

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He has a curious habit of looking one straight in the face as if trying to read ones thoughts

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He tries this on very much with me but I flatter myself he has got a tough nut to crack

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I know that from my glass

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Do you ever try to read your own face

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I do  and I can tell you it is not a bad study and gives you more trouble than you can well fancy if you have never tried it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He says that I afford him a curious psychological study and I humbly think I do

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I do not as you know take sufficient interest in dress to be able to describe the new fashions

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Dress is a bore

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: That is slang again but never mind Arthur says that every day

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There it is all out

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mina we have told all our secrets to each other since we were  children  we have slept together and eaten together and laughed and cried together and now though I have spoken I would like to speak more

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Oh Mina couldnt you guess

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I love him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am blushing as I write for although I  think  he loves me he has not told me so in words

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But oh Mina I love him I love him I love him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There that does me good

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I wish I were with you dear sitting by the fire undressing as we used to sit and I would try to tell you what I feel

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I do not know how I am writing this even to you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am afraid to stop or I should tear up the letter and I dont want to stop for I  do  so want to tell you all

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Let me hear from you  at once  and tell me all that you think about it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mina I must stop

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Goodnight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Bless me in your prayers and Mina pray for my happiness

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My dear it never rains but it pours

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: How true the old proverbs are

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here am I who shall be twenty in September and yet I never had a proposal till today not a real proposal and today I have had three

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Just fancy

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: THREE proposals in one day

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Isnt it awful

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Oh Mina I am so happy that I dont know what to do with myself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And three proposals

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But for goodness sake dont tell any of the girls or they would be getting all sorts of extravagant ideas and imagining themselves injured and slighted if in their very first day at home they did not get six at least

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some girls are so vain

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You and I Mina dear who are engaged and are going to settle down soon soberly into old married women can despise vanity

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Well I must tell you about the three but you must keep it a secret dear from  every one  except of course Jonathan

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You will tell him because I would if I were in your place certainly tell Arthur

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A woman ought to tell her husband everythingdont you think so dearand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must be fair

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Men like women certainly their wives to be quite as fair as they are and women I am afraid are not always quite as fair as they should be

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Well my dear number One came just before lunch

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I told you of him Dr John Seward the lunaticasylum man with the strong jaw and the good forehead

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was very cool outwardly but was nervous all the same

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He had evidently been schooling himself as to all sorts of little things and remembered them but he almost managed to sit down on his silk hat which men dont generally do when they are cool and then when he wanted to appear at ease he kept playing with a lancet in a way that made me nearly scream

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He spoke to me Mina very straightforwardly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He told me how dear I was to him though he had known me so little and what his life would be with me to help and cheer him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was going to tell me how unhappy he would be if I did not care for him but when he saw me cry he said that he was a brute and would not add to my present trouble

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he broke off and asked if I could love him in time and when I shook my head his hands trembled and then with some hesitation he asked me if I cared already for any one else

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He put it very nicely saying that he did not want to wring my confidence from me but only to know because if a womans heart was free a man might have hope

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And then Mina I felt a sort of duty to tell him that there was some one

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must tell you beforehand that Mr Morris doesnt always speak slangthat is to say he never does so to strangers or before them for he is really well educated and has exquisite mannersbut he found out that it amused me to hear him talk American slang and whenever I was present and there was no one to be shocked he said such funny things

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am afraid my dear he has to invent it all for it fits exactly into whatever else he has to say

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But this is a way slang has

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Well Mr Morris sat down beside me and looked as happy and jolly as he could but I could see all the same that he was very nervous

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He took my hand in his and said ever so sweetly  Miss Lucy I know I aint good enough to regulate the fixins of your little shoes but I guess if you wait till you find a man that is you will go join them seven young women with the lamps when you quit

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Wont you just hitch up alongside of me and let us go down the long road together driving in double harness  Well he did look so goodhumoured and so jolly that it didnt seem half so hard to refuse him as it did poor Dr Seward so I said as lightly as I could that I did not know anything of hitching and that I wasnt broken to harness at all yet

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he said that he had spoken in a light manner and he hoped that if he had made a mistake in doing so on so grave so momentous an occasion for him I would forgive him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He really did look serious when he was saying it and I couldnt help feeling a bit serious tooI know Mina you will think me a horrid flirtthough I couldnt help feeling a sort of exultation that he was number two in one day

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And then my dear before I could say a word he began pouring out a perfect torrent of lovemaking laying his very heart and soul at my feet

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He looked so earnest over it that I shall never again think that a man must be playful always and never earnest because he is merry at times

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I suppose he saw something in my face which checked him for he suddenly stopped and said with a sort of manly fervour that I could have loved him for if I had been free  Lucy you are an honesthearted girl I know

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I should not be here speaking to you as I am now if I did not believe you clean grit right through to the very depths of your soul

words: CHAPTER VI  MINA MURRAYS JOURNAL    24 July

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Whitby

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy met me at the station looking sweeter and lovelier than ever and we drove up to the house at the Crescent in which they have rooms

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This is a lovely place

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The little river the Esk runs through a deep valley which broadens out as it comes near the harbour

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A great viaduct runs across with high piers through which the view seems somehow further away than it really is

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The valley is beautifully green and it is so steep that when you are on the high land on either side you look right across it unless you are near enough to see down

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The houses of the old townthe side away from usare all redroofed and seem piled up one over the other anyhow like the pictures we see of Nuremberg

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Right over the town is the ruin of Whitby Abbey which was sacked by the Danes and which is the scene of part of Marmion where the girl was built up in the wall

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is a most noble ruin of immense size and full of beautiful and romantic bits there is a legend that a white lady is seen in one of the windows

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Between it and the town there is another church the parish one round which is a big graveyard all full of tombstones

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This is to my mind the nicest spot in Whitby for it lies right over the town and has a full view of the harbour and all up the bay to where the headland called Kettleness stretches out into the sea

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It descends so steeply over the harbour that part of the bank has fallen away and some of the graves have been destroyed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In one place part of the stonework of the graves stretches out over the sandy pathway far below

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There are walks with seats beside them through the churchyard and people go and sit there all day long looking at the beautiful view and enjoying the breeze

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I shall come and sit here very often myself and work

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Indeed I am writing now with my book on my knee and listening to the talk of three old men who are sitting beside me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They seem to do nothing all day but sit up here and talk

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The harbour lies below me with on the far side one long granite wall stretching out into the sea with a curve outwards at the end of it in the middle of which is a lighthouse

title: Dracula
words: Had I even the secret of one such minddid I hold the key to the fancy of even one lunaticI might advance my own branch of science to a pitch compared with which BurdonSandersons physiology or Ferriers brainknowledge would be as nothing

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula
words: How well the man reasoned lunatics always do within their own scope

title: Dracula
words: I wonder at how many lives he values a man or if at only one

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: How many of us begin a new record with each day of our lives

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: To me it seems only yesterday that my whole life ended with my new hope and that truly I began a new record

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: So it will be until the Great Recorder sums me up and closes my ledger account with a balance to profit or loss

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 26 July

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am anxious and it soothes me to express myself here it is like whispering to ones self and listening at the same time

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And there is also something about the shorthand symbols that makes it different from writing

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am unhappy about Lucy and about Jonathan

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had not heard from Jonathan for some time and was very concerned but yesterday dear Mr Hawkins who is always so kind sent me a letter from him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had written asking him if he had heard and he said the enclosed had just been received

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is only a line dated from Castle Dracula and says that he is just starting for home

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: That is not like Jonathan I do not understand it and it makes me uneasy

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then too Lucy although she is so well has lately taken to her old habit of walking in her sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Her mother has spoken to me about it and we have decided that I am to lock the door of our room every night

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mrs Westenra has got an idea that sleepwalkers always go out on roofs of houses and along the edges of cliffs and then get suddenly wakened and fall over with a despairing cry that echoes all over the place

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Poor dear she is naturally anxious about Lucy and she tells me that her husband Lucys father had the same habit that he would get up in the night and dress himself and go out if he were not stopped

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy is to be married in the autumn and she is already planning out her dresses and how her house is to be arranged

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I sympathise with her for I do the same only Jonathan and I will start in life in a very simple way and shall have to try to make both ends meet

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mr Holmwoodhe is the Hon

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthur Holmwood only son of Lord Godalmingis coming up here very shortlyas soon as he can leave town for his father is not very well and I think dear Lucy is counting the moments till he comes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She wants to take him up to the seat on the churchyard cliff and show him the beauty of Whitby

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I daresay it is the waiting which disturbs her she will be all right when he arrives

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 27 July

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: No news from Jonathan

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am getting quite uneasy about him though why I should I do not know but I do wish that he would write if it were only a single line

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy walks more than ever and each night I am awakened by her moving about the room

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Fortunately the weather is so hot that she cannot get cold but still the anxiety and the perpetually being wakened is beginning to tell on me and I am getting nervous and wakeful myself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Thank God Lucys health keeps up

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mr Holmwood has been suddenly called to Ring to see his father who has been taken seriously ill

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy frets at the postponement of seeing him but it does not touch her looks she is a trifle stouter and her cheeks are a lovely rosepink

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She has lost that anæmic look which she had

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I pray it will all last

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 3 August

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Another week gone and no news from Jonathan not even to Mr Hawkins from whom I have heard

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Oh I do hope he is not ill

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He surely would have written

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I look at that last letter of his but somehow it does not satisfy me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It does not read like him and yet it is his writing

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There is no mistake of that

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy has not walked much in her sleep the last week but there is an odd concentration about her which I do not understand even in her sleep she seems to be watching me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She tries the door and finding it locked goes about the room searching for the key

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 6 August

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Another three days and no news

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This suspense is getting dreadful

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If I only knew where to write to or where to go to I should feel easier but no one has heard a word of Jonathan since that last letter

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must only pray to God for patience

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy is more excitable than ever but is otherwise well

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Last night was very threatening and the fishermen say that we are in for a storm

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must try to watch it and learn the weather signs

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Today is a grey day and the sun as I write is hidden in thick clouds high over Kettleness

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Everything is greyexcept the green grass which seems like emerald amongst it grey earthy rock grey clouds tinged with the sunburst at the far edge hang over the grey sea into which the sandpoints stretch like grey fingers

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The sea is tumbling in over the shallows and the sandy flats with a roar muffled in the seamists drifting inland

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The horizon is lost in a grey mist

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All is vastness the clouds are piled up like giant rocks and there is a brool over the sea that sounds like some presage of doom

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Dark figures are on the beach here and there sometimes half shrouded in the mist and seem men like trees walking

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The fishingboats are racing for home and rise and dip in the ground swell as they sweep into the harbour bending to the scuppers

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here comes old Mr Swales

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He is making straight for me and I can see by the way he lifts his hat that he wants to talk

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have been quite touched by the change in the poor old man

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When he sat down beside me he said in a very gentle way  I want to say something to you miss

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could see he was not at ease so I took his poor old wrinkled hand in mine and asked him to speak fully so he said leaving his hand in mine  Im afraid my deary that I must have shocked you by all the wicked things Ive been sayin about the dead and such like for weeks past but I didnt mean them and I want ye to remember that when Im gone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We aud folks that be daffled and with one foot abaft the krokhooal dont altogether like to think of it and we dont want to feel scart of it an thats why Ive took to makin light of it so that Id cheer up my own heart a bit

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But Lord love ye miss I aint afraid of dyin not a bit only I dont want to die if I can help it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My time must be nigh at hand now for I be aud and a hundred years is too much for any man to expect and Im so nigh it that the Aud Man is already whettin his scythe

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Ye see I cant get out o the habit of caffin about it all at once the chafts will wag as they be used to

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some day soon the Angel of Death will sound his trumpet for me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But dont ye dooal an greet my dearyfor he saw that I was cryingif he should come this very night Id not refuse to answer his call

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For life be after all only a waitin for somethin else than what were doin and death be all that we can rightly depend on

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But Im content for its comin to me my deary and comin quick

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It may be comin while we be lookin and wonderin

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula
words: Look look he cried suddenly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Theres something in that wind and in the hoast beyont that sounds and looks and tastes and smells like death

author: Stoker, Bram

words: Its in the air I feel it comin

words: Lord make me answer cheerful when my call comes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: CHAPTER VII  CUTTING FROM THE DAILYGRAPH 8 AUGUST    Pasted in Mina Murrays Journal   From a Correspondent

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Whitby

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One of the greatest and suddenest storms on record has just been experienced here with results both strange and unique

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The weather had been somewhat sultry but not to any degree uncommon in the month of August

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Saturday evening was as fine as was ever known and the great body of holidaymakers laid out yesterday for visits to Mulgrave Woods Robin Hoods Bay Rig Mill Runswick Staithes and the various trips in the neighbourhood of Whitby

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The steamers  Emma  and  Scarborough  made trips up and down the coast and there was an unusual amount of tripping both to and from Whitby

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The day was unusually fine till the afternoon when some of the gossips who frequent the East Cliff churchyard and from that commanding eminence watch the wide sweep of sea visible to the north and east called attention to a sudden show of marestails high in the sky to the northwest

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The wind was then blowing from the southwest in the mild degree which in barometrical language is ranked No

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 2 light breeze

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The coastguard on duty at once made report and one old fisherman who for more than half a century has kept watch on weather signs from the East Cliff foretold in an emphatic manner the coming of a sudden storm

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The approach of sunset was so very beautiful so grand in its masses of splendidlycoloured clouds that there was quite an assemblage on the walk along the cliff in the old churchyard to enjoy the beauty

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Before the sun dipped below the black mass of Kettleness standing boldly athwart the western sky its downward way was marked by myriad clouds of every sunsetcolourflame purple pink green violet and all the tints of gold with here and there masses not large but of seemingly absolute blackness in all sorts of shapes as well outlined as colossal silhouettes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The experience was not lost on the painters and doubtless some of the sketches of the Prelude to the Great Storm will grace the R A and R I walls in May next

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: More than one captain made up his mind then and there that his cobble or his mule as they term the different classes of boats would remain in the harbour till the storm had passed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The wind fell away entirely during the evening and at midnight there was a dead calm a sultry heat and that prevailing intensity which on the approach of thunder affects persons of a sensitive nature

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There were but few lights in sight at sea for even the coasting steamers which usually hug the shore so closely kept well to seaward and but few fishingboats were in sight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The only sail noticeable was a foreign schooner with all sails set which was seemingly going westwards

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The foolhardiness or ignorance of her officers was a prolific theme for comment whilst she remained in sight and efforts were made to signal her to reduce sail in face of her danger

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Before the night shut down she was seen with sails idly flapping as she gently rolled on the undulating swell of the sea      As idle as a painted ship upon a painted ocean

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Shortly before ten oclock the stillness of the air grew quite oppressive and the silence was so marked that the bleating of a sheep inland or the barking of a dog in the town was distinctly heard and the band on the pier with its lively French air was like a discord in the great harmony of natures silence

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A little after midnight came a strange sound from over the sea and high overhead the air began to carry a strange faint hollow booming

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then without warning the tempest broke

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With a rapidity which at the time seemed incredible and even afterwards is impossible to realize the whole aspect of nature at once became convulsed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The waves rose in growing fury each overtopping its fellow till in a very few minutes the lately glassy sea was like a roaring and devouring monster

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Whitecrested waves beat madly on the level sands and rushed up the shelving cliffs others broke over the piers and with their spume swept the lanthorns of the lighthouses which rise from the end of either pier of Whitby Harbour

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The wind roared like thunder and blew with such force that it was with difficulty that even strong men kept their feet or clung with grim clasp to the iron stanchions

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was found necessary to clear the entire piers from the mass of onlookers or else the fatalities of the night would have been increased manifold

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: To add to the difficulties and dangers of the time masses of seafog came drifting inlandwhite wet clouds which swept by in ghostly fashion so dank and damp and cold that it needed but little effort of imagination to think that the spirits of those lost at sea were touching their living brethren with the clammy hands of death and many a one shuddered as the wreaths of seamist swept by

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At times the mist cleared and the sea for some distance could be seen in the glare of the lightning which now came thick and fast followed by such sudden peals of thunder that the whole sky overhead seemed trembling under the shock of the footsteps of the storm

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some of the scenes thus revealed were of immeasurable grandeur and of absorbing interestthe sea running mountains high threw skywards with each wave mighty masses of white foam which the tempest seemed to snatch at and whirl away into space here and there a fishingboat with a rag of sail running madly for shelter before the blast now and again the white wings of a stormtossed seabird

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: On the summit of the East Cliff the new searchlight was ready for experiment but had not yet been tried

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The officers in charge of it got it into working order and in the pauses of the inrushing mist swept with it the surface of the sea

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Once or twice its service was most effective as when a fishingboat with gunwale under water rushed into the harbour able by the guidance of the sheltering light to avoid the danger of dashing against the piers

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As each boat achieved the safety of the port there was a shout of joy from the mass of people on shore a shout which for a moment seemed to cleave the gale and was then swept away in its rush

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Before long the searchlight discovered some distance away a schooner with all sails set apparently the same vessel which had been noticed earlier in the evening

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The wind had by this time backed to the east and there was a shudder amongst the watchers on the cliff as they realized the terrible danger in which she now was

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Between her and the port lay the great flat reef on which so many good ships have from time to time suffered and with the wind blowing from its present quarter it would be quite impossible that she should fetch the entrance of the harbour

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was now nearly the hour of high tide but the waves were so great that in their troughs the shallows of the shore were almost visible and the schooner with all sails set was rushing with such speed that in the words of one old salt she must fetch up somewhere if it was only in hell

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then came another rush of seafog greater than any hithertoa mass of dank mist which seemed to close on all things like a grey pall and left available to men only the organ of hearing for the roar of the tempest and the crash of the thunder and the booming of the mighty billows came through the damp oblivion even louder than before

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The rays of the searchlight were kept fixed on the harbour mouth across the East Pier where the shock was expected and men waited breathless

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The wind suddenly shifted to the northeast and the remnant of the seafog melted in the blast and then  mirabile dictu  between the piers leaping from wave to wave as it rushed at headlong speed swept the strange schooner before the blast with all sail set and gained the safety of the harbour

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The searchlight followed her and a shudder ran through all who saw her for lashed to the helm was a corpse with drooping head which swung horribly to and fro at each motion of the ship

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: No other form could be seen on deck at all

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A great awe came on all as they realised that the ship as if by a miracle had found the harbour unsteered save by the hand of a dead man

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: However all took place more quickly than it takes to write these words

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The schooner paused not but rushing across the harbour pitched herself on that accumulation of sand and gravel washed by many tides and many storms into the southeast corner of the pier jutting under the East Cliff known locally as Tate Hill Pier

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was of course a considerable concussion as the vessel drove up on the sand heap

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Every spar rope and stay was strained and some of the tophammer came crashing down

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But strangest of all the very instant the shore was touched an immense dog sprang up on deck from below as if shot up by the concussion and running forward jumped from the bow on the sand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Making straight for the steep cliff where the churchyard hangs over the laneway to the East Pier so steeply that some of the flat tombstonesthruffsteans or throughstones as they call them in the Whitby vernacularactually project over where the sustaining cliff has fallen away it disappeared in the darkness which seemed intensified just beyond the focus of the searchlight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It so happened that there was no one at the moment on Tate Hill Pier as all those whose houses are in close proximity were either in bed or were out on the heights above

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Thus the coastguard on duty on the eastern side of the harbour who at once ran down to the little pier was the first to climb on board

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The men working the searchlight after scouring the entrance of the harbour without seeing anything then turned the light on the derelict and kept it there

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The coastguard ran aft and when he came beside the wheel bent over

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Robin Hood

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Tate Hill Pier

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: to examine it and recoiled at once as though under some sudden emotion

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This seemed to pique general curiosity and quite a number of people began to run

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is a good way round from the West Cliff by the Drawbridge to Tate Hill Pier but your correspondent is a fairly good runner and came well ahead of the crowd

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I arrived however I found already assembled on the pier a crowd whom the coastguard and police refused to allow to come on board

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: By the courtesy of the chief boatman I was as your correspondent permitted to climb on deck and was one of a small group who saw the dead seaman whilst actually lashed to the wheel

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was no wonder that the coastguard was surprised or even awed for not often can such a sight have been seen

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The man was simply fastened by his hands tied one over the other to a spoke of the wheel

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Between the inner hand and the wood was a crucifix the set of beads on which it was fastened being around both wrists and wheel and all kept fast by the binding cords

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The poor fellow may have been seated at one time but the flapping and buffeting of the sails had worked through the rudder of the wheel and dragged him to and fro so that the cords with which he was tied had cut the flesh to the bone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Accurate note was made of the state of things and a doctorSurgeon J M Caffyn of 33 East Elliot Placewho came immediately after me declared after making examination that the man must have been dead for quite two days

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In his pocket was a bottle carefully corked empty save for a little roll of paper which proved to be the addendum to the log

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The coastguard said the man must have tied up his own hands fastening the knots with his teeth

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The fact that a coastguard was the first on board may save some complications later on in the Admiralty Court for coastguards cannot claim the salvage which is the right of the first civilian entering on a derelict

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Already however the legal tongues are wagging and one young law student is loudly asserting that the rights of the owner are already completely sacrificed his property being held in contravention of the statutes of mortmain since the tiller as emblemship if not proof of delegated possession is held in a  dead hand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is needless to say that the dead steersman has been reverently removed from the place where he held his honourable watch and ward till deatha steadfastness as noble as that of the young Casabiancaand placed in the mortuary to await inquest

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Already the sudden storm is passing and its fierceness is abating crowds are scattering homeward and the sky is beginning to redden over the Yorkshire wolds

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I shall send in time for your next issue further details of the derelict ship which found her way so miraculously into harbour in the storm

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Whitby    9 August

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The sequel to the strange arrival of the derelict in the storm last night is almost more startling than the thing itself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It turns out that the schooner is a Russian from Varna and is called the  Demeter

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She is almost entirely in ballast of silver sand with only a small amount of cargoa number of great wooden boxes filled with mould

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This cargo was consigned to a Whitby solicitor Mr S F Billington of 7 The Crescent who this morning went aboard and formally took possession of the goods consigned to him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Russian consul too acting for the charterparty took formal possession of the ship and paid all harbour dues etc Nothing is talked about here today except the strange coincidence the officials of the Board of Trade have been most exacting in seeing that every compliance has been made with existing regulations

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As the matter is to be a nine days wonder they are evidently determined that there shall be no cause of after complaint

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A good deal of interest was abroad concerning the dog which landed when the ship struck and more than a few of the members of the S P C A which is very strong in Whitby have tried to befriend the animal

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: To the general disappointment however it was not to be found it seems to have disappeared entirely from the town

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It may be that it was frightened and made its way on to the moors where it is still hiding in terror

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There are some who look with dread on such a possibility lest later on it should in itself become a danger for it is evidently a fierce brute

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Early this morning a large dog a halfbred mastiff belonging to a coal merchant close to Tate Hill Pier was found dead in the roadway opposite to its masters yard

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It had been fighting and manifestly had had a savage opponent for its throat was torn away and its belly was slit open as if with a savage claw

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Later

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: By the kindness of the Board of Trade inspector I have been permitted to look over the logbook of the  Demeter  which was in order up to within three days but contained nothing of special interest except as to facts of missing men

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The greatest interest however is with regard to the paper found in the bottle which was today produced at the inquest and a more strange narrative than the two between them unfold it has not been my lot to come across

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As there is no motive for concealment I am permitted to use them and accordingly send you a rescript simply omitting technical details of seamanship and supercargo

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It almost seems as though the captain had been seized with some kind of mania before he had got well into blue water and that this had developed persistently throughout the voyage

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
