words: She ought not to have much inclination for sleepwalking then

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: CHAPTER VIII  MINA MURRAYS JOURNAL    Same day 11 oclock p m Oh but I am tired

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If it were not that I had made my diary a duty I should not open it tonight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We had a lovely walk

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy after a while was in gay spirits owing I think to some dear cows who came nosing towards us in a field close to the lighthouse and frightened the wits out of us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I believe we forgot everything except of course personal fear and it seemed to wipe the slate clean and give us a fresh start

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We had a capital severe tea at Robin Hoods Bay in a sweet little oldfashioned inn with a bowwindow right over the seaweedcovered rocks of the strand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I believe we should have shocked the New Woman with our appetites

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Men are more tolerant bless them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then we walked home with some or rather many stoppages to rest and with our hearts full of a constant dread of wild bulls

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy was really tired and we intended to creep off to bed as soon as we could

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The young curate came in however and Mrs Westenra asked him to stay for supper

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy and I had both a fight for it with the dusty miller I know it was a hard fight on my part and I am quite heroic

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I think that some day the bishops must get together and see about breeding up a new class of curates who dont take supper no matter how they may be pressed to and who will know when girls are tired

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy is asleep and breathing softly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She has more colour in her cheeks than usual and looks oh so sweet

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If Mr Holmwood fell in love with her seeing her only in the drawingroom I wonder what he would say if he saw her now

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some of the New Women writers will some day start an idea that men and women should be allowed to see each other asleep before proposing or accepting

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But I suppose the New Woman wont condescend in future to accept she will do the proposing herself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And a nice job she will make of it too

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Theres some consolation in that

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am so happy tonight because dear Lucy seems better

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I really believe she has turned the corner and that we are over her troubles with dreaming

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I should be quite happy if I only knew if Jonathan God bless and keep him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 11 August 3 a

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: m Diary again

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: No sleep now so I may as well write

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am too agitated to sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We have had such an adventure such an agonising experience

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I fell asleep as soon as I had closed my diary Suddenly I became broad awake and sat up with a horrible sense of fear upon me and of some feeling of emptiness around me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The room was dark so I could not see Lucys bed I stole across and felt for her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The bed was empty

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I lit a match and found that she was not in the room

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The door was shut but not locked as I had left it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I feared to wake her mother who has been more than usually ill lately so threw on some clothes and got ready to look for her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As I was leaving the room it struck me that the clothes she wore might give me some clue to her dreaming intention

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Dressinggown would mean house dress outside

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Dressinggown and dress were both in their places

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Thank God I said to myself she cannot be far as she is only in her nightdress

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I ran downstairs and looked in the sittingroom

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Not there

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then I looked in all the other open rooms of the house with an evergrowing fear chilling my heart

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Finally I came to the hall door and found it open

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was not wide open but the catch of the lock had not caught

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The people of the house are careful to lock the door every night so I feared that Lucy must have gone out as she was

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was no time to think of what might happen a vague overmastering fear obscured all details

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I took a big heavy shawl and ran out

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The clock was striking one as I was in the Crescent and there was not a soul in sight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I ran along the North Terrace but could see no sign of the white figure which I expected

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At the edge of the West Cliff above the pier I looked across the harbour to the East Cliff in the hope or fearI dont know whichof seeing Lucy in our favourite seat

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was a bright full moon with heavy black driving clouds which threw the whole scene into a fleeting diorama of light and shade as they sailed across

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For a moment or two I could see nothing as the shadow of a cloud obscured St Marys Church and all around it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then as the cloud passed I could see the ruins of the abbey coming into view and as the edge of a narrow band of light as sharp as a swordcut moved along the church and the churchyard became gradually visible

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Whatever my expectation was it was not disappointed for there on our favourite seat the silver light of the moon struck a halfreclining figure snowy white

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The coming of the cloud was too quick for me to see much for shadow shut down on light almost immediately but it seemed to me as though something dark stood behind the seat where the white figure shone and bent over it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: What it was whether man or beast I could not tell I did not wait to catch another glance but flew down the steep steps to the pier and along by the fishmarket to the bridge which was the only way to reach the East Cliff

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The town seemed as dead for not a soul did I see I rejoiced that it was so for I wanted no witness of poor Lucys condition

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The time and distance seemed endless and my knees trembled and my breath came laboured as I toiled up the endless steps to the abbey

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must have gone fast and yet it seemed to me as if my feet were weighted with lead and as though every joint in my body were rusty

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I got almost to the top I could see the seat and the white figure for I was now close enough to distinguish it even through the spells of shadow

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was undoubtedly something long and black bending over the halfreclining white figure

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I called in fright Lucy

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy and something raised a head and from where I was I could see a white face and red gleaming eyes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy did not answer and I ran on to the entrance of the churchyard

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As I entered the church was between me and the seat and for a minute or so I lost sight of her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I came in view again the cloud had passed and the moonlight struck so brilliantly that I could see Lucy half reclining with her head lying over the back of the seat

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She was quite alone and there was not a sign of any living thing about

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I bent over her I could see that she was still asleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Her lips were parted and she was breathingnot softly as usual with her but in long heavy gasps as though striving to get her lungs full at every breath

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As I came close she put up her hand in her sleep and pulled the collar of her nightdress close around her throat

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Whilst she did so there came a little shudder through her as though she felt the cold

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I flung the warm shawl over her and drew the edges tight round her neck for I dreaded lest she should get some deadly chill from the night air unclad as she was

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I feared to wake her all at once so in order to have my hands free that I might help her I fastened the shawl at her throat with a big safetypin but I must have been clumsy in my anxiety and pinched or pricked her with it for byandby when her breathing became quieter she put her hand to her throat again and moaned

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I had her carefully wrapped up I put my shoes on her feet and then began very gently to wake her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At first she did not respond but gradually she became more and more uneasy in her sleep moaning and sighing occasionally

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At last as time was passing fast and for many other reasons I wished to get her home at once I shook her more forcibly till finally she opened her eyes and awoke

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She did not seem surprised to see me as of course she did not realise all at once where she was

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy always wakes prettily and even at such a time when her body must have been chilled with cold and her mind somewhat appalled at waking unclad in a churchyard at night she did not lose her grace

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She trembled a little and clung to me when I told her to come at once with me home she rose without a word with the obedience of a child

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As we passed along the gravel hurt my feet and Lucy noticed me wince

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She stopped and wanted to insist upon my taking my shoes but I would not

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: However when we got to the pathway outside the churchyard where there was a puddle of water remaining from the storm I daubed my feet with mud using each foot in turn on the other so that as we went home no one in case we should meet any one should notice my bare feet

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Fortune favoured us and we got home without meeting a soul

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Once we saw a man who seemed not quite sober passing along a street in front of us but we hid in a door till he had disappeared up an opening such as there are here steep little closes or wynds as they call them in Scotland

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My heart beat so loud all the time that sometimes I thought I should faint

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was filled with anxiety about Lucy

title: Dracula
words: When we got in and had washed our feet and had said a prayer of thankfulness together I tucked her into bed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Before falling asleep she askedeven imploredme not to say a word to any one even her mother about her sleepwalking adventure

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I hesitated at first to promise but on thinking of the state of her mothers health and how the knowledge of such a thing would fret her and thinking too of how such a story might become distortednay infallibly wouldin case it should leak out I thought it wiser to do so

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I hope I did right

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have locked the door and the key is tied to my wrist so perhaps I shall not be again disturbed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy is sleeping soundly the reflex of the dawn is high and far over the sea                                        Same day noon

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All goes well

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy slept till I woke her and seemed not to have even changed her side

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The adventure of the night does not seem to have harmed her on the contrary it has benefited her for she looks better this morning than she has done for weeks

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was sorry to notice that my clumsiness with the safetypin hurt her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Indeed it might have been serious for the skin of her throat was pierced

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must have pinched up a piece of loose skin and have transfixed it for there are two little red points like pinpricks and on the band of her nightdress was a drop of blood

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I apologised and was concerned about it she laughed and petted me and said she did not even feel it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Fortunately it cannot leave a scar as it is so tiny

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Same day night

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We passed a happy day

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The air was clear and the sun bright and there was a cool breeze

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We took our lunch to Mulgrave Woods Mrs Westenra driving by the road and Lucy and I walking by the cliffpath and joining her at the gate

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I felt a little sad myself for I could not but feel how  absolutely  happy it would have been had Jonathan been with me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But there

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must only be patient

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In the evening we strolled in the Casino Terrace and heard some good music by Spohr and Mackenzie and went to bed early

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy seems more restful than she has been for some time and fell asleep at once

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I shall lock the door and secure the key the same as before though I do not expect any trouble tonight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 12 August

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My expectations were wrong for twice during the night I was wakened by Lucy trying to get out

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She seemed even in her sleep to be a little impatient at finding the door shut and went back to bed under a sort of protest

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I woke with the dawn and heard the birds chirping outside of the window

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy woke too and I was glad to see was even better than on the previous morning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All her old gaiety of manner seemed to have come back and she came and snuggled in beside me and told me all about Arthur

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I told her how anxious I was about Jonathan and then she tried to comfort me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Well she succeeded somewhat for though sympathy cant alter facts it can help to make them more bearable

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 13 August

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Another quiet day and to bed with the key on my wrist as before

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Again I awoke in the night and found Lucy sitting up in bed still asleep pointing to the window

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I got up quietly and pulling aside the blind looked out

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was brilliant moonlight and the soft effect of the light over the sea and skymerged together in one great silent mysterywas beautiful beyond words

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Between me and the moonlight flitted a great bat coming and going in great whirling circles

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Once or twice it came quite close but was I suppose frightened at seeing me and flitted away across the harbour towards the abbey

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I came back from the window Lucy had lain down again and was sleeping peacefully

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She did not stir again all night

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 14 August

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: On the East Cliff reading and writing all day

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy seems to have become as much in love with the spot as I am and it is hard to get her away from it when it is time to come home for lunch or tea or dinner

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This afternoon she made a funny remark

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We were coming home for dinner and had come to the top of the steps up from the West Pier and stopped to look at the view as we generally do

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The setting sun low down in the sky was just dropping behind Kettleness the red light was thrown over on the East Cliff and the old abbey and seemed to bathe everything in a beautiful rosy glow

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We were silent for a while and suddenly Lucy murmured as if to herself  His red eyes again

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They are just the same

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was such an odd expression coming  apropos  of nothing that it quite startled me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I slewed round a little so as to see Lucy well without seeming to stare at her and saw that she was in a halfdreamy state with an odd look on her face that I could not quite make out so I said nothing but followed her eyes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She appeared to be looking over at our own seat whereon was a dark figure seated alone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was a little startled myself for it seemed for an instant as if the stranger had great eyes like burning flames but a second look dispelled the illusion

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The red sunlight was shining on the windows of St Marys Church behind our seat and as the sun dipped there was just sufficient change in the refraction and reflection to make it appear as if the light moved

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I called Lucys attention to the peculiar effect and she became herself with a start but she looked sad all the same it may have been that she was thinking of that terrible night up there

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We never refer to it so I said nothing and we went home to dinner

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy had a headache and went early to bed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I saw her asleep and went out for a little stroll myself I walked along the cliffs to the westward and was full of sweet sadness for I was thinking of Jonathan

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When coming homeit was then bright moonlight so bright that though the front of our part of the Crescent was in shadow everything could be well seenI threw a glance up at our window and saw Lucys head leaning out

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I thought that perhaps she was looking out for me so I opened my handkerchief and waved it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She did not notice or make any movement whatever

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Just then the moonlight crept round an angle of the building and the light fell on the window

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There distinctly was Lucy with her head lying up against the side of the windowsill and her eyes shut

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She was fast asleep and by her seated on the windowsill was something that looked like a goodsized bird

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was afraid she might get a chill so I ran upstairs but as I came into the room she was moving back to her bed fast asleep and breathing heavily she was holding her hand to her throat as though to protect it from cold

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I did not wake her but tucked her up warmly I have taken care that the door is locked and the window securely fastened

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She looks so sweet as she sleeps but she is paler than is her wont and there is a drawn haggard look under her eyes which I do not like

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I fear she is fretting about something

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I wish I could find out what it is

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Rose later than usual

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy was languid and tired and slept on after we had been called

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We had a happy surprise at breakfast

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthurs father is better and wants the marriage to come off soon

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy is full of quiet joy and her mother is glad and sorry at once

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Later on in the day she told me the cause

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She is grieved to lose Lucy as her very own but she is rejoiced that she is soon to have some one to protect her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Poor dear sweet lady

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She confided to me that she has got her deathwarrant

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She has not told Lucy and made me promise secrecy her doctor told her that within a few months at most she must die for her heart is weakening

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At any time even now a sudden shock would be almost sure to kill her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Ah we were wise to keep from her the affair of the dreadful night of Lucys sleepwalking

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 17 August

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: No diary for two whole days

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have not had the heart to write

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some sort of shadowy pall seems to be coming over our happiness

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: No news from Jonathan and Lucy seems to be growing weaker whilst her mothers hours are numbering to a close

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I do not understand Lucys fading away as she is doing

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She eats well and sleeps well and enjoys the fresh air but all the time the roses in her cheeks are fading and she gets weaker and more languid day by day at night I hear her gasping as if for air

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I keep the key of our door always fastened to my wrist at night but she gets up and walks about the room and sits at the open window

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Last night I found her leaning out when I woke up and when I tried to wake her I could not she was in a faint

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I managed to restore her she was as weak as water and cried silently between long painful struggles for breath

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I asked her how she came to be at the window she shook her head and turned away

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I trust her feeling ill may not be from that unlucky prick of the safetypin

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I looked at her throat just now as she lay asleep and the tiny wounds seem not to have healed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They are still open and if anything larger than before and the edges of them are faintly white

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They are like little white dots with red centres

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Unless they heal within a day or two I shall insist on the doctor seeing about them

words: CHAPTER IX    Letter Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: BudaPesth 24 August

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My dearest Lucy  I know you will be anxious to hear all that has happened since we parted at the railway station at Whitby

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Well my dear I got to Hull all right and caught the boat to Hamburg and then the train on here

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I feel that I can hardly recall anything of the journey except that I knew I was coming to Jonathan and that as I should have to do some nursing I had better get all the sleep I could

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I found my dear one oh so thin and pale and weaklooking

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All the resolution has gone out of his dear eyes and that quiet dignity which I told you was in his face has vanished

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He is only a wreck of himself and he does not remember anything that has happened to him for a long time past

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At least he wants me to believe so and I shall never ask

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He has had some terrible shock and I fear it might tax his poor brain if he were to try to recall it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Sister Agatha who is a good creature and a born nurse tells me that he raved of dreadful things whilst he was off his head

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I wanted her to tell me what they were but she would only cross herself and say she would never tell that the ravings of the sick were the secrets of God and that if a nurse through her vocation should hear them she should respect her trust

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She is a sweet good soul and the next day when she saw I was troubled she opened up the subject again and after saying that she could never mention what my poor dear raved about added I can tell you this much my dear that it was not about anything which he has done wrong himself and you as his wife to be have no cause to be concerned

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He has not forgotten you or what he owes to you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His fear was of great and terrible things which no mortal can treat of

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I do believe the dear soul thought I might be jealous lest my poor dear should have fallen in love with any other girl

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The idea of  my  being jealous about Jonathan

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And yet my dear let me whisper I felt a thrill of joy through me when I  knew  that no other woman was a cause of trouble

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am now sitting by his bedside where I can see his face while he sleeps

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he called me back and when I came he had his hand over the notebook and he said to me very solemnly  WilhelminaI knew then that he was in deadly earnest for he has never called me by that name since he asked me to marry himyou know dear my ideas of the trust between husband and wife there should be no secret no concealment

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You know I have had brain fever and that is to be mad

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

words: After a while finding no response I knocked and rang again still no answer

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I cursed the laziness of the servants that they should lie abed at such an hourfor it was now ten oclockand so rang and knocked again but more impatiently but still without response

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Hitherto I had blamed only the servants but now a terrible fear began to assail me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Was this desolation but another link in the chain of doom which seemed drawing tight around us Was it indeed a house of death to which I had come too late

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I knew that minutes even seconds of delay might mean hours of danger to Lucy if she had had again one of those frightful relapses and I went round the house to try if I could find by chance an entry anywhere

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could find no means of ingress

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Every window and door was fastened and locked and I returned baffled to the porch

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As I did so I heard the rapid pitpat of a swiftly driven horses feet

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They stopped at the gate and a few seconds later I met Van Helsing running up the avenue

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When he saw me he gasped out  Then it was you and just arrived

title: Dracula
words: How is she

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Are we too late

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Did you not get my telegram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I answered as quickly and coherently as I could that I had only got his telegram early in the morning and had not lost a minute in coming here and that I could not make any one in the house hear me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He paused and raised his hat as he said solemnly  Then I fear we are too late

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Gods will be done

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With his usual recuperative energy he went on Come

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If there be no way open to get in we must make one

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Time is all in all to us now

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We went round to the back of the house where there was a kitchen window

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Professor took a small surgical saw from his case and handing it to me pointed to the iron bars which guarded the window

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I attacked them at once and had very soon cut through three of them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then with a long thin knife we pushed back the fastening of the sashes and opened the window

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I helped the Professor in and followed him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was no one in the kitchen or in the servants rooms which were close at hand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We tried all the rooms as we went along and in the diningroom dimly lit by rays of light through the shutters found four servantwomen lying on the floor

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was no need to think them dead for their stertorous breathing and the acrid smell of laudanum in the room left no doubt as to their condition

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing and I looked at each other and as we moved away he said We can attend to them later

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then we ascended to Lucys room

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For an instant or two we paused at the door to listen but there was no sound that we could hear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: How shall I describe what we saw

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: On the bed lay two women Lucy and her mother

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The latter lay farthest in and she was covered with a white sheet the edge of which had been blown back by the draught through the broken window showing the drawn white face with a look of terror fixed upon it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: By her side lay Lucy with face white and still more drawn

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The flowers which had been round her neck we found upon her mothers bosom and her throat was bare showing the two little wounds which we had noticed before but looking horribly white and mangled

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Without a word the Professor bent over the bed his head almost touching poor Lucys breast then he gave a quick turn of his head as of one who listens and leaping to his feet he cried out to me  It is not yet too late

words: She was hardly able to turn her head and the little nourishment which she could take seemed to do her no good

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At times she slept and both Van Helsing and I noticed the difference in her between sleeping and waking

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Whilst asleep she looked stronger although more haggard and her breathing was softer her open mouth showed the pale gums drawn back from the teeth which thus looked positively longer and sharper than usual when she woke the softness of her eyes evidently changed the expression for she looked her own self although a dying one

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In the afternoon she asked for Arthur and we telegraphed for him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Quincey went off to meet him at the station

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When he arrived it was nearly six oclock and the sun was setting full and warm and the red light streamed in through the window and gave more colour to the pale cheeks

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When he saw her Arthur was simply choking with emotion and none of us could speak

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In the hours that had passed the fits of sleep or the comatose condition that passed for it had grown more frequent so that the pauses when conversation was possible were shortened

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthurs presence however seemed to act as a stimulant she rallied a little and spoke to him more brightly than she had done since we arrived

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He too pulled himself together and spoke as cheerily as he could so that the best was made of everything

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was now nearly one oclock and he and Van Helsing are sitting with her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am to relieve them in a quarter of an hour and I am entering this on Lucys phonograph

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Until six oclock they are to try to rest

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I fear that tomorrow will end our watching for the shock has been too great the poor child cannot rally

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: God help us all

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Letter Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Unopened by her   17 September

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My dearest Lucy  It seems  an age  since I heard from you or indeed since I wrote

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You will pardon me I know for all my faults when you have read all my budget of news

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Well I got my husband back all right when we arrived at Exeter there was a carriage waiting for us and in it though he had an attack of gout Mr Hawkins

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He took us to his house where there were rooms for us all nice and comfortable and we dined together

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: After dinner Mr Hawkins said  My dears I want to drink your health and prosperity and may every blessing attend you both

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I know you both from children and have with love and pride seen you grow up

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Now I want you to make your home here with me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have left to me neither chick nor child all are gone and in my will I have left you everything

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I cried Lucy dear as Jonathan and the old man clasped hands

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Our evening was a very very happy one

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: So here we are installed in this beautiful old house and from both my bedroom and the drawingroom I can see the great elms of the cathedral close with their great black stems standing out against the old yellow stone of the cathedral and I can hear the rooks overhead cawing and cawing and chattering and gossiping all day after the manner of rooksand humans

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am busy I need not tell you arranging things and housekeeping

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Jonathan and Mr Hawkins are busy all day for now that Jonathan is a partner Mr Hawkins wants to tell him all about the clients

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: How is your dear mother getting on

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I wish I could run up to town for a day or two to see you dear but I dare not go yet with so much on my shoulders and Jonathan wants looking after still

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He is beginning to put some flesh on his bones again but he was terribly weakened by the long illness even now he sometimes starts out of his sleep in a sudden way and awakes all trembling until I can coax him back to his usual placidity

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: However thank God these occasions grow less frequent as the days go on and they will in time pass away altogether I trust

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And now I have told you my news let me ask yours

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When are you to be married and where and who is to perform the ceremony and what are you to wear and is it to be a public or a private wedding

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Tell me all about it dear tell me all about everything for there is nothing which interests you which will not be dear to me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Jonathan asks me to send his respectful duty but I do not think that is good enough from the junior partner of the important firm Hawkins  Harker and so as you love me and he loves me and I love you with all the moods and tenses of the verb I send you simply his love instead

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Goodbye my dearest Lucy and all blessings on you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Yours  MINA HARKER

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Report from Patrick Hennessey M D M R C S L K Q C P I etc etc to John Seward M D    20 September

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My dear Sir  In accordance with your wishes I enclose report of the conditions of everything left in my charge

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With regard to patient Renfield there is more to say

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He has had another outbreak which might have had a dreadful ending but which as it fortunately happened was unattended with any unhappy results

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This afternoon a carriers cart with two men made a call at the empty house whose grounds abut on oursthe house to which you will remember the patient twice ran away

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The men stopped at our gate to ask the porter their way as they were strangers

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was myself looking out of the study window having a smoke after dinner and saw one of them come up to the house

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As he passed the window of Renfields room the patient began to rate him from within and called him all the foul names he could lay his tongue to

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The man who seemed a decent fellow enough contented himself by telling him to shut up for a foulmouthed beggar whereon our man accused him of robbing him and wanting to murder him and said that he would hinder him if he were to swing for it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I opened the window and signed to the man not to notice so he contented himself after looking the place over and making up his mind as to what kind of a place he had got to by saying Lor bless yer sir I wouldnt mind what was said to me in a bloomin madhouse

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I pity ye and the guvnor for havin to live in the house with a wild beast like that Then he asked his way civilly enough and I told him where the gate of the empty house was he went away followed by threats and curses and revilings from our man

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I went down to see if I could make out any cause for his anger since he is usually such a wellbehaved man and except his violent fits nothing of the kind had ever occurred

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I found him to my astonishment quite composed and most genial in his manner

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I tried to get him to talk of the incident but he blandly asked me questions as to what I meant and led me to believe that he was completely oblivious of the affair

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was I am sorry to say however only another instance of his cunning for within half an hour I heard of him again

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This time he had broken out through the window of his room and was running down the avenue

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I called to the attendants to follow me and ran after him for I feared he was intent on some mischief

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My fear was justified when I saw the same cart which had passed before coming down the road having on it some great wooden boxes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The men were wiping their foreheads and were flushed in the face as if with violent exercise

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Before I could get up to him the patient rushed at them and pulling one of them off the cart began to knock his head against the ground

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If I had not seized him just at the moment I believe he would have killed the man there and then

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The other fellow jumped down and struck him over the head with the buttend of his heavy whip

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was a terrible blow but he did not seem to mind it but seized him also and struggled with the three of us pulling us to and fro as if we were kittens

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You know I am no light weight and the others were both burly men

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At first he was silent in his fighting but as we began to master him and the attendants were putting a straitwaistcoat on him he began to shout Ill frustrate them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They shant rob me they shant murder me by inches

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Ill fight for my Lord and Master and all sorts of similar incoherent ravings

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was with very considerable difficulty that they got him back to the house and put him in the padded room

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One of the attendants Hardy had a finger broken

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: However I set it all right and he is going on well

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The two carriers were at first loud in their threats of actions for damages and promised to rain all the penalties of the law on us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Their threats were however mingled with some sort of indirect apology for the defeat of the two of them by a feeble madman

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They said that if it had not been for the way their strength had been spent in carrying and raising the heavy boxes to the cart they would have made short work of him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They gave as another reason for their defeat the extraordinary state of drouth to which they had been reduced by the dusty nature of their occupation and the reprehensible distance from the scene of their labours of any place of public entertainment

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I quite understood their drift and after a stiff glass of grog or rather more of the same and with each a sovereign in hand they made light of the attack and swore that they would encounter a worse madman any day for the pleasure of meeting so bloomin good a bloke as your correspondent

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I took their names and addresses in case they might be needed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They are as followsJack Smollet of Duddings Rents King Georges Road Great Walworth and Thomas Snelling Peter Farleys Row Guide Court Bethnal Green

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They are both in the employmen

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Letter Mina Harker to Lucy Westenra

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Unopened by her   18 September

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My dearest Lucy  Such a sad blow has befallen us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mr Hawkins has died very suddenly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some may not think it so sad for us but we had both come to so love him that it really seems as though we had lost a father

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I never knew either father or mother so that the dear old mans death is a real blow to me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Jonathan is greatly distressed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is not only that he feels sorrow deep sorrow for the dear good man who has befriended him all his life and now at the end has treated him like his own son and left him a fortune which to people of our modest bringing up is wealth beyond the dream of avarice but Jonathan feels it on another account

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He says the amount of responsibility which it puts upon him makes him nervous

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He begins to doubt himself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I try to cheer him up and  my  belief in  him  helps him to have a belief in himself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But it is here that the grave shock that he experienced tells upon him the most

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Oh it is too hard that a sweet simple noble strong nature such as hisa nature which enabled him by our dear good friends aid to rise from clerk to master in a few yearsshould be so injured that the very essence of its strength is gone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Forgive me dear if I worry you with my troubles in the midst of your own happiness but Lucy dear I must tell some one for the strain of keeping up a brave and cheerful appearance to Jonathan tries me and I have no one here that I can confide in

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I dread coming up to London as we must do the day after tomorrow for poor Mr Hawkins left in his will that he was to be buried in the grave with his father

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As there are no relations at all Jonathan will have to be chief mourner

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I shall try to run over to see you dearest if only for a few minutes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Forgive me for troubling you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With all blessings  Your loving  MINA HARKER

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Dr Sewards Diary

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 20 September

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Only resolution and habit can let me make an entry tonight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am too miserable too lowspirited too sick of the world and all in it including life itself that I would not care if I heard this moment the flapping of the wings of the angel of death

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And he has been flapping those grim wings to some purpose of lateLucys mother and Arthurs father and now Let me get on with my work

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I duly relieved Van Helsing in his watch over Lucy

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We wanted Arthur to go to rest also but he refused at first

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was only when I told him that we should want him to help us during the day and that we must not all break down for want of rest lest Lucy should suffer that he agreed to go

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing was very kind to him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Come my child he said come with me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You are sick and weak and have had much sorrow and much mental pain as well as that tax on your strength that we know of

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You must not be alone for to be alone is to be full of fears and alarms

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Come to the drawingroom where there is a big fire and there are two sofas

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You shall lie on one and I on the other and our sympathy will be comfort to each other even though we do not speak and even if we sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthur went off with him casting back a longing look on Lucys face which lay in her pillow almost whiter than the lawn

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She lay quite still and I looked round the room to see that all was as it should be

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could see that the Professor had carried out in this room as in the other his purpose of using the garlic the whole of the windowsashes reeked with it and round Lucys neck over the silk handkerchief which Van Helsing made her keep on was a rough chaplet of the same odorous flowers

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy was breathing somewhat stertorously and her face was at its worst for the open mouth showed the pale gums

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Her teeth in the dim uncertain light seemed longer and sharper than they had been in the morning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In particular by some trick of the light the canine teeth looked longer and sharper than the rest

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I sat down by her and presently she moved uneasily

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At the same moment there came a sort of dull flapping or buffeting at the window

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I went over to it softly and peeped out by the corner of the blind

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was a full moonlight and I could see that the noise was made by a great bat which wheeled rounddoubtless attracted by the light although so dimand every now and again struck the window with its wings

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I came back to my seat I found that Lucy had moved slightly and had torn away the garlic flowers from her throat

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I replaced them as well as I could and sat watching her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Presently she woke and I gave her food as Van Helsing had prescribed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She took but a little and that languidly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There did not seem to be with her now the unconscious struggle for life and strength that had hitherto so marked her illness

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It struck me as curious that the moment she became conscious she pressed the garlic flowers close to her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was certainly odd that whenever she got into that lethargic state with the stertorous breathing she put the flowers from her but that when she waked she clutched them close

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was no possibility of making any mistake about this for in the long hours that followed she had many spells of sleeping and waking and repeated both actions many times

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At six oclock Van Helsing came to relieve me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthur had then fallen into a doze and he mercifully let him sleep on

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When he saw Lucys face I could hear the sissing indraw of his breath and he said to me in a sharp whisper Draw up the blind I want light

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he bent down and with his face almost touching Lucys examined her carefully

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He removed the flowers and lifted the silk handkerchief from her throat

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As he did so he started back and I could hear his ejaculation Mein Gott as it was smothered in his throat

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I bent over and looked too and as I noticed some queer chill came over me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The wounds on the throat had absolutely disappeared

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For fully five minutes Van Helsing stood looking at her with his face at its sternest

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he turned to me and said calmly  She is dying

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It will not be long now

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It will be much difference mark me whether she dies conscious or in her sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Wake that poor boy and let him come and see the last he trusts us and we have promised him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I went to the diningroom and waked him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was dazed for a moment but when he saw the sunlight streaming in through the edges of the shutters he thought he was late and expressed his fear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I assured him that Lucy was still asleep but told him as gently as I could that both Van Helsing and I feared that the end was near

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He covered his face with his hands and slid down on his knees by the sofa where he remained perhaps a minute with his head buried praying whilst his shoulders shook with grief

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I took him by the hand and raised him up

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Come I said my dear old fellow summon all your fortitude it will be best and easiest for her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When we came into Lucys room I could see that Van Helsing had with his usual forethought been putting matters straight and making everything look as pleasing as possible

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He had even brushed Lucys hair so that it lay on the pillow in its usual sunny ripples

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When we came into the room she opened her eyes and seeing him whispered softly  Arthur

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Oh my love I am so glad you have come

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was stooping to kiss her when Van Helsing motioned him back

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: No he whispered not yet

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Hold her hand it will comfort her more

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: So Arthur took her hand and knelt beside her and she looked her best with all the soft lines matching the angelic beauty of her eyes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then gradually her eyes closed and she sank to sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For a little bit her breast heaved softly and her breath came and went like a tired childs

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And then insensibly there came the strange change which I had noticed in the night

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Her breathing grew stertorous the mouth opened and the pale gums drawn back made the teeth look longer and sharper than ever

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In a sort of sleepwaking vague unconscious way she opened her eyes which were now dull and hard at once and said in a soft voluptuous voice such as I had never heard from her lips  Arthur

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Oh my love I am so glad you have come

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Kiss me Arthur bent eagerly over to kiss her but at that instant Van Helsing who like me had been startled by her voice swooped upon him and catching him by the neck with both hands dragged him back with a fury of strength which I never thought he could have possessed and actually hurled him almost across the room

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Not for your life he said not for your living soul and hers

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And he stood between them like a lion at bay

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthur was so taken aback that he did not for a moment know what to do or say and before any impulse of violence could seize him he realised the place and the occasion and stood silent waiting

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I kept my eyes fixed on Lucy as did Van Helsing and we saw a spasm as of rage flit like a shadow over her face the sharp teeth champed together

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then her eyes closed and she breathed heavily

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Very shortly after she opened her eyes in all their softness and putting out her poor pale thin hand took Van Helsings great brown one drawing it to her she kissed it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My true friend she said in a faint voice but with untellable pathos My true friend and his Oh guard him and give me peace  I swear it he said solemnly kneeling beside her and holding up his hand as one who registers an oath

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he turned to Arthur and said to him Come my child take her hand in yours and kiss her on the forehead and only once

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Their eyes met instead of their lips and so they parted

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucys eyes closed and Van Helsing who had been watching closely took Arthurs arm and drew him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some change had come over her body

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Death had given back part of her beauty for her brow and cheeks had recovered some of their flowing lines even the lips had lost their deadly pallor

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was as if the blood no longer needed for the working of the heart had gone to make the harshness of death as little rude as might be

words: CHAPTER XIII  DR

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: SEWARDS DIARY continued

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The funeral was arranged for the next succeeding day so that Lucy and her mother might be buried together

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I attended to all the ghastly formalities and the urbane undertaker proved that his staff were afflictedor blessedwith something of his own obsequious suavity

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Even the woman who performed the last offices for the dead remarked to me in a confidential brotherprofessional way when she had come out from the deathchamber  She makes a very beautiful corpse sir

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Its quite a privilege to attend on her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Its not too much to say that she will do credit to our establishment

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I noticed that Van Helsing never kept far away

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This was possible from the disordered state of things in the household

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There were no relatives at hand and as Arthur had to be back the next day to attend at his fathers funeral we were unable to notify any one who should have been bidden

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Under the circumstances Van Helsing and I took it upon ourselves to examine papers etc

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He insisted upon looking over Lucys papers himself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I asked him why for I feared that he being a foreigner might not be quite aware of English legal requirements and so might in ignorance make some unnecessary trouble

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He answered me  I know I know

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You forget that I am a lawyer as well as a doctor

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But this is not altogether for the law

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You knew that when you avoided the coroner

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have more than him to avoid

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There may be papers moresuch as this

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As he spoke he took from his pocketbook the memorandum which had been in Lucys breast and which she had torn in her sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When you find anything of the solicitor who is for the late Mrs Westenra seal all her papers and write him tonight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For me I watch here in the room and in Miss Lucys old room all night and I myself search for what may be

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is not well that her very thoughts go into the hands of strangers

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I went on with my part of the work and in another half hour had found the name and address of Mrs Westenras solicitor and had written to him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All the poor ladys papers were in order explicit directions regarding the place of burial were given

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had hardly sealed the letter when to my surprise Van Helsing walked into the room saying  Can I help you friend John

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am free and if I may my service is to you  Have you got what you looked for

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I asked to which he replied  I did not look for any specific thing

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I only hoped to find and find I have all that there wasonly some letters and a few memoranda and a diary new begun

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But I have them here and we shall for the present say nothing of them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I shall see that poor lad tomorrow evening and with his sanction I shall use some

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When we had finished the work in hand he said to me  And now friend John I think we may to bed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We want sleep both you and I and rest to recuperate

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Tomorrow we shall have much to do but for the tonight there is no need of us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Alas  Before turning in we went to look at poor Lucy

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The undertaker had certainly done his work well for the room was turned into a small  chapelle ardente

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was a wilderness of beautiful white flowers and death was made as little repulsive as might be

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The end of the windingsheet was laid over the face when the Professor bent over and turned it gently back we both started at the beauty before us the tall wax candles showing a sufficient light to note it well

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All Lucys loveliness had come back to her in death and the hours that had passed instead of leaving traces of decays effacing fingers had but restored the beauty of life till positively I could not believe my eyes that I was looking at a corpse

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Professor looked sternly grave

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He had not loved her as I had and there was no need for tears in his eyes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He said to me Remain till I return and left the room

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He came back with a handful of wild garlic from the box waiting in the hall but which had not been opened and placed the flowers amongst the others on and around the bed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he took from his neck inside his collar a little gold crucifix and placed it over the mouth

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He restored the sheet to its place and we came away

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was undressing in my own room when with a premonitory tap at the door he entered and at once began to speak  Tomorrow I want you to bring me before night a set of postmortem knives

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Must we make an autopsy

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I asked

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Yes and no

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I want to operate but not as you think

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Let me tell you now but not a word to another

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I want to cut off her head and take out her heart

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Ah you a surgeon and so shocked

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You whom I have seen with no tremble of hand or heart do operations of life and death that make the rest shudder

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Oh but I must not forget my dear friend John that you loved her and I have not forgotten it for it is I that shall operate and you must only help

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I would like to do it tonight but for Arthur I must not he will be free after his fathers funeral tomorrow and he will want to see herto see  it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then when she is coffined ready for the next day you and I shall come when all sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We shall unscrew the coffinlid and shall do our operation and then replace all so that none know save we alone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But why do it at all

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The girl is dead

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Why mutilate her poor body without need

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And if there is no necessity for a postmortem and nothing to gain by itno good to her to us to science to human knowledgewhy do it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Without such it is monstrous

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For answer he put his hand on my shoulder and said with infinite tenderness  Friend John I pity your poor bleeding heart and I love you the more because it does so bleed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If I could I would take on myself the burden that you do bear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But there are things that you know not but that you shall know and bless me for knowing though they are not pleasant things

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: John my child you have been my friend now many years and yet did you ever know me to do any without good cause

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I may errI am but man but I believe in all I do

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Was it not for these causes that you send for me when the great trouble came

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Yes Were you not amazed nay horrified when I would not let Arthur kiss his lovethough she was dyingand snatched him away by all my strength

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Yes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And yet you saw how she thanked me with her so beautiful dying eyes her voice too so weak and she kiss my rough old hand and bless me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Yes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And did you not hear me swear promise to her that so she closed her eyes grateful

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Yes  Well I have good reason now for all I want to do

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You have for many years trust me you have believe me weeks past when there be things so strange that you might have well doubt

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Believe me yet a little friend John

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If you trust me not then I must tell what I think and that is not perhaps well

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And if I workas work I shall no matter trust or no trustwithout my friend trust in me I work with heavy heart and feel oh so lonely when I want all help and courage that may be

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He paused a moment and went on solemnly Friend John there are strange and terrible days before us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Let us not be two but one that so we work to a good end

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Will you not have faith in me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I took his hand and promised him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I held my door open as he went away and watched him go into his room and close the door

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As I stood without moving I saw one of the maids pass silently along the passageshe had her back towards me so did not see meand go into the room where Lucy lay

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The sight touched me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Devotion is so rare and we are so grateful to those who show it unasked to those we love

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here was a poor girl putting aside the terrors which she naturally had of death to go watch alone by the bier of the mistress whom she loved so that the poor clay might not be lonely till laid to eternal rest                                       I must have slept long and soundly for it was broad daylight when Van Helsing waked me by coming into my room

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He came over to my bedside and said  You need not trouble about the knives we shall not do it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Why not

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I asked

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For his solemnity of the night before had greatly impressed me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Because he said sternly it is too lateor too early

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: See

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here he held up the little golden crucifix

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This was stolen in the night

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: How stolen I asked in wonder since you have it now

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Because I get it back from the worthless wretch who stole it from the woman who robbed the dead and the living

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Her punishment will surely come but not through me she knew not altogether what she did and thus unknowing she only stole

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Now we must wait

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He went away on the word leaving me with a new mystery to think of a new puzzle to grapple with
