author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was very genial and very appreciative of what we had done and took off our hands all cares as to details

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: During lunch he told us that Mrs Westenra had for some time expected sudden death from her heart and had put her affairs in absolute order he informed us that with the exception of a certain entailed property of Lucys fathers which now in default of direct issue went back to a distant branch of the family the whole estate real and personal was left absolutely to Arthur Holmwood

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When he had told us so much he went on  Frankly we did our best to prevent such a testamentary disposition and pointed out certain contingencies that might leave her daughter either penniless or not so free as she should be to act regarding a matrimonial alliance

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Indeed we pressed the matter so far that we almost came into collision for she asked us if we were or were not prepared to carry out her wishes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Of course we had then no alternative but to accept

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We were right in principle and ninetynine times out of a hundred we should have proved by the logic of events the accuracy of our judgment

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Frankly however I must admit that in this case any other form of disposition would have rendered impossible the carrying out of her wishes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For by her predeceasing her daughter the latter would have come into possession of the property and even had she only survived her mother by five minutes her property would in case there were no willand a will was a practical impossibility in such a casehave been treated at her decease as under intestacy

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In which case Lord Godalming though so dear a friend would have had no claim in the world and the inheritors being remote would not be likely to abandon their just rights for sentimental reasons regarding an entire stranger

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I assure you my dear sirs I am rejoiced at the result perfectly rejoiced

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was a good fellow but his rejoicing at the one little partin which he was officially interestedof so great a tragedy was an objectlesson in the limitations of sympathetic understanding

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He did not remain long but said he would look in later in the day and see Lord Godalming

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His coming however had been a certain comfort to us since it assured us that we should not have to dread hostile criticism as to any of our acts

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthur was expected at five oclock so a little before that time we visited the deathchamber

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was so in very truth for now both mother and daughter lay in it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The undertaker true to his craft had made the best display he could of his goods and there was a mortuary air about the place that lowered our spirits at once

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing ordered the former arrangement to be adhered to explaining that as Lord Godalming was coming very soon it would be less harrowing to his feelings to see all that was left of his  fiancée  quite alone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The undertaker seemed shocked at his own stupidity and exerted himself to restore things to the condition in which we left them the night before so that when Arthur came such shocks to his feelings as we could avoid were saved

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Poor fellow

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He looked desperately sad and broken even his stalwart manhood seemed to have shrunk somewhat under the strain of his muchtried emotions

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He had I knew been very genuinely and devotedly attached to his father and to lose him and at such a time was a bitter blow to him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With me he was warm as ever and to Van Helsing he was sweetly courteous but I could not help seeing that there was some constraint with him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Professor noticed it too and motioned me to bring him upstairs

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I did so and left him at the door of the room as I felt he would like to be quite alone with her but he took my arm and led me in saying huskily  You loved her too old fellow she told me all about it and there was no friend had a closer place in her heart than you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I dont know how to thank you for all you have done for her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I cant think yet

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here he suddenly broke down and threw his arms round my shoulders and laid his head on my breast crying  Oh Jack Jack

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: What shall I do

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The whole of life seems gone from me all at once and there is nothing in the wide world for me to live for

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I comforted him as well as I could

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In such cases men do not need much expression

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A grip of the hand the tightening of an arm over the shoulder a sob in unison are expressions of sympathy dear to a mans heart

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I stood still and silent till his sobs died away and then I said softly to him  Come and look at her  Together we moved over to the bed and I lifted the lawn from her face

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: God how beautiful she was

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Every hour seemed to be enhancing her loveliness

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It frightened and amazed me somewhat and as for Arthur he fell atrembling and finally was shaken with doubt as with an ague

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At last after a long pause he said to me in a faint whisper  Jack is she really dead

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I assured him sadly that it was so and went on to suggestfor I felt that such a horrible doubt should not have life for a moment longer than I could helpthat it often happened that after death faces became softened and even resolved into their youthful beauty that this was especially so when death had been preceded by any acute or prolonged suffering

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It seemed to quite do away with any doubt and after kneeling beside the couch for a while and looking at her lovingly and long he turned aside

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I told him that that must be goodbye as the coffin had to be prepared so he went back and took her dead hand in his and kissed it and bent over and kissed her forehead

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He came away fondly looking back over his shoulder at her as he came

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I left him in the drawingroom and told Van Helsing that he had said goodbye so the latter went to the kitchen to tell the undertakers men to proceed with the preparations and to screw up the coffin

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When he came out of the room again I told him of Arthurs question and he replied  I am not surprised

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Just now I doubted for a moment myself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We all dined together and I could see that poor Art was trying to make the best of things

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing had been silent all dinnertime but when we had lit our cigars he said  Lord but Arthur interrupted him  No no not that for Gods sake not yet at any rate

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Forgive me sir I did not mean to speak offensively it is only because my loss is so recent

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Professor answered very sweetly  I only used that name because I was in doubt

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I must not call you Mr and I have grown to love youyes my dear boy to love youas Arthur

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthur held out his hand and took the old mans warmly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Call me what you will he said

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I hope I may always have the title of a friend

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And let me say that I am at a loss for words to thank you for your goodness to my poor dear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He paused a moment and went on I know that she understood your goodness even better than I do and if I was rude or in any way wanting at that time you acted soyou rememberthe Professor noddedyou must forgive me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He answered with a grave kindness  I know it was hard for you to quite trust me then for to trust such violence needs to understand and I take it that you do notthat you cannottrust me now for you do not yet understand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And there may be more times when I shall want you to trust when you cannotand may notand must not yet understand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But the time will come when your trust shall be whole and complete in me and when you shall understand as though the sunlight himself shone through

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then you shall bless me from first to last for your own sake and for the sake of others and for her dear sake to whom I swore to protect

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula
words: The Professor cleared his throat a couple of times as though about to speak and finally said  May I ask you something now  Certainly

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Jonathan thought it would interest me to go into the Row for a while so we sat down but there were very few people there and it was sadlooking and desolate to see so many empty chairs

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It made us think of the empty chair at home so we got up and walked down Piccadilly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Jonathan was holding me by the arm the way he used to in old days before I went to school

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I felt it very improper for you cant go on for some years teaching etiquette and decorum to other girls without the pedantry of it biting into yourself a bit but it was Jonathan and he was my husband and we didnt know anybody who saw usand we didnt care if they didso on we walked

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was looking at a very beautiful girl in a big cartwheel hat sitting in a victoria outside Guilianos when I felt Jonathan clutch my arm so tight that he hurt me and he said under his breath My God I am always anxious about Jonathan for I fear that some nervous fit may upset him again so I turned to him quickly and asked him what it was that disturbed him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was very pale and his eyes seemed bulging out as half in terror and half in amazement he gazed at a tall thin man with a beaky nose and black moustache and pointed beard who was also observing the pretty girl

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was looking at her so hard that he did not see either of us and so I had a good view of him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His face was not a good face it was hard and cruel and sensual and his big white teeth that looked all the whiter because his lips were so red were pointed like an animals

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Jonathan kept staring at him till I was afraid he would notice

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I feared he might take it ill he looked so fierce and nasty

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I asked Jonathan why he was disturbed and he answered evidently thinking that I knew as much about it as he did Do you see who it is  No dear I said I dont know him who is it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His answer seemed to shock and thrill me for it was said as if he did not know that it was to me Mina to whom he was speaking  It is the man himself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The poor dear was evidently terrified at somethingvery greatly terrified I do believe that if he had not had me to lean on and to support him he would have sunk down

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Westminster Gazette 25 September

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A HAMPSTEAD MYSTERY

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The neighbourhood of Hampstead is just at present exercised with a series of events which seem to run on lines parallel to those of what was known to the writers of headlines as The Kensington Horror or The Stabbing Woman or The Woman in Black

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: During the past two or three days several cases have occurred of young children straying from home or neglecting to return from their playing on the Heath

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In all these cases the children were too young to give any properly intelligible account of themselves but the consensus of their excuses is that they had been with a bloofer lady

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It has always been late in the evening when they have been missed and on two occasions the children have not been found until early in the following morning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is generally supposed in the neighbourhood that as the first child missed gave as his reason for being away that a bloofer lady had asked him to come for a walk the others had picked up the phrase and used it as occasion served

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This is the more natural as the favourite game of the little ones at present is luring each other away by wiles

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A correspondent writes us that to see some of the tiny tots pretending to be the bloofer lady is supremely funny

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some of our caricaturists might he says take a lesson in the irony of grotesque by comparing the reality and the picture

words: You must eat now afterwards you shall tell me all

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: After lunch when we went back to the drawingroom he said to me  And now tell me all about him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When it came to speaking to this great learned man I began to fear that he would think me a weak fool and Jonathan a madmanthat journal is all so strangeand I hesitated to go on

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But he was so sweet and kind and he had promised to help and I trusted him so I said  Dr

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing what I have to tell you is so queer that you must not laugh at me or at my husband

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have been since yesterday in a sort of fever of doubt you must be kind to me and not think me foolish that I have even half believed some very strange things

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He reassured me by his manner as well as his words when he said  Oh my dear if you only know how strange is the matter regarding which I am here it is you who would laugh

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have learned not to think little of any ones belief no matter how strange it be

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have tried to keep an open mind and it is not the ordinary things of life that could close it but the strange things the extraordinary things the things that make one doubt if they be mad or sane

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Thank you thank you a thousand times

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You have taken a weight off my mind

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If you will let me I shall give you a paper to read

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is long but I have typewritten it out

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It will tell you my trouble and Jonathans

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is the copy of his journal when abroad and all that happened

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I dare not say anything of it you will read for yourself and judge

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And then when I see you perhaps you will be very kind and tell me what you think

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I promise he said as I gave him the papers I shall in the morning so soon as I can come to see you and your husband if I may  Jonathan will be here at halfpast eleven and you must come to lunch with us and see him then you could catch the quick 334 train which will leave you at Paddington before eight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was surprised at my knowledge of the trains offhand but he does not know that I have made up all the trains to and from Exeter so that I may help Jonathan in case he is in a hurry

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: So he took the papers with him and went away and I sit here thinkingthinking I dont know what

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I will pledge my life on it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It may be worse for others but for him and you there is no dread

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He is a noble fellow and let me tell you from experience of men that one who would do as he did in going down that wall and to that roomay and going a second timeis not one to be injured in permanence by a shock

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His brain and his heart are all right this I swear before I have even seen him so be at rest

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I shall have much to ask him of other things

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am blessed that today I come to see you for I have learn all at once so much that again I am dazzledazzle more than ever and I must think

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Yours the most faithful  ABRAHAM VAN HELSING

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula
words: I fear to think

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have this moment whilst writing had a wire from Jonathan saying that he leaves by the 625 tonight from Launceston and will be here at 1018 so that I shall have no fear tonight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Will you therefore instead of lunching with us please come to breakfast at eight oclock if this be not too early for you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

words: First he took from his bag a mass of what looked like thin waferlike biscuit which was carefully rolled up in a white napkin next he took out a doublehandful of some whitish stuff like dough or putty

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He crumbled the wafer up fine and worked it into the mass between his hands

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This he then took and rolling it into thin strips began to lay them into the crevices between the door and its setting in the tomb

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was somewhat puzzled at this and being close asked him what it was that he was doing

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthur and Quincey drew near also as they too were curious

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He answered  I am closing the tomb so that the UnDead may not enter

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And is that stuff you have put there going to do it

title: Dracula

title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing reverently lifted his hat as he answered  The Host

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I brought it from Amsterdam

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have an Indulgence

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was an answer that appalled the most sceptical of us and we felt individually that in the presence of such earnest purpose as the Professors a purpose which could thus use the to him most sacred of things it was impossible to distrust

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In respectful silence we took the places assigned to us close round the tomb but hidden from the sight of any one approaching

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I pitied the others especially Arthur

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I had myself been apprenticed by my former visits to this watching horror and yet I who had up to an hour ago repudiated the proofs felt my heart sink within me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Never did tombs look so ghastly white never did cypress or yew or juniper so seem the embodiment of funereal gloom never did tree or grass wave or rustle so ominously never did bough creak so mysteriously and never did the faraway howling of dogs send such a woeful presage through the night

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was a long spell of silence a big aching void and then from the Professor a keen Ssss

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He pointed and far down the avenue of yews we saw a white figure advancea dim white figure which held something dark at its breast

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The figure stopped and at the moment a ray of moonlight fell upon the masses of driving clouds and showed in startling prominence a darkhaired woman dressed in the cerements of the grave

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We could not see the face for it was bent down over what we saw to be a fairhaired child

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was a pause and a sharp little cry such as a child gives in sleep or a dog as it lies before the fire and dreams

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We were starting forward but the Professors warning hand seen by us as he stood behind a yewtree kept us back and then as we looked the white figure moved forwards again

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was now near enough for us to see clearly and the moonlight still held

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My own heart grew cold as ice and I could hear the gasp of Arthur as we recognised the features of Lucy Westenra

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucy Westenra but yet how changed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The sweetness was turned to adamantine heartless cruelty and the purity to voluptuous wantonness

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing stepped out and obedient to his gesture we all advanced too the four of us ranged in a line before the door of the tomb

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing raised his lantern and drew the slide by the concentrated light that fell on Lucys face we could see that the lips were crimson with fresh blood and that the stream had trickled over her chin and stained the purity of her lawn deathrobe

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We shuddered with horror

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could see by the tremulous light that even Van Helsings iron nerve had failed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthur was next to me and if I had not seized his arm and held him up he would have fallen

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When LucyI call the thing that was before us Lucy because it bore her shapesaw us she drew back with an angry snarl such as a cat gives when taken unawares then her eyes ranged over us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lucys eyes in form and colour but Lucys eyes unclean and full of hellfire instead of the pure gentle orbs we knew

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At that moment the remnant of my love passed into hate and loathing had she then to be killed I could have done it with savage delight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As she looked her eyes blazed with unholy light and the face became wreathed with a voluptuous smile

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Oh God how it made me shudder to see it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With a careless motion she flung to the ground callous as a devil the child that up to now she had clutched strenuously to her breast growling over it as a dog growls over a bone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The child gave a sharp cry and lay there moaning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was a coldbloodedness in the act which wrung a groan from Arthur when she advanced to him with outstretched arms and a wanton smile he fell back and hid his face in his hands

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She still advanced however and with a languorous voluptuous grace said  Come to me Arthur

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Leave these others and come to me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My arms are hungry for you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Come and we can rest together

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Come my husband come

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There was something diabolically sweet in her tonessomething of the tingling of glass when struckwhich rang through the brains even of us who heard the words addressed to another

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As for Arthur he seemed under a spell moving his hands from his face he opened wide his arms

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She was leaping for them when Van Helsing sprang forward and held between them his little golden crucifix

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She recoiled from it and with a suddenly distorted face full of rage dashed past him as if to enter the tomb

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When within a foot or two of the door however she stopped as if arrested by some irresistible force

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then she turned and her face was shown in the clear burst of moonlight and by the lamp which had now no quiver from Van Helsings iron nerves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Never did I see such baffled malice on a face and never I trust shall such ever be seen again by mortal eyes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The beautiful colour became livid the eyes seemed to throw out sparks of hellfire the brows were wrinkled as though the folds of the flesh were the coils of Medusas snakes and the lovely bloodstained mouth grew to an open square as in the passion masks of the Greeks and Japanese

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If ever a face meant deathif looks could killwe saw it at that moment

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And so for full half a minute which seemed an eternity she remained between the lifted crucifix and the sacred closing of her means of entry

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing broke the silence by asking Arthur  Answer me oh my friend

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Am I to proceed in my work

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthur threw himself on his knees and hid his face in his hands as he answered  Do as you will friend do as you will

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There can be no horror like this ever any more and he groaned in spirit

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Quincey and I simultaneously moved towards him and took his arms

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We could hear the click of the closing lantern as Van Helsing held it down coming close to the tomb he began to remove from the chinks some of the sacred emblem which he had placed there

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula
words: Then there is more to do but not like this of tonight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As for this little one he is not much harm and by tomorrow night he shall be well

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We shall leave him where the police will find him as on the other night and then to home

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Coming close to Arthur he said  My friend Arthur you have had a sore trial but after when you look back you will see how it was necessary

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: You are now in the bitter waters my child

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: By this time tomorrow you will please God have passed them and have drunk of the sweet waters so do not mourn overmuch

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Till then I shall not ask you to forgive me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthur and Quincey came home with me and we tried to cheer each other on the way

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We had left the child in safety and were tired so we all slept with more or less reality of sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 29 September night

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A little before twelve oclock we threeArthur Quincey Morris and myselfcalled for the Professor

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was odd to notice that by common consent we had all put on black clothes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Of course Arthur wore black for he was in deep mourning but the rest of us wore it by instinct

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We got to the churchyard by halfpast one and strolled about keeping out of official observation so that when the gravediggers had completed their task and the sexton under the belief that every one had gone had locked the gate we had the place all to ourselves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing instead of his little black bag had with him a long leather one something like a cricketing bag it was manifestly of fair weight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When we were alone and had heard the last of the footsteps die out up the road we silently and as if by ordered intention followed the Professor to the tomb

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He unlocked the door and we entered closing it behind us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he took from his bag the lantern which he lit and also two wax candles which when lighted he stuck by melting their own ends on other coffins so that they might give light sufficient to work by

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When he again lifted the lid off Lucys coffin we all lookedArthur trembling like an aspenand saw that the body lay there in all its deathbeauty

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But there was no love in my own heart nothing but loathing for the foul Thing which had taken Lucys shape without her soul

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I could see even Arthurs face grow hard as he looked

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Presently he said to Van Helsing  Is this really Lucys body or only a demon in her shape

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is her body and yet not it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But wait a while and you all see her as she was and is

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She seemed like a nightmare of Lucy as she lay there the pointed teeth the bloodstained voluptuous mouthwhich it made one shudder to seethe whole carnal and unspiritual appearance seeming like a devilish mockery of Lucys sweet purity

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing with his usual methodicalness began taking the various contents from his bag and placing them ready for use

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: First he took out a soldering iron and some plumbing solder and then a small oillamp which gave out when lit in a corner of the tomb gas which burned at fierce heat with a blue flame then his operating knives which he placed to hand and last a round wooden stake some two and a half or three inches thick and about three feet long

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One end of it was hardened by charring in the fire and was sharpened to a fine point

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With this stake came a heavy hammer such as in households is used in the coalcellar for breaking the lumps

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: To me a doctors preparations for work of any kind are stimulating and bracing but the effect of these things on both Arthur and Quincey was to cause them a sort of consternation

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They both however kept their courage and remained silent and quiet

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When all was ready Van Helsing said  Before we do anything let me tell you this it is out of the lore and experience of the ancients and of all those who have studied the powers of the UnDead

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When they become such there comes with the change the curse of immortality they cannot die but must go on age after age adding new victims and multiplying the evils of the world for all that die from the preying of the UnDead becomes themselves UnDead and prey on their kind

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And so the circle goes on ever widening like as the ripples from a stone thrown in the water

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Friend Arthur if you had met that kiss which you know of before poor Lucy die or again last night when you open your arms to her you would in time when you had died have become  nosferatu  as they call it in Eastern Europe and would all time make more of those UnDeads that so have fill us with horror

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The career of this so unhappy dear lady is but just begun

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Those children whose blood she suck are not as yet so much the worse but if she live on UnDead more and more they lose their blood and by her power over them they come to her and so she draw their blood with that so wicked mouth

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But if she die in truth then all cease the tiny wounds of the throats disappear and they go back to their plays unknowing ever of what has been

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But of the most blessed of all when this now UnDead be made to rest as true dead then the soul of the poor lady whom we love shall again be free

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Instead of working wickedness by night and growing more debased in the assimilating of it by day she shall take her place with the other Angels

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: So that my friend it will be a blessed hand for her that shall strike the blow that sets her free

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: To this I am willing but is there none amongst us who has a better right

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Will it be no joy to think of hereafter in the silence of the night when sleep is not It was my hand that sent her to the stars it was the hand of him that loved her best the hand that of all she would herself have chosen had it been to her to choose Tell me if there be such a one amongst us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We all looked at Arthur

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He saw too what we all did the infinite kindness which suggested that his should be the hand which would restore Lucy to us as a holy and not an unholy memory he stepped forward and said bravely though his hand trembled and his face was as pale as snow  My true friend from the bottom of my broken heart I thank you

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Tell me what I am to do and I shall not falter

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing laid a hand on his shoulder and said  Brave lad

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A moments courage and it is done

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This stake must be driven through her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It will be a fearful ordealbe not deceived in thatbut it will be only a short time and you will then rejoice more than your pain was great from this grim tomb you will emerge as though you tread on air

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But you must not falter when once you have begun

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Only think that we your true friends are round you and that we pray for you all the time

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Go on said Arthur hoarsely

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Tell me what I am to do  Take this stake in your left hand ready to place the point over the heart and the hammer in your right

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then when we begin our prayer for the deadI shall read him I have here the book and the others shall followstrike in Gods name that so all may be well with the dead that we love and that the UnDead pass away

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Arthur took the stake and the hammer and when once his mind was set on action his hands never trembled nor even quivered

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing opened his missal and began to read and Quincey and I followed as well as we could

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Thing in the coffin writhed and a hideous bloodcurdling screech came from the opened red lips

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The body shook and quivered and twisted in wild contortions the sharp white teeth champed together till the lips were cut and the mouth was smeared with a crimson foam

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But Arthur never faltered

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He looked like a figure of Thor as his untrembling arm rose and fell driving deeper and deeper the mercybearing stake whilst the blood from the pierced heart welled and spurted up around it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: His face was set and high duty seemed to shine through it the sight of it gave us courage so that our voices seemed to ring through the little vault

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And then the writhing and quivering of the body became less and the teeth seemed to champ and the face to quiver

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Finally it lay still

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The terrible task was over

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The hammer fell from Arthurs hand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He reeled and would have fallen had we not caught him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The great drops of sweat sprang from his forehead and his breath came in broken gasps

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It had indeed been an awful strain on him and had he not been forced to his task by more than human considerations he could never have gone through with it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: For a few minutes we were so taken up with him that we did not look towards the coffin

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When we did however a murmur of startled surprise ran from one to the other of us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We gazed so eagerly that Arthur rose for he had been seated on the ground and came and looked too and then a glad strange light broke over his face and dispelled altogether the gloom of horror that lay upon it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There in the coffin lay no longer the foul Thing that we had so dreaded and grown to hate that the work of her destruction was yielded as a privilege to the one best entitled to it but Lucy as we had seen her in her life with her face of unequalled sweetness and purity

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: True that there were there as we had seen them in life the traces of care and pain and waste but these were all dear to us for they marked her truth to what we knew

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One and all we felt that the holy calm that lay like sunshine over the wasted face and form was only an earthly token and symbol of the calm that was to reign for ever

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

words: Outside the air was sweet the sun shone and the birds sang and it seemed as if all nature were tuned to a different pitch

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: No no my friend Jonathan you go take the lock off a hundred empty house in this your London or of any city in the world and if you do it as such things are rightly done and at the time such things are rightly done no one will interfere

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have read of a gentleman who owned a so fine house in London and when he went for months of summer to Switzerland and lock up his house some burglar came and broke window at back and got in

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he went and made open the shutters in front and walk out and in through the door before the very eyes of the police

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he have an auction in that house and advertise it and put up big notice and when the day come he sell off by a great auctioneer all the goods of that other man who own them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then he go to a builder and he sell him that house making an agreement that he pull it down and take all away within a certain time

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And your police and other authority help him all they can

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And when that owner come back from his holiday in Switzerland he find only an empty hole where his house had been

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: SEWARDS DIARY    11 October Evening

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Jonathan Harker has asked me to note this as he says he is hardly equal to the task and he wants an exact record kept

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I think that none of us were surprised when we were asked to see Mrs Harker a little before the time of sunset

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We have of late come to understand that sunrise and sunset are to her times of peculiar freedom when her old self can be manifest without any controlling force subduing or restraining her or inciting her to action

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This mood or condition begins some half hour or more before actual sunrise or sunset and lasts till either the sun is high or whilst the clouds are still aglow with the rays streaming above the horizon

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At first there is a sort of negative condition as if some tie were loosened and then the absolute freedom quickly follows when however the freedom ceases the changeback or relapse comes quickly preceded only by a spell of warning silence

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Tonight when we met she was somewhat constrained and bore all the signs of an internal struggle

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: A very few minutes however gave her complete control of herself then motioning her husband to sit beside her on the sofa where she was half reclining she made the rest of us bring chairs up close

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula
words: Jonathan Harkers Journal

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 15 October Varna

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We left Charing Cross on the morning of the 12th got to Paris the same night and took the places secured for us in the Orient Express

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We travelled night and day arriving here at about five oclock

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lord Godalming went to the Consulate to see if any telegram had arrived for him whilst the rest of us came on to this hotelthe Odessus

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The journey may have had incidents I was however too eager to get on to care for them

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Until the  Czarina Catherine  comes into port there will be no interest for me in anything in the wide world

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Thank God Mina is well and looks to be getting stronger her colour is coming back

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She sleeps a great deal throughout the journey she slept nearly all the time

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Before sunrise and sunset however she is very wakeful and alert and it has become a habit for Van Helsing to hypnotise her at such times

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At first some effort was needed and he had to make many passes but now she seems to yield at once as if by habit and scarcely any action is needed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He seems to have power at these particular moments to simply will and her thoughts obey him

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He always asks her what she can see and hear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She answers to the first  Nothing all is dark

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And to the second  I can hear the waves lapping against the ship and the water rushing by

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Canvas and cordage strain and masts and yards creak

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The wind is highI can hear it in the shrouds and the bow throws back the foam

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is evident that the  Czarina Catherine  is still at sea hastening on her way to Varna

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lord Godalming has just returned

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He had four telegrams one each day since we started and all to the same effect that the  Czarina Catherine  had not been reported to Lloyds from anywhere

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He had arranged before leaving London that his agent should send him every day a telegram saying if the ship had been reported

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was to have a message even if she were not reported so that he might be sure that there was a watch being kept at the other end of the wire

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We had dinner and went to bed early

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Tomorrow we are to see the ViceConsul and to arrange if we can about getting on board the ship as soon as she arrives

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Van Helsing says that our chance will be to get on the boat between sunrise and sunset

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Count even if he takes the form of a bat cannot cross the running water of his own volition and so cannot leave the ship

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As he dare not change to mans form without suspicionwhich he evidently wishes to avoidhe must remain in the box

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: If then we can come on board after sunrise he is at our mercy for we can open the box and make sure of him as we did of poor Lucy before he wakes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: What mercy he shall get from us will not count for much

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We think that we shall not have much trouble with officials or the seamen

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Thank God this is the country where bribery can do anything and we are well supplied with money

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We have only to make sure that the ship cannot come into port between sunset and sunrise without our being warned and we shall be safe

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Judge Moneybag will settle this case I think

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

words: Minas report still the same lapping waves and rushing water darkness and favouring winds

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We are evidently in good time and when we hear of the  Czarina Catherine  we shall be ready

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As she must pass the Dardanelles we are sure to have some report

title: Dracula
words: The Professor stood up  He has so used your mind and by it he has left us here in Varna whilst the ship that carried him rushed through enveloping fog up to Galatz where doubtless he had made preparation for escaping from us

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It would have to take its chance of being delayed and delay would be fatal with enemies on the track

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 3  By Water

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here is the safest way in one respect but with most danger in another

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: On the water he is powerless except at night even then he can only summon fog and storm and snow and his wolves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But were he wrecked the living water would engulf him helpless and he would indeed be lost

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He could have the vessel drive to land but if it were unfriendly land wherein he was not free to move his position would still be desperate

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We know from the record that he was on the water so what we have to do is to ascertain  what  water

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The first thing is to realise exactly what he has done as yet we may then get a light on what his later task is to be

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Firstly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We must differentiate between what he did in London as part of his general plan of action when he was pressed for moments and had to arrange as best he could

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Secondly  we must see as well as we can surmise it from the facts we know of what he has done here

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As to the first he evidently intended to arrive at Galatz and sent invoice to Varna to deceive us lest we should ascertain his means of exit from England his immediate and sole purpose then was to escape

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The proof of this is the letter of instructions sent to Immanuel Hildesheim to clear and take away the box  before sunrise

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There is also the instruction to Petrof Skinsky

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: These we must only guess at but there must have been some letter or message since Skinsky came to Hildesheim

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: That so far his plans were successful we know

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The  Czarina Catherine  made a phenomenally quick journeyso much so that Captain Donelsons suspicions were aroused but his superstition united with his canniness played the Counts game for him and he ran with his favouring wind through fogs and all till he brought up blindfold at Galatz

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: That the Counts arrangements were well made has been proved

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Hildesheim cleared the box took it off and gave it to Skinsky

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Skinsky took itand here we lose the trail

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We only know that the box is somewhere on the water moving along

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The customs and the octroi if there be any have been avoided

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Now we come to what the Count must have done after his arrival on land  at Galatz

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The box was given to Skinsky before sunrise

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At sunrise the Count could appear in his own form

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here we ask why Skinsky was chosen at all to aid in the work

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In my husbands diary Skinsky is mentioned as dealing with the Slovaks who trade down the river to the port and the mans remark that the murder was the work of a Slovak showed the general feeling against his class

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Count wanted isolation

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: My surmise is this that in London the Count decided to get back to his castle by water as the most safe and secret way

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He was brought from the castle by Szgany and probably they delivered their cargo to Slovaks who took the boxes to Varna for there they were shipped for London

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Thus the Count had knowledge of the persons who could arrange this service

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When the box was on land before sunrise or after sunset he came out from his box met Skinsky and instructed him what to do as to arranging the carriage of the box up some river

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When this was done and he knew that all was in train he blotted out his traces as he thought by murdering his agent

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have examined the map and find that the river most suitable for the Slovaks to have ascended is either the Pruth or the Sereth

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I read in the typescript that in my trance I heard cows low and water swirling level with my ears and the creaking of wood

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There would be no such sound if floating down stream

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Of course it may not be either the Sereth or the Pruth but we may possibly investigate further

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Now of these two the Pruth is the more easily navigated but the Sereth is at Fundu joined by the Bistritza which runs up round the Borgo Pass

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The loop it makes is manifestly as close to Draculas castle as can be got by water

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

words: I felt so thankful that Lord Godalming is rich and that both he and Mr Morris who also has plenty of money are willing to spend it so freely

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am writing this in the light from the furnace door of the steam launch Lord Godalming is firing up

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He is an experienced hand at the work as he has had for years a launch of his own on the Thames and another on the Norfolk Broads

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Regarding our plans we finally decided that Minas guess was correct and that if any waterway was chosen for the Counts escape back to his Castle the Sereth and then the Bistritza at its junction would be the one

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We took it that somewhere about the 47th degree north latitude would be the place chosen for the crossing the country between the river and the Carpathians

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We have no fear in running at good speed up the river at night there is plenty of water and the banks are wide enough apart to make steaming even in the dark easy enough

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Lord Godalming tells me to sleep for a while as it is enough for the present for one to be on watch

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But I cannot sleephow can I with the terrible danger hanging over my darling and her going out into that awful place My only comfort is that we are in the hands of God

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Only for that faith it would be easier to die than to live and so be quit of all the trouble

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Mr Morris and Dr Seward were off on their long ride before we started they are to keep up the right bank far enough off to get on higher lands where they can see a good stretch of river and avoid the following of its curves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They have for the first stages two men to ride and lead their spare horsesfour in all so as not to excite curiosity

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When they dismiss the men which shall be shortly they shall themselves look after the horses

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It may be necessary for us to join forces if so they can mount our whole party

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: One of the saddles has a movable horn and can be easily adapted for Mina if required

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is a wild adventure we are on

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Here as we are rushing along through the darkness with the cold from the river seeming to rise up and strike us with all the mysterious voices of the night around us it all comes home

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We seem to be drifting into unknown places and unknown ways into a whole world of dark and dreadful things

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Still hurrying along

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The day has come and Godalming is sleeping

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am on watch

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The morning is bitterly cold the furnace heat is grateful though we have heavy fur coats

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As yet we have passed only a few open boats but none of them had on board any box or package of anything like the size of the one we seek

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The men were scared every time we turned our electric lamp on them and fell on their knees and prayed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 1 November evening

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: No news all day we have found nothing of the kind we seek

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We have now passed into the Bistritza and if we are wrong in our surmise our chance is gone

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We have overhauled every boat big and little

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Early this morning one crew took us for a Government boat and treated us accordingly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We saw in this a way of smoothing matters so at Fundu where the Bistritza runs into the Sereth we got a Roumanian flag which we now fly conspicuously

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: With every boat which we have overhauled since then this trick has succeeded we have had every deference shown to us and not once any objection to whatever we chose to ask or do

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Some of the Slovaks tell us that a big boat passed them going at more than usual speed as she had a double crew on board

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: This was before they came to Fundu so they could not tell us whether the boat turned into the Bistritza or continued on up the Sereth

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At Fundu we could not hear of any such boat so she must have passed there in the night

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am feeling very sleepy the cold is perhaps beginning to tell upon me and nature must have rest some time

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Godalming insists that he shall keep the first watch

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: God bless him for all his goodness to poor dear Mina and me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 2 November morning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is broad daylight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: That good fellow would not wake me

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He says it would have been a sin to for I slept peacefully and was forgetting my trouble

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It seems brutally selfish to me to have slept so long and let him watch all night but he was quite right

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am a new man this morning and as I sit here and watch him sleeping I can do all that is necessary both as to minding the engine steering and keeping watch

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: CHAPTER XXVII  MINA HARKERS JOURNAL    1 November

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All day long we have travelled and at a good speed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The horses seem to know that they are being kindly treated for they go willingly their full stage at best speed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We have now had so many changes and find the same thing so constantly that we are encouraged to think that the journey will be an easy one

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Dr Van Helsing is laconic he tells the farmers that he is hurrying to Bistritz and pays them well to make the exchange of horses

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We get hot soup or coffee or tea and off we go

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is a lovely country full of beauties of all imaginable kinds and the people are brave and strong and simple and seem full of nice qualities

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: They are  very very  superstitious

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: In the first house where we stopped when the woman who served us saw the scar on my forehead she crossed herself and put out two fingers towards me to keep off the evil eye

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I believe they went to the trouble of putting an extra amount of garlic into our food and I cant abide garlic

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Ever since then I have taken care not to take off my hat or veil and so have escaped their suspicions

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We are travelling fast and as we have no driver with us to carry tales we go ahead of scandal but I daresay that fear of the evil eye will follow hard behind us all the way

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The Professor seems tireless all day he would not take any rest though he made me sleep for a long spell

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At sunset time he hypnotised me and he says that I answered as usual darkness lapping water and creaking wood so our enemy is still on the river

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am afraid to think of Jonathan but somehow I have now no fear for him or for myself

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I write this whilst we wait in a farmhouse for the horses to be got ready

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Dr Van Helsing is sleeping Poor dear he looks very tired and old and grey but his mouth is set as firmly as a conquerors even in his sleep he is instinct with resolution

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When we have well started I must make him rest whilst I drive

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I shall tell him that we have days before us and we must not break down when most of all his strength will be needed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All is ready we are off shortly

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I was successful and we took turns driving all night now the day is on us bright though cold

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There is a strange heaviness in the airI say heaviness for want of a better word I mean that it oppresses us both

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It is very cold and only our warm furs keep us comfortable

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At dawn Van Helsing hypnotised me he says I answered darkness creaking wood and roaring water so the river is changing as they ascend

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I do hope that my darling will not run any chance of dangermore than need be but we are in Gods hands

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All day long driving

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The country gets wilder as we go and the great spurs of the Carpathians which at Veresti seemed so far from us and so low on the horizon now seem to gather round us and tower in front

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We both seem in good spirits I think we make an effort each to cheer the other in the doing so we cheer ourselves

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Dr Van Helsing says that by morning we shall reach the Borgo Pass

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The houses are very few here now and the Professor says that the last horse we got will have to go on with us as we may not be able to change

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: He got two in addition to the two we changed so that now we have a rude fourinhand

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The dear horses are patient and good and they give us no trouble

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We are not worried with other travellers and so even I can drive

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We shall get to the Pass in daylight we do not want to arrive before

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: So we take it easy and have each a long rest in turn

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Oh what will tomorrow bring to us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We go to seek the place where my poor darling suffered so much

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: God grant that we may be guided aright and that He will deign to watch over my husband and those dear to us both and who are in such deadly peril

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As for me I am not worthy in His sight

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Alas

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am unclean to His eyes and shall be until He may deign to let me stand forth in His sight as one of those who have not incurred His wrath

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Her long sleep all day have refresh and restore her for now she is all sweet and bright as ever

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At sunset I try to hypnotise her but alas with no effect the power has grown less and less with each day and tonight it fail me altogether

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Well Gods will be donewhatever it may be and whithersoever it may lead

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula
words: This time she wake with not much trouble and then I try to put her to hypnotic sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But she sleep not being as though I were not

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Still I try and try till all at once I find her and myself in dark so I look round and find that the sun have gone down

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Madam Mina laugh and I turn and look at her

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She is now quite awake and look so well as I never saw her since that night at Carfax when we first enter the Counts house

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I am amaze and not at ease then but she is so bright and tender and thoughtful for me that I forget all fear

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I light a fire for we have brought supply of wood with us and she prepare food while I undo the horses and set them tethered in shelter to feed

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then when I return to the fire she have my supper ready

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I go to help her but she smile and tell me that she have eat alreadythat she was so hungry that she would not wait

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I like it not and I have grave doubts but I fear to affright her and so I am silent of it

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She help me and I eat alone and then we wrap in fur and lie beside the fire and I tell her to sleep while I watch

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But presently I forget all of watching and when I sudden remember that I watch I find her lying quiet but awake and looking at me with so bright eyes

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Once twice more the same occur and I get much sleep till before morning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: When I wake I try to hypnotise her but alas though she shut her eyes obedient she may not sleep

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: The sun rise up and up and up and then sleep come to her too late but so heavy that she will not wake

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I have to lift her up and place her sleeping in the carriage when I have harnessed the horses and made all ready

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Madam still sleep and she look in her sleep more healthy and more redder than before

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And I like it not

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: And I am afraid afraid afraidI am afraid of all thingseven to think but I must go on my way

title: Dracula
words: The stake we play for is life and death or more than these and we must not flinch

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: 5 November morning

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Let me be accurate in everything for though you and I have seen some strange things together you may at the first think that I Van Helsing am madthat the many horrors and the so long strain on nerves has at the last turn my brain

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: All yesterday we travel ever getting closer to the mountains and moving into a more and more wild and desert land

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: There are great frowning precipices and much falling water and Nature seem to have held sometime her carnival

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Madam Mina still sleep and sleep and though I did have hunger and appeased it I could not waken hereven for food

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I began to fear that the fatal spell of the place was upon her tainted as she is with that Vampire baptism

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Well said I to myself if it be that she sleep all the day it shall also be that I do not sleep at night

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: As we travel on the rough road for a road of an ancient and imperfect kind there was I held down my head and slept

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Again I waked with a sense of guilt and of time passed and found Madam Mina still sleeping and the sun low down

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But all was indeed changed the frowning mountains seemed further away and we were near the top of a steeprising hill on summit of which was such a castle as Jonathan tell of in his diary

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: At once I exulted and feared for now for good or ill the end was near

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I woke Madam Mina and again tried to hypnotise her but alas unavailing till too late

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then ere the great dark came upon usfor even after downsun the heavens reflected the gone sun on the snow and all was for a time in a great twilightI took out the horses and fed them in what shelter I could

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then I make a fire and near it I make Madam Mina now awake and more charming than ever sit comfortable amid her rugs

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I did not press her knowing her unavailingness

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But I myself eat for I must needs now be strong for all

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Then with the fear on me of what might be I drew a ring so big for her comfort round where Madam Mina sat and over the ring I passed some of the wafer and I broke it fine so that all was well guarded

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She sat still all the timeso still as one dead and she grew whiter and ever whiter till the snow was not more pale and no word she said

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: But when I drew near she clung to me and I could know that the poor soul shook her from head to feet with a tremor that was pain to feel

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I said to her presently when she had grown more quiet  Will you not come over to the fire for I wished to make a test of what she could

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: She rose obedient but when she have made a step she stopped and stood as one stricken

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Why not go on

words: I asked

author: Stoker, Bram

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: I rejoiced for I knew that what she could not none of those that we dreaded could

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Though there might be danger to her body yet her soul was safe

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: We had of late been so accustomed to watch for sunrise and sunset that we knew with fair accuracy when it would be and we knew that before long the sun would set

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: It was hard to believe that by our watches it was less than an hour that we waited in that rocky shelter before the various bodies began to converge close upon us

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula

author: Stoker, Bram
title: Dracula
words: Strangely enough those pursued did not seem to realise or at least to care that they were pursued they seemed however to hasten with redoubled speed as the sun dropped lower and lower on the mountain tops

title: Dracula

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale
words: But first on earth as Vampyre sent   Thy corse shall from its tomb be rent   Then ghastly haunt the native place   And suck the blood of all thy race   There from thy daughter sister wife   At midnight drain the stream of life   Yet loathe the banquet which perforce   Must feed thy livid living corse   Thy victims ere they yet expire   Shall know the demon for their sire   As cursing thee thou cursing them   Thy flowers are withered on the stem

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale
words: But one that for thy crime must fall   The youngest best beloved of all   Shall bless thee with a fathers name   That word shall wrap thy heart in flame

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale
words: Yet thou must end thy task and mark   Her cheeks last tingeher eyes last spark   And the last glassy glance must view   Which freezes oer its lifeless blue   Then with unhallowed hand shall tear   The tresses of her yellow hair   Of which in life a lock when shorn   Affections fondest pledge was worn   But now is borne away by thee   Memorial of thine agony

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale
words: At Brussels and other towns through which they passed Aubrey was surprized at the apparent eagerness with which his companion sought for the centres of all fashionable vice there he entered into all the spirit of the faro table he betted and always gambled with success except where the known sharper was his antagonist and then he lost even more than he gained but it was always with the same unchanging face with which he generally watched the society around it was not however so when he encountered the rash youthful novice or the luckless father of a numerous family then his very wish seemed fortunes lawthis apparent abstractedness of mind was laid aside and his eyes sparkled with more fire than that of the cat whilst dallying with the halfdead mouse

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale
words: Her earnestness and apparent belief of what she narrated excited the interest even of Aubrey and often as she told him the tale of the living vampyre who had passed years amidst his friends and dearest ties forced every year by feeding upon the life of a lovely female to prolong his existence for the ensuing months his blood would run cold whilst he attempted to laugh her out of such idle and horrible fantasies but Ianthe cited to him the names of old men who had at last detected one living among themselves after several of their near relatives and children had been found marked with the stamp of the fiends appetite and when she found him so incredulous she begged of him to believe her for it had been remarked that those who had dared to question their existence always had some proof given which obliged them with grief and heartbreaking to confess it was true

author: Polidori, John William

title: The Vampyre; a Tale

title: The Vampyre; a Tale

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale

title: The Vampyre; a Tale

title: The Vampyre; a Tale

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale
words: They were all simply decorated plain greenstained walls marble tables on either side a large myrtle in the centre and a small fountain beneath which could be made to play through the branches by moving a spring fixed in the side of a small bronze Venus in a leaning posture a large couch or sofa completed the furniture

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale
words: In the hall stood half a dozen English cane chairs and an empty bookcase there were no mirrors nor a single painting

title: The Vampyre; a Tale

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale
words: On the tablet of the recess lay Voltaires Shakspeares Boileaus and Rousseaus works complete Volneys Ruins of Empires Zimmerman in the German language Klopstocks Messiah Kotzebues novels Schillers play of the Robbers Miltons Paradise Lost an Italian edition printed at Parma in 1810 several small pamphlets from the Greek press at Constantinople much torn but no English book of any description

author: Polidori, John William

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale

author: Polidori, John William
title: The Vampyre; a Tale

words: I and my father constituted the family at the schloss

title: Carmilla

words: There was a fourth Mademoiselle De Lafontaine a lady such as you term I believe a finishing governess

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: She spoke French and German Madame Perrodon French and broken English to which my father and I added English which partly to prevent its becoming a lost language among us and partly from patriotic motives we spoke every day

words: The consequence was a Babel at which strangers used to laugh and which I shall make no attempt to reproduce in this narrative

title: Carmilla
