title: Carmilla
words: I was not frightened for I was one of those happy children who are studiously kept in ignorance of ghost stories of fairy tales and of all such lore as makes us cover up our heads when the door cracks suddenly or the flicker of an expiring candle makes the shadow of a bedpost dance upon the wall nearer to our faces

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

title: Carmilla
words: It was that of a young lady who was kneeling with her hands under the coverlet

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I was now for the first time frightened and I yelled with all my might and main

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Nurse nursery maid housekeeper all came running in and hearing my story they made light of it soothing me all they could meanwhile

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: But child as I was I could perceive that their faces were pale with an unwonted look of anxiety and I saw them look under the bed and about the room and peep under tables and pluck open cupboards and the housekeeper whispered to the nurse Lay your hand along that hollow in the bed someone  did  lie there so sure as you did not the place is still warm

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I remember the nursery maid petting me and all three examining my chest where I told them I felt the puncture and pronouncing that there was no sign visible that any such thing had happened to me

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The housekeeper and the two other servants who were in charge of the nursery remained sitting up all night and from that time a servant always sat up in the nursery until I was about fourteen

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I was very nervous for a long time after this

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: A doctor was called in he was pallid and elderly

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I remember my father coming up and standing at the bedside and talking cheerfully and asking the nurse a number of questions and laughing very heartily at one of the answers and patting me on the shoulder and kissing me and telling me not to be frightened that it was nothing but a dream and could not hurt me

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: But I was not comforted for I knew the visit of the strange woman was  not  a dream and I was  awfully  frightened

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: But this though supported by the nurse did not quite satisfy me

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I forget all my life preceding that event and for some time after it is all obscure also but the scenes I have just described stand out vivid as the isolated pictures of the phantasmagoria surrounded by darkness

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: II   A Guest   I am now going to tell you something so strange that it will require all your faith in my veracity to believe my story

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: It is not only true nevertheless but truth of which I have been an eyewitness

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: It was a sweet summer evening and my father asked me as he sometimes did to take a little ramble with him along that beautiful forest vista which I have mentioned as lying in front of the schloss

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: General Spielsdorf cannot come to us so soon as I had hoped said my father as we pursued our walk

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: He was to have paid us a visit of some weeks and we had expected his arrival next day

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: He was to have brought with him a young lady his niece and ward Mademoiselle Rheinfeldt whom I had never seen but whom I had heard described as a very charming girl and in whose society I had promised myself many happy days

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I was more disappointed than a young lady living in a town or a bustling neighborhood can possibly imagine

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: This visit and the new acquaintance it promised had furnished my day dream for many weeks

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: And how soon does he come

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I asked

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Not till autumn

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Not for two months I dare say he answered

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: And I am very glad now dear that you never knew Mademoiselle Rheinfeldt  And why

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I asked both mortified and curious

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Because the poor young lady is dead he replied

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I quite forgot I had not told you but you were not in the room when I received the Generals letter this evening

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I was very much shocked

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: General Spielsdorf had mentioned in his first letter six or seven weeks before that she was not so well as he would wish her but there was nothing to suggest the remotest suspicion of danger

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Here is the Generals letter he said handing it to me

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I am afraid he is in great affliction the letter appears to me to have been written very nearly in distraction

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: We sat down on a rude bench under a group of magnificent lime trees

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The sun was setting with all its melancholy splendor behind the sylvan horizon and the stream that flows beside our home and passes under the steep old bridge I have mentioned wound through many a group of noble trees almost at our feet reflecting in its current the fading crimson of the sky

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: General Spielsdorfs letter was so extraordinary so vehement and in some places so selfcontradictory that I read it twice overthe second time aloud to my fatherand was still unable to account for it except by supposing that grief had unsettled his mind

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: It said I have lost my darling daughter for as such I loved her

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: During the last days of dear Berthas illness I was not able to write to you

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Before then I had no idea of her danger

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I have lost her and now learn  all  too late

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: She died in the peace of innocence and in the glorious hope of a blessed futurity

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The fiend who betrayed our infatuated hospitality has done it all

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I thought I was receiving into my house innocence gaiety a charming companion for my lost Bertha

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Heavens what a fool have I been

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I thank God my child died without a suspicion of the cause of her sufferings

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: She is gone without so much as conjecturing the nature of her illness and the accursed passion of the agent of all this misery

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I devote my remaining days to tracking and extinguishing a monster

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I am told I may hope to accomplish my righteous and merciful purpose

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: At present there is scarcely a gleam of light to guide me

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I curse my conceited incredulity my despicable affectation of superiority my blindness my obstinacyalltoo late

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I cannot write or talk collectedly now

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I am distracted

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: So soon as I shall have a little recovered I mean to devote myself for a time to enquiry which may possibly lead me as far as Vienna

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Some time in the autumn two months hence or earlier if I live I will see youthat is if you permit me I will then tell you all that I scarce dare put upon paper now

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Farewell

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Pray for me dear friend

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: In these terms ended this strange letter

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Though I had never seen Bertha Rheinfeldt my eyes filled with tears at the sudden intelligence I was startled as well as profoundly disappointed

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The sun had now set and it was twilight by the time I had returned the Generals letter to my father

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: It was a soft clear evening and we loitered speculating upon the possible meanings of the violent and incoherent sentences which I had just been reading

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: We had nearly a mile to walk before reaching the road that passes the schloss in front and by that time the moon was shining brilliantly

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: At the drawbridge we met Madame Perrodon and Mademoiselle De Lafontaine who had come out without their bonnets to enjoy the exquisite moonlight

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: We heard their voices gabbling in animated dialogue as we approached

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: We joined them at the drawbridge and turned about to admire with them the beautiful scene

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The glade through which we had just walked lay before us

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: At our left the narrow road wound away under clumps of lordly trees and was lost to sight amid the thickening forest

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: At the right the same road crosses the steep and picturesque bridge near which stands a ruined tower which once guarded that pass and beyond the bridge an abrupt eminence rises covered with trees and showing in the shadows some grey ivyclustered rocks

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Over the sward and low grounds a thin film of mist was stealing like smoke marking the distances with a transparent veil and here and there we could see the river faintly flashing in the moonlight

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: No softer sweeter scene could be imagined

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The news I had just heard made it melancholy but nothing could disturb its character of profound serenity and the enchanted glory and vagueness of the prospect

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: My father who enjoyed the picturesque and I stood looking in silence over the expanse beneath us

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The two good governesses standing a little way behind us discoursed upon the scene and were eloquent upon the moon

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Madame Perrodon was fat middleaged and romantic and talked and sighed poetically

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The effect of the full moon in such a state of brilliancy was manifold

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: It acted on dreams it acted on lunacy it acted on nervous people it had marvelous physical influences connected with life

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The moon this night she said is full of idyllic and magnetic influenceand see when you look behind you at the front of the schloss how all its windows flash and twinkle with that silvery splendor as if unseen hands had lighted up the rooms to receive fairy guests

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: There are indolent styles of the spirits in which indisposed to talk ourselves the talk of others is pleasant to our listless ears and I gazed on pleased with the tinkle of the ladies conversation

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: At this moment the unwonted sound of carriage wheels and many hoofs upon the road arrested our attention

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

words: Do pray

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: If Madame will entrust her child to the care of my daughter and of her good gouvernante Madame Perrodon and permit her to remain as our guest under my charge until her return it will confer a distinction and an obligation upon us and we shall treat her with all the care and devotion which so sacred a trust deserves

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I cannot do that sir it would be to task your kindness and chivalry too cruelly said the lady distractedly

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: It would on the contrary be to confer on us a very great kindness at the moment when we most need it

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: My daughter has just been disappointed by a cruel misfortune in a visit from which she had long anticipated a great deal of happiness

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: If you confide this young lady to our care it will be her best consolation

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The nearest village on your route is distant and affords no such inn as you could think of placing your daughter at you cannot allow her to continue her journey for any considerable distance without danger

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: If as you say you cannot suspend your journey you must part with her tonight and nowhere could you do so with more honest assurances of care and tenderness than here

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

words: By this time the carriage was replaced in its upright position and the horses quite tractable in the traces again

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I was filled with wonder that my father did not seem to perceive the change and also unspeakably curious to learn what it could be that she was speaking almost in his ear with so much earnestness and rapidity

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: She kneeled beside her for a moment and whispered as Madame supposed a little benediction in her ear then hastily kissing her she stepped into her carriage the door was closed the footmen in stately liveries jumped up behind the outriders spurred on the postilions cracked their whips the horses plunged and broke suddenly into a furious canter that threatened soon again to become a gallop and the carriage whirled away followed at the same rapid pace by the two horsemen in the rear

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

title: Carmilla

title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: IX   The Doctor   As Carmilla would not hear of an attendant sleeping in her room my father arranged that a servant should sleep outside her door so that she would not attempt to make another such excursion without being arrested at her own door

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: At twelve oclock accordingly I was ready and not long after my father Madame and I set out upon our projected drive

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: In this solitude having just listened to so strange a story connected as it was with the great and titled dead whose monuments were moldering among the dust and ivy round us and every incident of which bore so awfully upon my own mysterious casein this haunted spot darkened by the towering foliage that rose on every side dense and high above its noiseless wallsa horror began to steal over me and my heart sank as I thought that my friends were after all not about to enter and disturb this triste and ominous scene

title: Carmilla
words: The old Generals eyes were fixed on the ground as he leaned with his hand upon the basement of a shattered monument

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: XV   Ordeal and Execution   As he spoke one of the strangest looking men I ever beheld entered the chapel at the door through which Carmilla had made her entrance and her exit

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: He was tall narrowchested stooping with high shoulders and dressed in black

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: His face was brown and dried in with deep furrows he wore an oddlyshaped hat with a broad leaf

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: His hair long and grizzled hung on his shoulders

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: He wore a pair of gold spectacles and walked slowly with an odd shambling gait with his face sometimes turned up to the sky and sometimes bowed down towards the ground seemed to wear a perpetual smile his long thin arms were swinging and his lank hands in old black gloves ever so much too wide for them waving and gesticulating in utter abstraction

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The very man exclaimed the General advancing with manifest delight

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: My dear Baron how happy I am to see you I had no hope of meeting you so soon

title: Carmilla
words: He signed to my father who had by this time returned and leading the fantastic old gentleman whom he called the Baron to meet him

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: He introduced him formally and they at once entered into earnest conversation

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The stranger took a roll of paper from his pocket and spread it on the worn surface of a tomb that stood by

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: He had a pencil case in his fingers with which he traced imaginary lines from point to point on the paper which from their often glancing from it together at certain points of the building I concluded to be a plan of the chapel

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: He accompanied what I may term his lecture with occasional readings from a dirty little book whose yellow leaves were closely written over

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: They sauntered together down the side aisle opposite to the spot where I was standing conversing as they went then they began measuring distances by paces and finally they all stood together facing a piece of the sidewall which they began to examine with great minuteness pulling off the ivy that clung over it and rapping the plaster with the ends of their sticks scraping here and knocking there

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: In this quest we were successful and I was glad being unspeakably fatigued when we reached home

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The arrangements for the night were singular

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The priest had performed certain solemn rites that night the purport of which I did not understand any more than I comprehended the reason of this extraordinary precaution taken for my safety during sleep

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I saw all clearly a few days later

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The disappearance of Carmilla was followed by the discontinuance of my nightly sufferings

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: You have heard no doubt of the appalling superstition that prevails in Upper and Lower Styria in Moravia Silesia in Turkish Serbia in Poland even in Russia the superstition so we must call it of the Vampire

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: If human testimony taken with every care and solemnity judicially before commissions innumerable each consisting of many members all chosen for integrity and intelligence and constituting reports more voluminous perhaps than exist upon any one other class of cases is worth anything it is difficult to deny or even to doubt the existence of such a phenomenon as the Vampire

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: For my part I have heard no theory by which to explain what I myself have witnessed and experienced other than that supplied by the ancient and wellattested belief of the country

title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Let me add a word or two about that quaint Baron Vordenburg to whose curious lore we were indebted for the discovery of the Countess Mircallas grave

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: He had taken up his abode in Gratz where living upon a mere pittance which was all that remained to him of the once princely estates of his family in Upper Styria he devoted himself to the minute and laborious investigation of the marvelously authenticated tradition of Vampirism

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: He had at his fingers ends all the great and little works upon the subject

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Magia Posthuma Phlegon de Mirabilibus Augustinus de cura pro Mortuis Philosophicae et Christianae Cogitationes de Vampiris by John Christofer Herenberg and a thousand others among which I remember only a few of those which he lent to my father

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: He had a voluminous digest of all the judicial cases from which he had extracted a system of principles that appear to governsome always and others occasionally onlythe condition of the vampire

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: I may mention in passing that the deadly pallor attributed to that sort of revenants is a mere melodramatic fiction

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: They present in the grave and when they show themselves in human society the appearance of healthy life

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: When disclosed to light in their coffins they exhibit all the symptoms that are enumerated as those which proved the vampirelife of the longdead Countess Karnstein

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: How they escape from their graves and return to them for certain hours every day without displacing the clay or leaving any trace of disturbance in the state of the coffin or the cerements has always been admitted to be utterly inexplicable

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The amphibious existence of the vampire is sustained by daily renewed slumber in the grave

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: Its horrible lust for living blood supplies the vigor of its waking existence

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: The vampire is prone to be fascinated with an engrossing vehemence resembling the passion of love by particular persons

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: In pursuit of these it will exercise inexhaustible patience and stratagem for access to a particular object may be obstructed in a hundred ways

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: In these cases it seems to yearn for something like sympathy and consent

author: Le Fanu, Joseph Sheridan
title: Carmilla
words: In ordinary ones it goes direct to its object overpowers with violence and strangles and exhausts often at a single feast

title: Carmilla
words: The vampire is apparently subject in certain situations to special conditions

author: Gautier, Théophile

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Yes

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: My story is a strange and terrible one and though I am sixtysix years of age I scarcely dare even now to disturb the ashes of that memory

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: To you I can refuse nothing but I should not relate such a tale to any less experienced mind

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: So strange were the circumstances of my story that I can scarcely believe myself to have ever actually been a party to them

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: For more than three years I remained the victim of a most singular and diabolical illusion

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Poor country priest though I was I led every night in a dreamwould to God it had been all a dreama most worldly life a damning life a life of Sardanapalus

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: One single look too freely cast upon a woman wellnigh caused me to lose my soul but finally by the grace of God and the assistance of my patron saint I succeeded in casting out the evil spirit that possessed me

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: My daily life was long interwoven with a nocturnal life of a totally different character

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: By day I was a priest of the Lord occupied with prayer and sacred things by night from the instant that I closed my eyes I became a young nobleman a fine connoisseur in women dogs and horses gambling drinking and blaspheming and when I awoke at early daybreak it seemed to me on the other hand that I had been sleeping and had only dreamed that I was a priest

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Of this somnambulistic life there now remains to me only the recollection of certain scenes and words which I cannot banish from my memory but although I never actually left the walls of my presbytery one would think to hear me speak that I were a man who weary of all worldly pleasures had become a religious seeking to end a tempestuous life in the service of God rather than a humble seminarist who has grown old in this obscure curacy situated in the depths of the woods and even isolated from the life of the century

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Yes I have loved as none in the world ever lovedwith an insensate and furious passionso violent that I am astonished it did not cause my heart to burst asunder

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Ah what nightswhat nights

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: From my earliest childhood I had felt a vocation to the priesthood so that all my studies were directed with that idea in view

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Up to the age of twentyfour my life had been only a prolonged novitiate

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Having completed my course of theology I successively received all the minor orders and my superiors judged me worthy despite my youth to pass the last awful degree

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: My ordination was fixed for Easter week

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I had never gone into the world

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: My world was confined by the walls of the college and the seminary

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I knew in a vague sort of a way that there was something called Woman but I never permitted my thoughts to dwell on such a subject and I lived in a state of perfect innocence

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Twice a year only I saw my infirm and aged mother and in those visits were comprised my sole relations with the outer world

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I regretted nothing I felt not the least hesitation at taking the last irrevocable step I was filled with joy and impatience

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Never did a betrothed lover count the slow hours with more feverish ardour I slept only to dream that I was saying mass I believed there could be nothing in the world more delightful than to be a priest I would have refused to be a king or a poet in preference

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: My ambition could conceive of no loftier aim

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I tell you this in order to show you that what happened to me could not have happened in the natural order of things and to enable you to understand that I was the victim of an inexplicable fascination

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At last the great day came

title: Clarimonde

title: Clarimonde

title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I felt like a blind man who unexpectedly recovers his sight

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: What hast thou done I comprehended at last the full horror of my situation and the funereal and awful restraints of the state into which I had just entered became clearly revealed to me

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: To be a priestthat is to be chaste to never love to observe no distinction of sex or age to turn from the sight of all beauty to put out ones own eyes to hide for ever crouching in the chill shadows of some church or cloister to visit none but the dying to watch by unknown corpses and ever bear about with one the black soutane as a garb of mourning for oneself so that your very dress might serve as a pall for your coffin

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I closed the window with violence and flung myself on my bed my heart filled with frightful hate and jealousy and gnawed my fingers and my bedcovers like a tiger that has passed ten days without food

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I know not how long I remained in this condition but at last while writhing on the bed in a fit of spasmodic fury I suddenly perceived the Abbe Serapion who was standing erect in the centre of the room watching me attentively

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Filled with shame of myself I let my head fall upon my breast and covered my face with my hands

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Romuald my friend something very extraordinary is transpiring within you observed Serapion after a few moments silence your conduct is altogether inexplicable

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Youalways so quiet so pious so gentleyou to rage in your cell like a wild beast

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Take heed brotherdo not listen to the suggestions of the devil The Evil Spirit furious that you have consecrated yourself for ever to the Lord is prowli

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Paradise

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Love

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: ing around you like a ravening wolf and making a last effort to obtain possession of you

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Instead of allowing yourself to be conquered my dear Romuald make to yourself a cuirass of prayers a buckler of mortifications and combat the enemy like a valiant man you will then assuredly overcome him

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Virtue must be proved by temptation and gold comes forth purer from the hands of the assayer

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Fear not

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Never allow yourself to become discouraged

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The most watchful and steadfast souls are at moments liable to such temptation

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Pray fast meditate and the Evil Spirit will depart from you  The words of the Abbe Serapion restored me to myself and I became a little more calm

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I came he continued to tell you that you have been appointed to the curacy of C

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The priest who had charge of it has just died and Monseigneur the Bishop has ordered me to have you installed there at once

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Be ready therefore to start tomorrow

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I responded with an inclination of the head and the Abbe retired

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I opened my missal and commenced reading some prayers but the letters became confused and blurred under my eyes the thread of the ideas entangled itself hopelessly in my brain and the volume at last fell from my hands without my being aware of it

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: To leave tomorrow without having been able to see her again to add yet another barrier to the many already interposed between us to lose for ever all hope of being able to meet her except indeed through a miracle

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Even to write to her alas would be impossible for by whom could I dispatch my letter

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: With my sacred character of priest to whom could I dare unbosom myself in whom could I confide

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I became a prey to the bitterest anxiety

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Then suddenly recurred to me the words of the Abbe Serapion regarding the artifices of the devil and the strange character of the adventure the supernatural beauty of Clarimonde the phosphoric light of her eyes the burning imprint of her hand the agony into which she had thrown me the sudden change wrought within me when all my piety vanished in a single instantthese and other things clearly testified to the work of the Evil One and perhaps that satiny hand was but the glove which concealed his claws

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Filled with terror at these fancies I again picked up the missal which had slipped from my knees and fallen upon the floor and once more gave myself up to prayer

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Next morning Serapion came to take me away

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Two mules freighted with our miserable valises awaited us at the gate

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: He mounted one and I the other as well as I knew how

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: As we passed along the streets of the city I gazed attentively at all the windows and balconies in the hope of seeing Clarimonde but it was yet early in the morning and the city had hardly opened its eyes

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Mine sought to penetrate the blinds and windowcurtains of all the palaces before which we were passing

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Serapion doubtless attributed this curiosity to my admiration of the architecture for he slackened the pace of his animal in order to give me time to look around me

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At last we passed the city gates and commenced to mount the hill beyond

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: When we arrived at its summit I turned to take a last look at the place where Clarimonde dwelt

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The shadow of a great cloud hung over all the city the contrasting colours of its blue and red roofs were lost in the uniform halftint through which here and there floated upward like white flakes of foam the smoke of freshly kindled fires

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: By a singular optical effect one edifice which surpassed in height all the neighbouring buildings that were still dimly veiled by the vapours towered up fair and lustrous with the gilding of a solitary beam of sunlightalthough actually more than a league away it seemed quite near

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The smallest details of its architecture were plainly distinguishablethe turrets the platforms the windowcasements and even the swallowtailed weathervanes

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: What is that palace I see over there all lighted up by the sun I asked Serapion

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: He shaded his eyes with his hand and having looked in the direction indicated replied It is the ancient palace which the Prince Concini has given to the courtesan Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Awful things are done there

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At that instant I know not yet whether it was a reality or an illusion I fancied I saw gliding along the terrace a shapely white figure which gleamed for a moment in passing and as quickly vanished

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: It was Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Oh did she know that at that very hour all feverish and restlessfrom the height of the rugged road which separated me from her and which alas

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I could never more descendI was directing my eyes upon the palace where she dwelt and which a mocking beam of sunlight seemed to bring nigh to me as though inviting me to enter therein as its lord

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Undoubtedly she must have known it for her soul was too sympathetically united with mine not to have felt its least emotional thrill and that subtle sympathy it must have been which prompted her to climbalthough clad only in her nightdressto the summit of the terrace amid the icy dews of the morning

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The shadow gained the palace and the scene became to the eye only a motionless ocean of roofs and gables amid which one mountainous undulation was distinctly visible

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Serapion urged his mule forward my own at once followed at the same gait and a sharp angle in the road at last hid the city of S for ever from my eyes as I was destined never to return thither

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At the close of a weary threedays journey through dismal country fields we caught sight of the cock upon the steeple of the church which I was to take charge of peeping above the trees and after having followed some winding roads fringed with thatched cottages and little gardens we found ourselves in front of the facade which certainly possessed few features of magnificence

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: A porch ornamented with some mouldings and two or three pillars rudely hewn from sandstone a tiled roof with counterforts of the same sandstone as the pillarsthat was all

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: To the left lay the cemetery overgrown with high weeds and having a great iron cross rising up in its centre to the right stood the presbytery under the shadow of the church

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: It was a house of the most extreme simplicity and frigid cleanliness

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: We entered the enclosure

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: A few chickens were picking up some oats scattered upon the ground accustomed seemingly to the black habit of ecclesiastics they showed no fear of our presence and scarcely troubled themselves to get out of our way

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: A hoarse wheezy barking fell upon our ears and we saw an aged dog running toward us

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: It was my predecessors dog

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: He had dull bleared eyes grizzled hair and every mark of the greatest age to which a dog can possibly attain

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I patted him gently and he proceeded at once to march along beside me with an air of satisfaction unspeakable

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: A very old woman who had been the housekeeper of the former cure also came to meet us and after having invited me into a little back parlour asked whether I intended to retain her

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I replied that I would take care of her and the dog and the chickens and all the furniture her master had bequeathed her at his death

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At this she became fairly transported with joy and the Abbe Serapion at once paid her the price which she asked for her little property

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: As soon as my installation was over the Abbe Serapion returned to the seminary

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I was therefore left alone with no one but myself to look to for aid or counsel

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The thought of Clarimonde again began to haunt me and in spite of all my endeavours to banish it I always found it present in my meditations

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: One evening while promenading in my little garden along the walks bordered with boxplants I fancied that I saw through the elmtrees the figure of a woman who followed my every movement and that I beheld two seagreen eyes gleaming through the foliage but it was only an illusion and on going round to the other side of the garden I could find nothing except a footprint on the sanded walka footprint so small that it seemed to have been made by the foot of a child

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The garden was enclosed by very high walls

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I searched every nook and corner of it but could discover no one there

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I have never succeeded in fully accounting for this circumstance which after all was nothing compared with the strange things which happened to me afterward

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: For a whole year I lived thus filling all the duties of my calling with the most scrupulous exactitude praying and fasting exhorting and lending ghostly aid to the sick and bestowing alms even to the extent of frequently depriving myself of the very necessaries of life

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: But I felt a great aridness within me and the sources of grace seemed closed against me

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I never found that happiness which should spring from the fulfilment of a holy mission my thoughts were far away and the words of Clarimonde were ever upon my lips like an involuntary refrain

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Oh brother meditate well on this

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Through having but once lifted my eyes to look upon a woman through one fault apparently so venial I have for years remained a victim to the most miserable agonies and the happiness of my life has been destroyed for ever

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I will not longer dwell upon those defeats or on those inward victories invariably followed by yet more terrible falls but will at once proceed to the facts of my story

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: One night my doorbell was long and violently rung

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The aged housekeeper arose and opened to the stranger and the figure of a man whose complexion was deeply bronzed and who was richly clad in a foreign costume with a poniard at his girdle appeared under the rays of Barbaras lantern

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Her first impulse was one of terror but the stranger reassured her and stated that he desired to see me at once on matters relating to my holy calling

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Barbara invited him upstairs where I was on the point of retiring

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The stranger told me that his mistress a very noble lady was lying at the point of death and desired to se

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Pray

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Barbara

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: ee a priest

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I replied that I was prepared to follow him took with me the sacred articles necessary for extreme unction and descended in all haste

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Two horses black as the night itself stood without the gate pawing the ground with impatience and veiling their chests with long streams of smoky vapour exhaled from their nostrils

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: He held the stirrup and aided me to mount upon one then merely laying his hand upon the pommel of the saddle he vaulted on the other pressed the animals sides with his knees and loosened rein

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The horse bounded forward with the velocity of an arrow

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Mine of which the stranger held the bridle also started off at a swift gallop keeping up with his companion

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: We devoured the road

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The ground flowed backward beneath us in a long streaked line of pale gray and the black silhouettes of the trees seemed fleeing by us on either side like an army in rout

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: We passed through a forest so profoundly gloomy that I felt my flesh creep in the chill darkness with superstitious fear

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The showers of bright sparks which flew from the stony road under the ironshod feet of our horses remained glowing in our wake like a fiery trail and had any one at that hour of the night beheld us bothmy guide and myselfhe must have taken us for two spectres riding upon nightmares

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Witchfires ever and anon flitted across the road before us and the nightbirds shrieked fearsomely in the depth of the woods beyond where we beheld at intervals glow the phosphorescent eyes of wild cats

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The manes of the horses became more and more dishevelled the sweat streamed over their flanks and their breath came through their nostrils hard and fast

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: But when he found them slacking pace the guide reanimated them by uttering a strange gutteral unearthly cry and the gallop recommenced with fury

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At last the whirlwind race ceased a huge black mass pierced through with many bright points of light suddenly rose before us the hoofs of our horses echoed louder upon a strong wooden drawbridge and we rode under a great vaulted archway which darkly yawned between two enormous towers

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Some great excitement evidently reigned in the castle

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Servants with torches were crossing the courtyard in every direction and above lights were ascending and descending from landing to landing

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I obtained a confused glimpse of vast masses of architecturecolumns arcades flights of steps stairwaysa royal voluptuousness and elfin magnificence of construction worthy of fairyland

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: A negro pagethe same who had before brought me the tablet from Clarimonde and whom I instantly recognisedapproached to aid me in dismounting and the majordomo attired in black velvet with a gold chain about his neck advanced to meet me supporting himself upon an ivory cane

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Large tears were falling from his eyes and streaming over his cheeks and white beard

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Too late he cried sorrowfully shaking his venerable head

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Too late sir priest

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: But if you have not been able to save the soul come at least to watch by the poor body

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: He took my arm and conducted me to the deathchamber

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I wept not less bitterly than he for I had learned that the dead one was none other than that Clarimonde whom I had so deeply and so wildly loved

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: A  priedieu  stood at the foot of the bed a bluish flame flickering in a bronze patern filled all the room with a wan deceptive light here and there bringing out in the darkness at intervals some projection of furniture or cornice

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: In a chiselled urn upon the table there was a faded white rose whose leavesexcepting one that still heldhad all fallen like odorous tears to the foot of the vase

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: A broken black mask a fan and disguises of every variety which were lying on the armchairs bore witness that death had entered suddenly and unannounced into that sumptuous dwelling

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Without daring to cast my eyes upon the bed I knelt down and commenced to repeat the Psalms for the Dead with exceeding fervour thanking God that He had placed the tomb between me and the memory of this woman so that I might thereafter be able to utter her name in my prayers as a name for ever sanctified by death

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: But my fervour gradually weakened and I fell insensibly into a reverie

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: That chamber bore no semblance to a chamber of death

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: In lieu of the fetid and cadaverous odours which I had been accustomed to breathe during such funereal vigils a languorous vapour of Oriental perfumeI know not what amorous odour of womansoftly floated through the tepid air

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: That pale light seemed rather a twilight gloom contrived for voluptuous pleasure than a substitute for the yellowflickering watchtapers which shine by the side of corpses

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I thought upon the strange destiny which enabled me to meet Clarimonde again at the very moment when she was lost to me for ever and a sigh of regretful anguish escaped from my breast

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Then it seemed to me that some one behind me had also sighed and I turned round to look

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: It was only an echo

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: But in that moment my eyes fell upon the bed of death which they had till then avoided

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The red damask curtains decorated with large flowers worked in embroidery and looped up with gold bullion permitted me to behold the fair dead lying at full length with hands joined upon her bosom

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She was covered with a linen wrapping of dazzling whiteness which formed a strong contrast with the gloomy purple of the hangings and was of so fine a texture that it concealed nothing of her bodys charming form and allowed the eye to follow those beautiful outlinesundulating like the neck of a swanwhich even death had not robbed of their supple grace

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She seemed an alabaster statue executed by some skilful sculptor to place upon the tomb of a queen or rather perhaps like a slumbering maiden over whom the silent snow had woven a spotless veil

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I could no longer maintain my constrained attitude of prayer

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The air of the alcove intoxicated me that febrile perfume of halffaded roses penetrated my very brain and I commenced to pace restlessly up and down the chamber pausing at each turn before the bier to contemplate the graceful corpse lying beneath the transparency of its shroud

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Wild fancies came thronging to my brain

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I thought to myself that she might not perhaps be really dead that she might only have feigned death for the purpose of bringing me to her castle and then declaring her love

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At one time I even thought I saw her foot move under the whiteness of the coverings and slightly disarrange the long straight folds of the windingsheet

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: And then I asked myself Is this indeed Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: What proof have I that it is she

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Might not that black page have passed into the service of some other lady

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Surely I must be going mad to torture and afflict myself thus

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: But my heart answered with a fierce throbbing It is she it is she indeed

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I approached the bed again and fixed my eyes with redoubled attention upon the object of my incertitude

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Ah must I confess it

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: That exquisite perfection of bodily form although purified and made sacred by the shadow of death affected me more voluptuously than it should have done and that repose so closely resembled slumber that one might well have mistaken it for such

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I forgot that I had come there to perform a funeral ceremony I fancied myself a young bridegroom entering the chamber of the bride who all modestly hides her fair face and through coyness seeks to keep herself wholly veiled

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Heartbroken with grief yet wild with hope shuddering at once with fear and pleasure I bent over her and grasped the corner of the sheet

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I lifted it back holding my breath all the while through fear of waking her

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: My arteries throbbed with such violence that I felt them hiss through my temples and the sweat poured from my forehead in streams as though I had lifted a mighty slab of marble

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: There indeed lay Clarimonde even as I had seen her at the church on the day of my ordination

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She was not less charming than then

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: With her death seemed but a last coquetry

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The pallor of her cheeks the less brilliant carnation of her lips her long eyelashes lowered and relieving their dark fringe against that white skin lent her an unspeakably seductive aspect of melancholy chastity and mental suffering her long loose hair still intertwined with some little blue flowers made a shining pillow for her head and veiled the nudity of her shoulders with its thick ringlets her beautiful hands purer more diaphanous than the Host were crossed on her bosom in an attitude of pious rest and silent prayer which served to counteract all that might have proven otherwise too alluringeven after deathin the exquisite roundness and ivory polish of her bare arms from which the pearl bracelets had not yet been removed

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I remained long in mute contemplation and the more I gazed the less could I persuade myself that life had really abandoned that beautiful body for ever

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I do not know whether it was an illusion or a reflection of the lamplight but it seemed to me that the blood was again commencing to circulate under that lifeless pallor although she remained all motionless

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I laid my hand lightly on her arm it was cold but not colder than her hand on the day when it touched mine at the portals of the church

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I resumed my position bending my face above her and bathing her cheek with the warm dew of my tears

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Ah what bitter feelings of despair and helplessness what agonies unutterable did I endure in that long watch

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Vainly did I wish that I could have gathered all my life into one mass that I might give it all to her and breathe into her chill remains the flame which devoured me

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The night advanced and feeling the moment of eternal separation approach I could not deny myself the last sad sweet pleasure of imprinting a kiss upon the dead lips of her who had been my only love Oh miracle

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: A faint breath mingled itself with my breath and the mouth of Clarimonde responded to the pa

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Ah

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: assionate pressure of mine

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Her eyes unclosed and lighted up with something of their former brilliancy she uttered a long sigh and uncrossing her arms passed them around my neck with a look of ineffable delight

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Ah it is thou Romuald she murmured in a voice languishingly sweet as the last vibrations of a harp

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: What ailed thee dearest

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I waited so long for thee that I am dead but we are now betrothed I can see thee and visit thee

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Adieu Romuald adieu

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I love thee

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: That is all I wished to tell thee and I give thee back the life which thy kiss for a moment recalled

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: We shall soon meet again

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Her head fell back but her arms yet encircled me as though to retain me still

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: A furious whirlwind suddenly burst in the window and entered the chamber

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The last remaining leaf of the white rose for a moment palpitated at the extremity of the stalk like a butterflys wing then it detached itself and flew forth through the open casement bearing with it the soul of Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The lamp was extinguished and I fell insensible upon the bosom of the beautiful dead

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: When I came to myself again I was lying on the bed in my little room at the presbytery and the old dog of the former cure was licking my hand which had been hanging down outside of the covers

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Barbara all trembling with age and anxiety was busying herself about the room opening and shutting drawers and emptying powders into glasses

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: On seeing me open my eyes the old woman uttered a cry of joy the dog yelped and wagged his tail but I was still so weak that I could not speak a single word or make the slightest motion

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Afterward I learned that I had lain thus for three days giving no evidence of life beyond the faintest respiration

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Those three days do not reckon in my life nor could I ever imagine whither my spirit had departed during those three days I have no recollection of aught relating to them

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Barbara told me that the same copperycomplexioned man who came to seek me on the night of my departure from the presbytery had brought me back the next morning in a close litter and departed immediately afterward

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: When I became able to collect my scattered thoughts I reviewed within my mind all the circumstances of that fateful night

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At first I thought I had been the victim of some magical illusion but ere long the recollection of other circumstances real and palpable in themselves came to forbid that supposition

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I could not believe that I had been dreaming since Barbara as well as myself had seen the strange man with his two black horses and described with exactness every detail of his figure and apparel

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Nevertheless it appeared that none knew of any castle in the neighbourhood answering to the description of that in which I had again found Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: One morning I found the Abbe Serapion in my room

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Barbara had advised him that I was ill and he had come with all speed to see me

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Although this haste on his part testified to an affectionate interest in me yet his visit did not cause me the pleasure which it should have done

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The Abbe Serapion had something penetrating and inquisitorial in his gaze which made me feel very ill at ease

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: His presence filled me with embarrassment and a sense of guilt

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At the first glance he divined my interior trouble and I hated him for his clairvoyance

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: While he inquired after my health in hypocritically honeyed accents he constantly kept his two great yellow lioneyes fixed upon me and plunged his look into my soul like a soundinglead

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Then he asked me how I directed my parish if I was happy in it how I passed the leisure hours allowed me in the intervals of pastoral duty whether I had become acquainted with many of the inhabitants of the place what was my favourite reading and a thousand other such questions

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I answered these inquiries as briefly as possible and he without ever waiting for my answers passed rapidly from one subject of query to another

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: That conversation had evidently no connection with what he actually wished to say

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At last without any premonition but as though repeating a piece of news which he had recalled on the instant and feared might otherwise be forgotten subsequently he suddenly said in a clear vibrant voice which rang in my ears like the trumpets of the Last Judgment  The great courtesan Clarimonde died a few days ago at the close of an orgie which lasted eight days and eight nights

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: It was something infernally splendid

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The abominations of the banquets of Belshazzar and Cleopatra were reenacted there

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Good God what age are we living in

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The guests were served by swarthy slaves who spoke an unknown tongue and who seemed to me to be veritable demons

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The livery of the very least among them would have served for the galadress of an emperor

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: There have always been very strange stories told of this Clarimonde and all her lovers came to a violent or miserable end

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: They used to say that she was a ghoul a female vampire but I believe she was none other than Beelzebub himself

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: He ceased to speak and commenced to regard me more attentively than ever as though to observe the effect of his words on me

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I could not refrain from starting when I heard him utter the name of Clarimonde and this news of her death in addition to the pain it caused me by reason of its coincidence with the nocturnal scenes I had witnessed filled me with an agony and terror which my face betrayed despite my utmost endeavours to appear composed

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Serapion fixed an anxious and severe look upon me and then observed My son I must warn you that you are standing with foot raised upon the brink of an abyss take heed lest you fall therein

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Satans claws are long and tombs are not always true to their trust

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The tombstone of Clarimonde should be sealed down with a triple seal for if report be true it is not the first time she has died

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: May God watch over you Romuald

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: And with these words the Abbe walked slowly to the door

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I did not see him again at that time for he left for S almost immediately

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I became completely restored to health and resumed my accustomed duties

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The memory of Clarimonde and the words of the old Abbe were constantly in my mind nevertheless no extraordinary event had occurred to verify the funereal predictions of Serapion and I had commenced to believe that his fears and my own terrors were overexaggerated when one night I had a strange dream

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I had hardly fallen asleep when I heard my bedcurtains drawn apart as their rings slided back upon the curtain rod with a sharp sound

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I rose up quickly upon my elbow and beheld the shadow of a woman standing erect before me

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I recognised Clarimonde immediately

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She bore in her hand a little lamp shaped like those which are placed in tombs and its light lent her fingers a rosy transparency which extended itself by lessening degrees even to the opaque and milky whiteness of her bare arm

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Her only garment was the linen windingsheet which had shrouded her when lying upon the bed of death

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She sought to gather its folds over her bosom as though ashamed of being so scantily clad but her little hand was not equal to the task

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She was so white that the colour of the drapery blended with that of her flesh under the pallid rays of the lamp

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Enveloped with this subtle tissue which betrayed all the contour of her body she seemed rather the marble statue of some fair antique bather than a woman endowed with life

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: But dead or living statue or woman shadow or body her beauty was still the same only that the green light of her eyes was less brilliant and her mouth once so warmly crimson was only tinted with a faint tender rosiness like that of her cheeks

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The little blue flowers which I had noticed entwined in her hair were withered and dry and had lost nearly all their leaves but this did not prevent her from being charmingso charming that notwithstanding the strange character of the adventure and the unexplainable manner in which she had entered my room I felt not even for a moment the least fear

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She placed the lamp on the table and seated herself at the foot of my bed then bending toward me she said in that voice at once silvery clear and yet velvety in its sweet softness such as I never heard from any lips save hers  I have kept thee long in waiting dear Romuald and it must have seemed to thee that I had forgotten thee

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: But I come from afar off very far off and from a land whence no other has ever yet returned

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: There is neither sun nor moon in that land whence I come all is but space and shadow there is neither road nor pathway no earth for the foot no air for the wing and nevertheless behold me here for Love is stronger than Death and must conquer him in the end

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Oh what sad faces and fearful things I have seen on my way hither

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: What difficulty my soul returned to earth through the power of will alone has had in finding its body and reinstating itself therein

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: What terrible efforts I had to make ere I could lift the ponderous slab with which they had covered me

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: See the palms of my poor hands are all bruised

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Kiss them sweet love that they may be healed

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She laid the cold palms of her hands upon ray mouth one after the other

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I kissed them indeed many times and she the while watched me with a smile of ineffable affection

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I confess to my shame that I had entirely forgotten the advice of the Abbe Serapion and the sacred office wherewith I had been invested

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I had fallen without resistance and at the first assault

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I had not even made the least effort to repel the tempter

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The fresh coolness of Clarimondes skin penetrated my own and I felt voluptuous tremors pass over my whole body

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Poor child in spite of all I saw afterward I can hardly yet believe she was a demon at least she had no appearance of being such and never did Satan so skilfully conceal his claws and horns

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She had drawn her feet up beneath her and squatted down on the edge of the co
