words: ouch in an attitude full of negligent coquetry

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: From time to time she passed her little hand through my hair and twisted it into curls as though trying how a new style of wearing it would become my face

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I abandoned myself to her hands with the most guilty pleasure while she accompanied her gentle play with the prettiest prattle

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The most remarkable fact was that I felt no astonishment whatever at so extraordinary ah adventure and as in dreams one finds no difficulty in accepting the most fantastic events as simple facts so all these circumstances seemed to me perfectly natural in themselves

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I loved thee long ere I saw thee dear Romuald and sought thee everywhere

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Thou wast my dream and I first saw thee in the church at the fatal moment

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I said at once It is he

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I gave thee a look into which I threw all the love I ever had all the love I now have all the love I shall ever have for theea look that would have damned a cardinal or brought a king to his knees at my feet in view of all his court

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Thou remainedst unmoved preferring thy God to me  Ah how jealous I am of that God whom thou didst love and still lovest more than me  Woe is me unhappy one that I am

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I can never have thy heart all to myself I whom thou didst recall to life with a kissdead Clarimonde who for thy sake bursts asunder the gates of the tomb and comes to consecrate to thee a life which she has resumed only to make thee happy

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: All her words were accompanied with the most impassioned caresses which bewildered my sense and my reason to such an extent that I did not fear to utter a frightful blasphemy for the sake of consoling her and to declare that I loved her as much as God

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Her eyes rekindled and shone like chrysoprases

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: In truthin very truthas

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: much as God she cried flinging her beautiful arms around me Since it is so thou wilt come with me thou wilt follow me whithersoever I desire

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Thou wilt cast away thy ugly black habit

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Thou shalt be the proudest and most envied of cavaliers thou shalt be my lover

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: To be the acknowledged lover of Clarimonde who has refused even a Pope

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: That will be something to feel proud of

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Ah the fair unspeakably happy existence the beautiful golden life we shall live together

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: And when shall we depart my fair sir  Tomorrow

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Tomorrow

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I cried in my delirium

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Tomorrow then so let it be she answered

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: In the meanwhile I shall have opportunity to change my toilet for this is a little too light and in nowise suited for a voyage

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I must also forthwith notify all my friends who believe me dead and mourn for me as deeply as they are capable of doing

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The money the dresses the carriagesall will be ready

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I shall call for thee at this same hour

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Adieu dear heart

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: And she lightly touched my forehead with her lips

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The lamp went out the curtains closed again and all became dark a leaden dreamless sleep fell on me and held me unconscious until the morning following

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I awoke later than usual and the recollection of this singular adventure troubled me during the whole day

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I finally persuaded myself that it was a mere vapour of my heated imagination

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Nevertheless its sensations had been so vivid that it was difficult to persuade myself that they were not real and it was not without some presentiment of what was going to happen that I got into bed at last after having prayed God to drive far from me all thoughts of evil and to protect the chastity of my slumber

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I soon fell into a deep sleep and my dream was continued

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The curtains again parted and I beheld Clarimonde not as on the former occasion pale in her pale windingsheet with the violets of death upon her cheeks but gay sprightly jaunty in a superb travellingdress of green velvet trimmed with gold lace and looped up on either side to allow a glimpse of satin petticoat

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Her blond hair escaped in thick ringlets from beneath a broad black felt hat decorated with white feathers whimsically twisted into various shapes

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: In one hand she held a little ridingwhip terminated by a golden whistle

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She tapped me lightly with it and exclaimed Well my fine sleeper is this the way you make your preparations

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I thought I would find you up and dressed

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Arise quickly we have no time to lose

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I leaped out of bed at once

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Come dress yourself and let us go she continued pointing to a little package she had brought with her

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The horses are becoming impatient of delay and champing their bits at the door

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: We ought to have been by this time at least ten leagues distant from here

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I dressed myself hurriedly and she handed me the articles of apparel herself one by one bursting into laughter from time to time at my awkwardness as she explained to me the use of a garment when I had made a mistake

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She hurriedly arranged my hair and this done held up before me a little pocketmirror of Venetian crystal rimmed with silver filigreework and playfully asked How dost find thyself now

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Wilt engage me for thy valet de chambre  I was no longer the same person and I could not even recognise myself

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I resembled my former self no more than a finished statue resembles a block of stone

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: My old face seemed but a coarse daub of the one reflected in the mirror

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I was handsome and my vanity was sensibly tickled by the metamorphosis

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: That elegant apparel that richly embroidered vest had made of me a totally different personage and I marvelled at the power of transformation owned by a few yards of cloth cut after a certain pattern

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The spirit of my costume penetrated my very skin and within ten minutes more I had become something of a coxcomb

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: In order to feel more at ease in my new attire I took several turns up and down the room

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Clarimonde watched me with an air of maternal pleasure and appeared well satisfied with her work

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Come enough of this childs play

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Let us start Romuald dear

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: We have far to go and we may not get there in time

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She took my hand and led me forth

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: All the doors opened before her at a touch and we passed by the dog without awaking him

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At the gate we found Margheritone waiting the same swarthy groom who had once before been myescort

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: He held the bridles of three horses all black like those which bore us to the castleone for me one for him one for Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Those horses must have been Spanish genets born of mares fecundated by a zephyr for they were fleet as the wind itself and the moon which had just risen at our departure to light us on the way rolled over the sky like a wheel detached from her own chariot

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: We beheld her on the right leaping from tree to tree and putting herself out of breath in the effort to keep up with us

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Soon we came upon a level plain where hard by a clump of trees a carriage with four vigorous horses awaited us

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: We entered it and the postillions urged their animals into a mad gallop

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I had one arm around Clarimondes waist and one of her hands clasped in mine her head leaned upon my shoulder and I felt her bosom half bare lightly pressing against my arm

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I had never known such intense happiness

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: In that hour I had forgotten everything and I no more remembered having ever been a priest than I remembered what I had been doing in my mothers womb so great was the fascination which the evil spirit exerted upon me

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: From that night my nature seemed in some sort to have become halved and there were two men within me neither of whom knew the other

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At one moment I believed myself a priest who dreamed nightly that he was a gentleman at another that I was a gentleman who dreamed he was a priest

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I could no longer distinguish the dream from the reality nor could I discover where the reality began or where ended the dream

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The exquisite young lord and libertine railed at the priest the priest loathed the dissolute habits of the young lord

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Two spirals entangled and confounded the one with the other yet never touching would afford a fair representation of this bicephalic life which I lived

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Despite the strange character of my condition I do not believe that I ever inclined even for a moment to madness

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I always retained with extreme vividness all the perceptions of my two lives

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Only there was one absurd fact which I could not explain to myselfnamely that the consciousness of the same individuality existed in two men so opposite in character

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: It was an anomaly for which I could not accountwhether I believed myself to be the cure of the little village of C or  Il Signor Romualdo  the titled lover of Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Be that as it may I lived at least I believed that I lived in Venice

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I have never been able to discover rightly how much of illusion and how much of reality there was in this fantastic adventure

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: We dwelt in a great palace on the Canaleio filled with frescoes and statues and containing two Titians in the noblest style of the great master which were hung in Clarimondes chamber

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: It was a palace well worthy of a king

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: We had each our gondola our  barcarolli  in family livery our music hall and our special poet

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Clarimonde always lived upon a magnificent scale there was something of Cleopatra in her nature

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: As for me I had the retinue of a princes son and I was regarded with as much reverential respect as though I had been of the family of one of the twelve Apostles or the four Evangelists of the Most Serene Republic

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I would not have turned aside to allow even the Doge to pass and I do not believe that since Satan fell from heaven any creature was ever prouder or more insolent than I

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I went to the Ridotto and played with a luck which seemed absolutely infernal

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I received the best of all societythe sons of ruined families women of the theatre shrewd knaves parasites hectoring swashbucklers

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: But notwithstanding the dissipation of such a life I always remained faithful to Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I loved her wildly

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She would have excited satiety itself and chained inconstancy

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: e Clarimonde was to have twenty mistresses ay to possess all women so mobile so varied of aspect so fresh in new charms was she all in herselfa very chameleon of a woman in sooth

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She made you commit with her the infidelity you would have committed with another by donning to perfection the character the attraction the style of beauty of the woman who appeared to please you

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She returned my love a hundredfold and it was in vain that the young patricians and even the Ancients of the Council of Ten made her the most magnificent proposals

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: A Foscari even went so far as to offer to espouse her

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She rejected all his overtures

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Of gold she had enough

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She wished no longer for anything but lovea love youthful pure evoked by herself and which should be a first and last passion

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I would have been perfectly happy but for a cursed nightmare which recurred every night and in which I believed myself to be a poor village cure practising mortification and penance for my excesses during the day

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Reassured by my constant association with her I never thought further of the strange manner in which I had become acquainted with Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: But the words of the Abbe Serapion concerning her recurred often to my memory and never ceased to cause me uneasiness

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: For some time the health of Clarimonde had not been so good as usual her complexion grew paler day by day

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The physicians who were summoned could not comprehend the nature of her malady and knew not how to treat it

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: They all prescribed some insignificant remedies and never called a second time

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Her paleness nevertheless visibly increased and she became colder and colder until she seemed almost as white and dead as upon that memorable night in the unknown castle

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I grieved with anguish unspeakable to behold her thus slowly perishing and she touched by my agony smiled upon me sweetly and sadly with the fateful smile of those who feel that they must die

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: One morning I was seated at her bedside and breakfasting from a little table placed close at hand so that I might not be obliged to leave her for a single instant

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: In the act of cutting some fruit I accidentally inflicted rather a deep gash on my finger

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: The blood immediately gushed forth in a little purple jet and a few drops spurted upon Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Her eyes flashed her face suddenly assumed an expression of savage and ferocious joy such as I had never before observed in her

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She leaped out of her bed with animal agilitythe agility as it were of an ape or a catand sprang upon my wound which she commenced to suck with an air of unutterable pleasure

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: She swallowed the blood in little mouthfuls slowly and carefully like a connoisseur tasting a wine from Xeres or Syracuse

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Gradually her eyelids half closed and the pupils of her green eyes became oblong instead of round

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: From time to time she paused in order to kiss my hand then she would recommence to press her lips to the lips of the wound in order to coax forth a few more ruddy drops

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: When she found that the blood would no longer come she arose with eyes liquid and brilliant rosier than a May dawn her face full and fresh her hand warm and moistin fine more beautiful than ever and in the most perfect health

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I shall not die

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I shall not die she cried clinging to my neck half mad with joy

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I can love thee yet for a long time

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: My life is thine and all that is of me comes from thee

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: A few drops of thy rich and noble blood more precious and more potent than all the elixirs of the earth have given me back life

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: This scene long haunted my memory and inspired me with strange doubts in regard to Clarimonde and the same evening when slumber had transported me to my presbytery I beheld the Abbe Serapion graver and more anxious of aspect than ever

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Wretched young man into how terrible a plight have you fallen The tone in which he uttered these words powerfully affected me but in spite of its vividness even that impression was soon dissipated and a thousand other cares erased it from my mind

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: At last one evening while looking into a mirror whose traitorous position she had not taken into account I saw Clarimonde in the act of emptying a powder into the cup of spiced wine which she had long been in the habit of preparing after our repasts

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I took the cup feigned to carry it to my lips and then placed it on the nearest article of furniture as though intending to finish it at my leisure

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Taking advantage of a moment when the fair ones back was turned I threw the contents under the table after which I retired to my chamber and went to bed fully resolved not to sleep but to watch and discover what should come of all this mystery

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Sleep my god my child

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile

title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Yet my priestly scruples commenced to torment me more than ever and I was at a loss to imagine what new penance I could invent in order to mortify and subdue my flesh

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: In the effort to avoid falling under the influence of these wearisome hallucinations I strove to prevent myself from being overcome by sleep

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I held my eyelids open with my fingers and stood for hours together leaning upright against the wall fighting sleep with all my might but the dust of drowsiness invariably gathered upon my eyes at last and finding all resistance useless I would have to let my arms fall in the extremity of despairing weariness and the current of slumber would again bear me away to the perfidious shores

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Serapion addressed me with the most vehement exhortations severely reproaching me for my softness and want of fervour

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: Finally one day when I was more wretched than usual he said to me There is but one way by which you can obtain relief from this continual torment and though it is an extreme measure it must be made use of violent diseases require violent remedies

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: I know where Clarimonde is buried

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
words: After having directed the rays of the dark lantern upon the inscriptions of several tombs we came at last upon a great slab half concealed by huge weeds and devoured by mosses and parasitic plants whereupon we deciphered the opening lines of the epitaph       Here lies Clarimonde      Who was famed in her lifetime      As the fairest of women

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde

title: Clarimonde

author: Gautier, Théophile

author: Gautier, Théophile
title: Clarimonde
